**LISTING PROSPECTUS**

**NOT FOR GENERAL DISTRIBUTION IN THE UNITED STATES**

**Quatrim S.A.S.**

**€800,000,000 5.875% Senior Secured Notes due 2024**

Quatrim S.A.S., a société par actions simplifiée organized under the laws of France, having its registered office at 1, cours Antoine Guichard, 42000 Saint-Étienne,
France (the “Issuer”), is offering (the “Offering”) €800.0 million aggregate principal amount of its 5.875% senior secured notes due 2024 (the “Notes”). The Issuer
is owned directly by Casino Participations France S.A.S. (“CPF”), which is in turn owned directly by Casino, Guichard-Perrachon S.A. (“CGP”). The Notes will
be issued pursuant to an indenture (the “Indenture”) to be dated November 20, 2019 (the “Issue Date”), among, inter alios, the Issuer, the Initial Note Guarantors
(as defined below), Citibank, N.A., London Branch, as trustee (the “Trustee”) and as security agent (the “Security Agent”).
The Notes will bear interest at a rate of 5.875% per annum and will mature on January 15, 2024. The Issuer will pay interest semi-annually in arrears on the Notes
on May 15 and November 15 of each year, commencing on May 15, 2020. Interest on the Notes will accrue from the Issue Date. CGP and CPF, the indirect and
direct parents of the Issuer, respectively, Distribution Casino France S.A.S. (“DCF”) and Monoprix S.A.S., each a direct or indirect subsidiary of CGP (together,
the “Initial Note Guarantors”) will guarantee the Notes on a senior unsecured basis (each an “Initial **Note Guarantee” and collectively, the “Initial Note**
**Guarantees”). No later than December 31, 2019, Casino Finance S.A. (“Casino Finance”) will guarantee the Notes on a senior unsecured basis (the “Casino**
**Finance Note Guarantee”). No later than the earlier of (i) 30 days after the Latam Reorganization Completion Date (as such term is defined herein) and (ii) March**
31, 2020, Segisor S.A.S., a subsidiary of CGP (“Segisor”, together with Casino Finance, the “Subsequent Guarantors” and together with the Initial Note
Guarantors and Casino Finance, the “Note Guarantors”) will guarantee the Notes on a senior unsecured basis (the “Segisor Guarantee” and, together with the
Initial Note Guarantees and the Casino Finance Note Guarantee, the “Note Guarantees”). The Note Guarantees will be subject to such limitations as described
elsewhere herein.
The Offering is expected to be consummated on the Issue Date, which may be prior to the date of the execution of the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement
in an aggregate amount of at least €1.8 billion. If the Offering is consummated prior thereto, pending the execution of the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement
providing for the New Revolving Credit Facility in an aggregate amount of at least €1.8 billion, the Initial Purchasers (as defined herein) will, concurrently with
the issuance of the Notes on the Issue Date, deposit the gross proceeds of the Offering into an escrow account for the benefit of the holders of the Notes (the
“Escrow Account”). The Escrow Account will be pledged on the Issue Date in favor of the Trustee for the benefit of itself and for the benefit of the holders of the
Notes (the “Escrow Account Charge”). The release of the proceeds of the Offering from the Escrow Account will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions.
If the execution of the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement does not occur on or prior to December 20, 2019, or upon the occurrence of certain other events,
the Notes will be subject to a Special Mandatory Redemption (as defined herein) at a price equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes, plus accrued
and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the Special Mandatory Redemption Date (as defined herein). See “Description of the Notes—Escrow of
_Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption”. If the Offering is consummated concurrently with or after the execution of the New Revolving Credit Facility_
Agreement in an aggregate amount of at least €1.8 billion, the foregoing escrow procedures will not apply, and the Initial Purchasers will transfer the net proceeds
of the Offering in accordance with the instructions provided by the Issuer on the Issue Date.
At any time prior to November 15, 2021, the Issuer will be entitled, at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the
principal amount of the Notes redeemed plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the redemption date plus a “make-whole” premium, as
described in this listing prospectus (the “Listing Prospectus”). At any time on or after November 15, 2021, the Issuer may redeem all or part of the Notes at the
redemption prices set forth herein. The Issuer may also redeem all of the Notes upon the occurrence of certain changes in applicable tax law at a redemption price
equal to 100% of the outstanding amount of the Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any. Upon the occurrence of certain events
constituting a change of control, each holder of the Notes may require the Issuer to repurchase all or a portion of its Notes at 101% of their principal amount plus
accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any. See “Description of the Notes”.
The Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuer, will rank equal in right of payment to all of the Issuer’s existing and future senior indebtedness and will
rank senior to all of the Issuer’s future indebtedness that is subordinated in right of payment to the Notes. Each of the Note Guarantees will rank equal in right of
payment with all existing and future obligations of each Guarantor, and will rank senior in right of payment with all existing and future obligations of each Guarantor
that are expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Note Guarantee. As of the Issue Date, the Issuer’s obligations under the Indenture will be secured by
the Escrow Account Charge (in the event the proceeds of the Offering are deposited into escrow, and then only until the Escrow Release Date (as defined herein))
and the Note Collateral (as defined herein) on a first-ranking basis. The Note Collateral includes pledges over (i) the securities account to which the outstanding
shares of Immobilière Groupe Casino (“IGC”) held by the Issuer are credited and which, as of the Issue Date, will contain all of the outstanding shares of IGC, (ii)
all intragroup receivables owed to the Issuer under the Proceeds Loans, (iii) the bank accounts of the Issuer and (iv) the Bond Segregated Accounts (as defined
herein), all as described under “Description of the Notes—Security”. The validity and enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the security interests in the Note
Collateral and the liability of the Guarantors will be subject to the limitations described in “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity
_and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and Security Interests”._
There is currently no public market for the Notes. Application has been made to list the Notes on the Official List of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange and to admit
them to trading on the Professional Segment of the Euro MTF Market. This offering memorandum constitutes a prospectus for purposes of Part IV of the
Luxembourg law on Prospectuses for securities dated July 16, 2019.
**Investing in the Notes involves risks. See “Risk Factors” beginning on page 47 for a discussion of certain risks that you should consider in connection with**
**an investment in the Notes.**

**Issue price for the Notes: 100% of principal plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, from the Issue Date.**

**The Notes and the Note Guarantees have not been and will not be registered under the U.S. Securities Act of 1933, as amended (the “Securities Act”), or**
**the securities laws of any other jurisdiction. Accordingly, the Notes and the Note Guarantees are being offered and sold inside the United States only to**
**qualified institutional buyers (“QIBs”) in accordance with Rule 144A under the Securities Act (“Rule 144A”) and non-U.S. persons outside the United**
**States in offshore transactions in accordance with Regulation S under the Securities Act (“Regulation S”). Prospective purchasers that are QIBs are**
**hereby notified that the Initial Purchasers may be relying on the exemption from the provisions of Section 5 of the Securities Act provided by Rule 144A.**
**See “Notice to Investors”, “Plan of Distribution” and “Transfer Restrictions” for additional information about eligible offerees and transfer restrictions.**
The Notes will be issued in minimum denominations of €100,000 and integral multiples of €1,000 in excess thereof. The Notes were represented upon issuance by
one or more global notes in registered form, which were deposited and registered in the name of a nominee for a common depositary for Euroclear Bank SA/NV
(“Euroclear”) and Clearstream Banking S.A. (“Clearstream”) on the Issue Date. See “Book-Entry, Delivery and Form”.

**_IFRS 16 – Leases_**

IFRS 16 – Leases, which the IASB published in January 2016 and which became mandatory for companies
reporting in IFRS from January 1, 2019, eliminates the distinction between operating and finance leases, and
requires almost all leases to be recognized on the balance sheet. Under this new standard, an asset (the right to use
the leased asset) and a financial liability, measured as the net present value of future lease payments, are
recognized. Short term leases and low value leases are exempted. The new standard affects certain commonly
used financial ratios and performance metrics because of its impact on the balance sheet and on the nature of the
expenses related to leases, as rent expenses are substantially replaced with depreciation and finance costs.

We have applied the IFRS 16 standard from its mandatory adoption date of January 1, 2019. In the preparation of
our financial statements as of and for the six months ended June 30, 2019, we applied the full retrospective
transition approach and have restated all comparative information for the prior comparative period in accordance
with IAS 8 – Accounting Policies, Changes in Accounting Estimates and Errors. We have not, however, restated
our financial statements as of and for the years ended December 31, 2016, 2017 and 2018 presented in this Listing
Prospectus to give effect to IFRS 16.

Our discussion of our results of operations from continuing operations for the six months ended June 30, 2018
and 2019 presented herein is on a pre-IFRS 16 basis. We also present certain non-IFRS measures on a pre-IFRS
16 basis in this Listing Prospectus. See “—Other Financial Measures”. While we will be required under IFRS to
produce financial statements that give effect to IFRS 16, compliance with our covenants under the Indenture, the
New Term Loan B Facility (as defined below) and the New Revolving Credit Facility (as defined below) will be
calculated without taking into account the impact of IFRS 16.

**_IFRS 15 – Revenue from Contracts with Customers_**

IFRS 15 – Revenue from Contracts with Customers defines the principles for recognizing revenue and replaces
IAS 18 – Revenue, IAS 11 – Construction Contracts and all related interpretations. The standard defines a single
model for recognizing revenue, in five steps. It introduces new concepts and principles regarding the recognition
of revenue, in particular the identification of performance obligations and the allocation of the transaction price
for contracts with multiple performance obligations.

We decided to apply IFRS 15 from January 1, 2018 under the full retrospective approach, by restating comparative
information. In view of the nature of our businesses, the application of the standard had no material impact on our
previously published revenue and trading profit. Our discussion in this Listing Prospectus of our results of
operations and cash flows for the year ended December 31, 2018 presents for the comparative period the restated
amounts for the year ended December 31, 2017. However, our discussion in this Listing Prospectus of our results
of operations and cash flows for the year ended December 31, 2017 compared with the year ended December 31,
2016 does not give effect to IFRS 15.


-----

In connection with our adoption of IFRS 15, we changed the presentation of the income statement appearing in
our consolidated financial statements beginning with our consolidated financial statements as of and for the year
ended December 31, 2018, with a restated presentation of the comparative information as of and for the year ended
December 31, 2017. We did not, however, restate our consolidated financial statements as of and for the year
December 31, 2017 (which include a presentation of comparative information as of and for the year ended
December 31, 2016). To facilitate the review of these periods and present our financial information in a
comparable manner:

- where we present income statement information for the year ended December 31, 2017 alongside income
statement information for the year ended December 31, 2018, we present such income statement information
for the year ended December 31, 2017 restated for IFRS 15; and

- where we present income statement information for the year ended December 31, 2017 alongside income
statement information for the year ended December 31, 2016, we present such income statement information
for the year ended December 31, 2017 without any such IFRS 15 restatement, as it appears in our consolidated
financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2017.

**_IAS 29 – Financial Reporting in Hyper-Inflationary Economies_**

Grupo Éxito conducts part of its business in Argentina, which has experienced hyper-inflation. Beginning on
January 1, 2018, we have applied IAS 29 – Financial Reporting in Hyperinflationary Economies with limited
retrospective application to address this issue in our financial statements. IAS 29 requires that the statements of
financial position and income statements of subsidiaries operating in hyperinflationary economies should be (i)
restated by applying a general price index so that they are stated in terms of the measuring unit currency at the
end of the reporting period and (ii) converted into euros at the period-end exchange-rate. We have restated the
comparative period for the six months ended June 30, 2018 of our interim condensed consolidated financial
statements as of and for the six months ended June 30, 2019. We have not restated our consolidated financial
statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2017 nor our consolidated financial statements as of and
for the year ended December 31, 2016 appearing therein and herein, and neither gives effect to IAS 29.

Our discussion in this Listing Prospectus of our results of operations and cash flows for the year ended December
31, 2017 with the year ended December 31, 2016 discuss our 2017 results prior to the restatement.

**_IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments_**

IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments defines new principles covering the classification and measurement of financial
instruments, the recognition of impairment provisions for credit risk on financial assets and hedge accounting. We
have applied IFRS 9 as from January 1, 2018 by recording the cumulative impact in opening equity at the transition
date. In the aggregate, the changes resulting from our application of IFRS 9 are immaterial.

**Other Financial Measures**

This Listing Prospectus contains certain financial measures and ratios, including underlying net profit/(loss),
Group share, free cash flow before and after dividends and net interest paid, gross capital expenditure, net capital
expenditure, trading profit, EBITDA, net debt, same-store sales, organic growth and certain leverage and coverage
ratios that are not required by, defined under or presented in accordance with IFRS (the “Non-IFRS Measures”).
The information presented by Non-IFRS Measures is unaudited and has not been prepared in accordance with
IFRS.

We define the Non IFRS Measures as follows:

  - **Underlying net profit/(loss), Group share corresponds to net profit from continuing operations,**
adjusted for (i) the impact of other operating income and expenses, (ii) the impact of non-recurring
financial items, (iii) income tax expense/benefit related to these adjustments and (iv) minority interests
in underlying profit/(loss) (as defined below), and excluding the share attributable to non-controlling
interests.

Non-recurring financial items consist of changes in the fair value of equity derivatives (such as total
return swaps and forward contracts on CBD shares) and the effects of discounting tax liabilities in Brazil.

  - **Minority interests in underlying profit/(loss) represent the share of underlying net profit/(loss)**
attributable to non-controlling interests. This indicator is therefore equal to net profit from continuing
operations attributable to non-controlling interests, adjusted for non-controlling interests in other
operating income and expenses and the impact of non-recurring financial items, as well as income tax

i


-----

expense/benefits related to these adjustments (see the definition of underlying net profit/loss, Group
share).

The Group uses these indicators to measure changes in recurring profit from operations.

- **Free cash flow before dividends and net interest paid is defined by the Group as net cash from (used**
in) operating activities, as presented in the consolidated statement of cash flows, less net capital
expenditure.

- **Free cash flow after dividends and net interest paid is defined by the Group as free cash flow before**
dividends and net interest paid less dividends and net interest paid.

The Group uses these indicators to measure cash flow arising from and used in operating activities.
Management believes that free cash flow thus defined provides investors with additional perspective on
cash flow available for debt repayments and acquisitions (and, in the case of Free cash flow before
dividends and net interest paid, dividends), after accounting for net capital expenditures to support
ongoing business operations, interest on borrowings and long-term value creation. Free cash flow is used
to measure Group performance and overall liquidity.

We present these indicators in this Listing Prospectus before and after giving effect to the Asset Disposal
Plan and Rocade Plan (each as defined below), as applicable, in order to highlight the impact of these
plans on our free cash flow.

- **Gross capital expenditure, corresponds to “Cash outflows related to acquisitions of property, plant and**
equipment, intangible assets and investment property”, as presented in our consolidated statement of cash
flows.

- **Net capital expenditure, a component of Free cash flow before dividends and net interest paid and Free**
cash flow after dividends and net interest paid, corresponds to gross capital expenditure less “Cash
inflows related to disposals of property, plant and equipment, intangible assets and investment property
“, as presented in our consolidated statement of cash flows.

- **Trading profit is defined as operating profit before other operating income and expenses. Other**
operating income and other operating expenses include certain items which, by definition, are not
included in an assessment of a business unit’s recurring operating performance, such as gains and losses
on disposals of non-current assets, impairment losses on non-current assets, and income/expenses related
to changes in the scope of consolidation (for example, transaction costs and fees for acquisitions of
control, gains and losses from disposals of subsidiaries, remeasurement at fair value of previously-held
interests) and (ii) certain non-recurring items that would distort analyses of the Group’s recurring
profitability. They are defined as significant items of income and expense that are limited in number,
unusual or abnormal, whose occurrence is rare. Examples include restructuring costs (such as
reorganization costs and the costs of converting stores to new concepts) and provisions and expenses for
litigation and risks (including discounting adjustments).

On a pre-IFRS 16 basis, trading profit includes operating lease expenses. On a post-IFRS 16 basis, trading
profit does not include lease payments except for variable lease payments, leases for which the
underlying asset is of low value and depreciation of the right-of-use asset.

- **EBITDA, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, is defined as trading profit**
plus recurring depreciation and amortization expenses included in trading profit (but excluding
impairment of inventories and trade receivables, other receivables and provisions for litigation and risks
included in trade profit).

On a pre-IFRS 16 basis, trading profit includes all operating lease expenses. On a post-IFRS 16 basis,
trading profit does not include lease expenses except for variable lease expenses, leases for which the
underlying asset is of low value and depreciation of the right-of-use asset.

- **Net debt is defined as loans and other borrowings including related derivatives with a negative fair value**
designated as fair value hedges, less (i) cash and cash equivalents, (ii) financial assets held for cash
management purposes and as short-term investments, (iii) derivatives with a positive fair value
designated as fair value hedges, (iv) financial assets arising from a significant disposal of non-current
assets and (v) net assets held for sale attributable to direct owners of the selling subsidiary.

- **Same-store sales is defined as described in “Management’s Discussion & Analysis of Financial**
_Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting Comparability of Results of Operations—_
_Organic Growth and Same-Store Growth—Same-Store Growth”._

ii

  - **Organic growth means is defined as described in “Management’s Discussion & Analysis of Financial**
_Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting Comparability of Results of Operations—_
_Organic Growth and Same-Store Growth—Organic Growth”._

  - **Gross merchandise volume (“GMV”), with respect to our E-commerce segment, corresponds to sales,**
including tax, made directly on Cdiscount’s websites and by independent marketplace merchants.

We present Non-IFRS Measures because we believe that they provide additional information that is useful to the
market when analyzing the Group’s underlying trends, as well as its performance and financial position. These
indicators are also used by management to analyze performance. As they are not defined in any IFRS standard,
they are not directly comparable with indicators with similarly titled measures reported by other companies. They
are not intended to replace the IFRS indicators presented in the financial statements, nor should they be seen as
more important.

Certain of the Non-IFRS Measures presented in this Listing Prospectus are based on a number of assumptions that

Because of these limitations, the Non-IFRS Measures should not be considered as measures of discretionary cash

**Overview**

We are a leading major multi-format, multi-banner and multi-channel retailer with over 120 years of history,
offering a diverse range of products and services to customers primarily located in France and, through our
interests in Grupo Éxito and GPA, in Latin America. We offer both brand-name and private label food and
consumer products through traditional retail stores as well as e-commerce websites and apps. We also provide
business-to-business and business-to-consumer services through our portfolio of complementary lines of business.

Our retail banners operate under formats which aim to adapt to current consumer trends and needs across the
various geographies in which we operate. Our premium retail format offers many innovative services and a highquality shopping experience. Our convenience retail format is adapted to both city centers and rural areas, offering
everyday basics to meet the expectations of customers searching for quality, authenticity and service. Our
hypermarket, cash & carry and discount retail formats offer a wide range of quality products at affordable prices.
We believe most of our banners enjoy leading market positions in most of our markets.

We have a strong focus on innovation and have developed an omni-channel offering that we believe has favorably
positioned us to respond to consumer trends. We have developed partnerships with innovators such as Amazon
and Ocado in order to provide best-in-class grocery delivery services in France. Our pure-play e-commerce
platform, Cdiscount, is the second largest e-tailer in France by number of unique monthly visitors (“UMV”), and
has allowed us to offer a range of adjacent business-to-consumer and business-to-business services. In France,
Brazil and Colombia, our brick-and-mortar retail banners benefit from mobile applications and other e-commerce
functionality that allow us to provide targeted promotions to our customers and give our customers the flexibility
to shop how they want, when they want.

In addition to our retail operations, we have also developed a number of other complementary lines of business
that allow us to leverage our know-how while monetizing our asset base. These businesses include real estate
development and shopping center management, consumer finance, solar energy and energy efficiency solutions
via GreenYellow and, in France specifically, digital advertising and data center solutions via 3W.relevanC and
ScaleMax, respectively.

We operate primarily in France and, through our interests in GPA and Grupo Éxito, in Latin America, although
through Cdiscount and a number of international affiliates, we provide products and services to customers in other
international markets.

For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, without giving effect to the impact of IFRS 16, we generated €36,659
million in net sales and €1,757 million in EBITDA and our France Retail segment recorded net sales of €18,796
million and EBITDA of €903 million. Our E-commerce segment recorded net sales of €1,979 million and
EBITDA of €28 million for the same period.

**Our Competitive Strengths**

**_Leading position in the French food retail market through structurally well-positioned formats and offers_**
**_aligned with new consumer trends_**

We believe that we are poised to take advantage of a number of favorable consumer trends in French food retail
as an already established market leader positioned in dynamic geographic areas and rapidly growing market
segments.

We hold leading positions in the French food retail market, the largest grocery retail market in Western Europe in
terms of retail sales value (“RSV”) (based on partial-year information at a fixed euro exchange rate retail value
measured by retail selling price, excluding sales tax), according to Euromonitor International. The RSV of the
French grocery retail market (in nominal terms and applying a constant 2018 exchange rate) has consistently
grown every year since 2014, and is projected to grow at a CAGR of 2.2% between 2018 and 2023. The graph
below shows RSV growth in the RSV of the French grocery retail market from 2014 to 2018, the RSV and its

-----

historical growth rate in the German, British, Italian and Spanish grocery retail markets, and their respective
projected growth rates between 2018 and 2023, according to Euromonitor.

(1) Euromonitor International

According to Euromonitor International, we are the fifth largest food retailer in France, with a market share of
approximately 9.4% in 2018 (based on partial-year information at a fixed euro exchange rate retail value measured
by retail selling price, excluding sales tax). As of June 30, 2019, we had a network of 8,640 stores in France within
a diversified portfolio of 12 complementary banners, each with different strategies to meet changing consumer
expectations. Our portfolio of banners is particularly focused on convenience and premium formats, which
accounted for over 60% of our net sales for the year ended December 31, 2018 and address growing demand from
French consumers. We are a leading urban convenience food retailer in France, with a network of 6,801 premium
and convenience stores that have a distinct urban focus. Approximately 63% of our France Retail net sales for the
year ended December 31, 2018 were generated in three of the fastest growing regions of France – the Ile-deFrance, Rhône-Alpes and Provence-Alpes-Côte d’Azur regions – whose population accounted for 35.7% of the
total French population and approximately 48% of France’s GDP growth in 2018. The map below shows our net
sales in each of these key regions as of December 31, 2018.

In addition, we are the major French food retailer with the smallest exposure to the declining hypermarket format
(which accounted for 25% of our France Retail net sales in 2018). Finally, according to a third-party market
analysis, we were also the second largest retailer of organic products, with approximately €1.0 billion in net sales
from organic products in 2018, which represented growth of 16% over the prior year.

We believe that the French food retail market is characterized by a number of demographic characteristics that
are favorable for food retailers like our Group. For example, according to the IMF, the French population has
grown at a CAGR of 0.3% from 64.0 million people in 2014 to 64.7 million people in 2018, and population growth
is expected to accelerate to a CAGR of 0.5%, reaching to 66.5 million people by 2024, which necessarily means
an increase in the consumer base for food. Moreover, according to the World Bank, approximately 80% of
France’s inhabitants in 2018 lived in urban areas, favoring retailers that have a particular concentration in towns
and cities. As of December 31, 2018, approximately 53% of our stores in France were located in urban areas and
approximately 1,400 stores (including franchise and affiliate stores) operated in the Paris region alone. In addition,
according to the INSEE, approximately 33% of the French population is older than 55 years old. This segment of
the population drives an estimated 86% of food retail growth and buys an estimated 57% of fresh products, the
offer of which is a key differentiating factor among food retailers and a key source of profitability. Growth in the
French food retail market is moderate, but marked by a strong polarization of format performance, with
convenience stores expected to enjoy growth in net sales of 1.6%, supermarket net sales growth expected to be
flat and hypermarket net sales expected to decline by 1.5% in 2019. In light of our strong focus on the convenience
and premium formats and our low exposure to the hypermarket format, we expect to benefit disproportionately
from the trends favoring supermarkets and convenience formats when compared with our main competitors.

The French food retail market is also marked by consumer trends that we believe will be beneficial for our Group.
For example, we believe that food retail e-commerce has the potential to grow significantly in France due to its
current low level of penetration despite the high overall population of internet users in France. According to
information from Hootsuite, approximately 88% of the French population used the internet in 2018, with 75%
using the internet on their mobile devices and 58% active on social media. While online sales of food products
are typically lower than those of non-food products, our e-commerce food sales in France, excluding Cdiscount,

3


-----

but including sales through our partnership with Amazon, amounted to €315 million in 2018. We believe this
provides us with a significant food retail e-commerce growth opportunity. Furthermore, consumers are
increasingly leaning toward high-quality, organic goods, leading to stronger emphasis on the premium end of the
market and a decline in the mass market segment. We believe this is favorable for retailers like us, with a diverse
range of banners and an already strong position in sales of organic products. We are the only large food retailer
in France with a large-scale banner dedicated to organic products, Naturalia.

We believe that these market trends have led to the emergence of new competitors, such as physical retailers Bio
c’Bon, Biocoop and La Vie Claire in the organic retail space, Grand Frais in the fresh produce space and Action
in the discount segment; online generalist retailers like Amazon and pure players such as Nespresso and Zooplus;
business-to-consumer technology platforms that are last-mile competitors such as Deliveroo, Uber Eats, Frichti
and Glovo. However, we also believe that our product offering and partnerships with online retailers and delivery
services will help us answer customers’ needs and successfully face such competition.

**_Best-in-class omni-channel strategy: pioneer of food e-commerce and one of the leading non-food e-tailers_**

We are present in three e-commerce retail segments in France: food retail, through the development of our omnichannel strategy, household goods, through Cdiscount, and fashion and other personal goods, through the recent
acquisition of Sarenza by Monoprix.

E-commerce activity is an important area of development for our business, especially in light of market trends
that indicate that consumers will make an increasing share of their purchases online. Our online sales for the six
months ended June 30, 2019 in France under our retail banners, together with Cdiscount’s gross merchandise
value, grew by 10.2% as compared to the same period in 2018. Food e-commerce gross sales, including
Cdiscount’s sale volume, grew by 27.5% in the first half of 2019 as compared to the first half of 2017. We
generated €187 million in net sales under our banners in food e-commerce during the six months ended June 30,
2019, and Cdiscount’s gross merchandise volume (“GMV”) was €1.75 billion over the same time period.

We were a first-mover in French food retail e-commerce through home delivery service partnerships that we
formed with Amazon and Ocado. Through our partnership with Amazon, Amazon Prime customers are offered
express two-hour delivery of Monoprix, Casino and Naturalia products in Paris and 35 neighboring cities. We
intend to expand the geographic area covered by this service to other major French cities by 2020. Through our
exclusive partnership with Ocado in France, we expect Monoprix to benefit by 2020 from a front-to-back online,
solution with the ability to provide customers with next-day delivery of 50,000 items with low preparation and
delivery costs, due in part to the construction of an automated warehouse in the Paris region.

We have further enhanced our brick and mortar French food retail operations with a number of digital initiatives.
For example, each of our principal French retail banners has a mobile application enabling customers to do their
shopping or monitor their loyalty card online. As of December 31, 2018, our banners’ applications have been
downloaded approximately 10 million times. Users of our Casino Max app generated approximately 13% of our
hypermarket and supermarket net sales for the six months ended June 30, 2019. Furthermore, we have
implemented a number of digital solutions to enhance our customers’ shopping experience, such as permitting
mobile payments, digital receipts, and scan and go solutions through the Monoprix and Casino Max mobile apps.
Our banners’ apps also allow individual marketing capabilities, with personalized, targeted coupons and discounts,
which we believe is a key distinguishing factor from most of our competitors.

Cdiscount, our pure-play e-commerce platform, is the second-largest e-tailer in France by number of unique
monthly visitors, with an average of 19.6 million monthly unique visitors to its website during the second quarter
of 2019, based on a market study by Médiamétrie. In 2018, the difference in market share based on retail sales
value excluding sales tax between Amazon, the e-tailer with the largest share of the non-food products ecommerce market in France, and Cdiscount, the e-tailer with the second-largest share of the non-food products ecommerce market non-food e-tailer in France, is the smallest when compared to the difference between Amazon
and other European non-food e-tailers’ market share in their home markets. Cdiscount sold €3.6 billion in GMV
of products and services during the year ended December 31, 2018, of which 34% was sold by third-party
merchants through Cdiscount’s marketplace platform. The GMV contribution from products and services sold
through the Cdiscount marketplace has increased over recent years, from 32% of total GMV in 2017 to 34% in
2018 and 40% during the six months ended June 30, 2019. Cdiscount’s online marketplace is the most profitable
portion of its operations because Cdiscount is able to generate net sales through the commissions it receives from
marketplace sellers with limited associated operating costs or working capital investments. We aim to continue to
expand the share of GMV represented by the Cdiscount marketplace in the coming years.

We believe Cdiscount benefits from a strong competitive advantage through its nine million active customers and
its successful Cdiscount à Volonté loyalty program, through which over two million members have the ability to
have free one-day delivery of more than 280,000 items, with on-demand delivery within 30-minute time slots in

4


-----

Paris, as well as unlimited online access to 200 magazines. The delivery offerings through Cdiscount à Volonté
are made possible by our superior logistics infrastructure, which is capable of handling both heavy and small
products.

We have been able to leverage the Cdiscount platform to offer adjacent business-to-customer services, such as
discount travel, event ticketing, discount energy (through a partnership with GreenYellow), Coup de Pouce
consumer finance loans through its partnership with Banque Casino and insurance. We have also been able to
offer business-to-business services, including fulfilment services to our marketplace vendors, which accounted
for approximately 21% of Cdiscount’s marketplace GMV in 2018, and additional services, such as advertising
and visibility-boosting services. We intend to further develop and expand such service offerings in the future.

Finally, we have been able to roll-out Cdiscount’s reach beyond France to 25 countries in Europe, and have
established partnerships with 45 online European marketplaces as of September 2019. We intend to further expand
Cdiscount’s international operations in the future, such as through initiatives like International Marketplace
Network, our recent alliance with three online marketplaces – in each of Germany, Italy and Romania – that allows
marketplace vendors in each geographic region to access the wider consumer market of all four websites.

Our e-commerce ambitions are not limited to our sales of food products and Cdiscount alone. For example, in
2018, Monoprix acquired Sarenza, a website dedicated to the sale of shoes, fashion and other personal goods.
Monoprix intends to integrate and develop Sarenza as a key online player in the personal goods retail sector in
France.

**_Asset-light model and further acceleration in new businesses_**

In recent years, we have focused on developing an asset-light business model in France through the active
management of our real estate portfolio and encouraging the development of a franchisee network in stores across
our various French banners. We also have developed new lines of business, including solar energy, data analysis
for digital advertising and data centers, that take advantage of our physical footprint and accumulated know-how
from running a major retail group.

We believe that there is limited upside potential from the valuation of commercial real estate in France, and have
undertaken significant disposals of our real estate portfolio, including through entering into sale and leaseback
transactions. As of December 31, 2018, the market value of our owned real estate portfolio in France was estimated
to be approximately €2.6 billion, including transfer duties and excluding our share of property held by Mercialys,
a property development business in which we hold 25% of the voting rights. During 2019, we have sold, or entered
into agreements to sell, real estate assets for a total sales price of €750 million (excluding transfer duties). We
believe these disposals have strengthened our balance sheet, as we anticipate limited or no upside on the valuation
of commercial real estate assets in France, while giving us the operational flexibility to compete in a dynamic
competitive environment.

As for the real estate that we have retained, we have endeavored to upgrade our properties, including our Casino
Supermarkets and Monoprix stores, to improve customers’ shopping experience and boost sales. We have further
reduced average selling area in our hypermarkets by 11% from 2015, through space optimization and
specialization on premises, such as transforming selling or stocking areas into additional retail areas in shopping
centers that are adjacent to our hypermarkets and can be leased to third parties. As a result, based on information
from LSA Conso, the average selling area of our hypermarkets was 6,950 square meters as of December 31, 2018,
compared with 9,184 square meters for Carrefour hypermarkets and 10,460 square meters for Auchan
hypermarkets. We expect that hypermarket sales will represent an increasingly smaller proportion of our France
total gross sales in the coming years.

We have also encouraged the development of our franchisee network as a means of transitioning to an asset-light
model with lower capital expenditures. Growth in our franchisee network has also had a positive impact on our
France Retail sales: we estimate that new franchisees (including the Quattrucci family, whose stores generated
over €300 million in gross sales in 2017, before such stores were part of our Group) joining our network of French
retail stores in 2018.

ScaleMax’s first data center was set up in a Cdiscount warehouse in the first half of 2019.

**_Proactive portfolio management to seize market opportunities and create value_**

We actively manage our businesses, seeking disposal and acquisition opportunities where we believe we can best
derive value for our companies. We also actively seek out and enter into partnerships with third parties in order
to better serve our customers and leverage market trends.

Our Group has historically been able to benefit from our acquisitions of banners with successful formats and name
recognition in markets characterized by favorable trends. Our Group was built through a series of key acquisitions
and combinations, including our acquisition of a stake in Monoprix in 1997, the entirety of which we purchased
in July 2013, the purchase of a majority interest in Franprix and Leader Price in 1997, our acquisition of a stake
in Grupo Éxito in 1999 (in which we acquired a further stake in 2007), our investment in CBD in 1999, our
acquisition of Naturalia in 2008 and, most recently, our purchase of Sarenza in 2018.

We also have a proven history of successfully monetizing our assets through the pursuit of opportunistic disposals.
For example, in 2016, we successfully completed a disposal plan of approximately €4.0 billion through the
disposals of our businesses in Thailand and Vietnam, with significant capital gains associated with these
transactions. In June 2018, following a review of our business portfolio, we announced the launch of an asset
disposal plan covering non-core assets, in particular real estate assets, for a value of €1.5 billion to be completed
by the end of 2019. This plan complemented our already planned disposal of Via Varejo, a Brazilian appliance
retailer, the sale of which was completed in June 2019. We successfully completed the entire plan ahead of
schedule in January 2019, primarily through the execution of sale and leaseback agreements with respect to certain
of our stores’ real estate and the sale of a 15% stake in Mercialys, a commercial real estate management business
in which we have kept a 25% minority stake. We therefore decided to increase the size of the plan to a targeted

6

€2.5 billion, the Asset Disposal Plan, with the additional €1.0 billion of disposals due to be completed by the first
quarter of 2020. Of this €2.5 billion amount, agreements in respect of disposals of approximately €2.1 billion have
been signed to date, of which €1.8 billion have been completed following the closing of the sale of certain real
estate assets to Apollo Global Management, Inc. on October 17, 2019 and €0.3 billion have been signed and are
to be completed. We subsequently completed a strategic review of our assets in France and announced on August
20, 2019 that we would carry out a second phase of our Asset Disposal Plan for a target amount of €2.0 billion (in
addition to the existing €2.5 billion plan described above) to be raised by the end of the first quarter of 2021 in
order to accelerate the completion of our strategic focus on the best performing formats and most promising
geographic markets. In addition to the Asset Disposal Plan, we have also begun implementing the Rocade Plan,
pursuant to which we have undertaken a thorough review of our loss-making stores and have been disposing
and/or closing such stores. As of July 24, 2019, we had signed agreements for the disposal of integrated stores for
an aggregate sales price of €233 million and intend to continue rightsizing our footprint. Moreover, on September
19, 2019, following speculative news coverage of our business strategy, we confirmed that we were in talks with
Aldi in connection with a possible transaction involving Leader Price as part of our Asset Disposal Plan described
above.

Finally, we have sought and intend to continue seeking out partnerships with third parties to expand the products
and services we provide to our customers in an efficient manner. Such partnerships include the partnership
between our Group and Amazon in France, which began in March 2018, pursuant to which Amazon Prime
customers can receive home delivery of Monoprix groceries in Paris, which has recently expanded to include
Casino and Naturalia products and which we intend to expand to locations elsewhere in France. We also have
entered into a partnership with Ocado, the world’s leading online grocery specialist, to develop a scalable, modular
end-to-end solution for an e-commerce grocery platform, including a fully automated warehouse in the Paris
region. This solution will enable us to rapidly deliver large grocery orders to online customers. Moreover, in June
2018, our Group, together with the Auchan Retail, Metro and Schiever groups, announced the signature of several
agreements establishing the Horizon purchasing alliance, which aims to focus on moving away from purely
transactional negotiations toward a collaborative, balanced and innovative type of negotiations with suppliers.
After securing approval from competition authorities, Horizon has been operational since February 2019.

**_High-growth operations in attractive Latin American markets_**

Through our interests in GPA and Grupo Éxito, we have a highly developed network of retail banners in a number
of attractive formats in Brazil, Colombia, Argentina and Uruguay.

The Latin American business benefits from attractive and fast-growing markets with strong underlying
macroeconomic trends, including a growing population of over 300 million, which is favorable for food retailers.
As an established player in these markets, we believe we stand to benefit from the favorable demographics of
these countries, combined with their improving economies.

Despite a high rate of urbanization, the penetration rate of modern grocery stores in these markets remains
relatively low. As a result of this, as well as the rapid development in these countries of digitalization and
urbanization rates, we expect rapid structural changes in the region. In this context, we believe that retail groups
like ours with extensive digital know-how and omni-channel capabilities are especially well-positioned to benefit
from growth in Latin America, where digital media has had an extensive impact.

In Brazil, GPA was the largest player in grocery retail and one of the largest players in the cash & carry market
in 2018, with net sales of €11,416 million for the year ended December 31, 2018 and €5,914 million for the six
months ended June 30, 2019, as compared with net sales of €5,561 million for the six months ended June 30,
2018. As of June 30, 2019, GPA had a network of 1,059 stores throughout the country. GPA is active across
various formats, channels and regions of Brazil.

**_Extensive record of financial achievements in France_**

We have a history of successfully executing plans to improve our France Retail financial performance and
financial position. Our France Retail trading profit, excluding property development activities, has increased at a
CAGR of approximately 22% from 2014 through 2018, and its trading profit margin, calculated as a percentage
of net sales, has increased by 0.4 percentage points per year over the same time period. Our France Retail same
store net sales have also generally evolved favorably since 2014.

We have been able to reduce our combined France Retail and E-commerce net debt over the past years, from €7.1
billion as of December 31, 2014 to €2.9 billion as of December 31, 2018. We believe that a significant part of this
success is due to our ability to carry out targeted asset disposals through our various disposal plans as described
above. We believe that our successful track record in executing these opportunistic disposals has not only
generated significant value through the monetization of our asset base, but has also enabled us to focus our
business model in France on a core set of activities adapted to the needs of today’s consumers.

We intend to carry out a number of initiatives to improve our France Retail free cash flow generation to support
further reductions in our net debt. For further detail on our financial strategy, see “—Our Strategies—Continue
_transformation into a less capital-intensive business model with a strong focus on improving profitability and_
_cash flow generation and proactive deleveraging in France”._

**_Highly experienced management team to drive sustainable profitable growth_**

We benefit from the expertise of a senior management team that has significant experience in grocery retail and
corporate finance. Jean-Charles Naouri, the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of CGP since 2005, acquired
our indirect majority shareholder Rallye, itself a former chain of supermarkets, in 1991, and implemented its
merger with Casino in 1992. Mr. Naouri holds degrees from the École Normale Supérieure and the École
Nationale d’Administration and has a doctorate from Harvard University. We also benefit from the services of
our talented team of divisional managers, who more closely oversee the day-to-day operations of our retail banners
and our purchasing functions. Each draws upon significant experience in the retail sector and most of them have
been with our Group for many years.

**Our Strategy**

**_Accelerate leadership in convenience, organic and premium formats in France_**

We intend to capitalize on French consumer trends by further focusing on and developing our well positioned
formats and product range. We aim to adjust our mix of formats to best position our business for long-term growth.
We also aim to continue to expand our premium and convenience stores, formats which we believe will continue
to be particularly promising over the medium term, with the goal of opening 300 new stores by 2021. In particular,
to take advantage of consumers’ increased preference for organic products, we intend to develop our organic
product offering in each of our banners and speed up the expansion of our Naturalia stores. Through this and the
promotion of organic products through our digital distribution channels, including our partnership with Amazon
Prime, we believe that our net sales of organic products will continue to increase over the next few years.
Moreover, we plan to further reduce our exposure to the hypermarket format from its 21% share of France total
gross sales under banner in 2018, by focusing on our most profitable locations. With respect to the remainder of
the hypermarket portfolio, we expect to focus on initiatives to maximize real estate efficiency and area utilization.

We also plan to enhance our existing store network in France to meet changes in consumers’ tastes and needs. We
intend to continue developing new concepts and services in our stores, such as the Franprix Noé concept, which

9


-----

consists of lifestyle stores focusing on organic, healthy and fair-trade products, Le Drugstore Parisien, a
partnership with L’Oréal Paris, and Le 4 Casino, a phygital store with several digital innovations. Most recently,
we have launched a pilot store in Paris for our newest concept, Darwin, a Franprix store offering consumers a host
of conveniences, including full kitchen access, a large seating and dining area and the ability to shop for products
from other brands, such as Cdiscount and home goods retailer Hema, in store. We also intend to provide catering
services across our various banners, such as in-store salad bars and snack areas. Finally, we intend to expand our
network of autonomous Monoprix, Franprix and Casino supermarkets in order to improve customer service and
increase net sales from expanded opening hours.

**_Continue to strengthen our leadership in digital and omni-channel initiatives in France and pursue_**
**_innovations in all parts of our business_**

Innovation and digital transformations are two major axes of our development strategy. We intend to leverage
favorable consumer trends and our strong experience in digital and omni-channel offerings by increasing our focus
on efforts to expand our e-commerce activities in food retail, further developing our Cdiscount business, growing
our digital customer relationships and rolling out further innovative concepts and solutions.

Leveraging on the full deployment of our partnership with Ocado to develop a fully automated warehouse and
with the expansion of the delivery area through which Amazon Prime customers can order Monoprix, Casino and
Naturalia products, we aim to generate significant food e-commerce sales in the near- to medium-term.

In our pure-play e-commerce business, we intend to increase Cdiscount’s GMV through the further development
of our marketplace, which we expect will account for an increasing share of Cdiscount’s net sales in the coming
years. We also intend to further expand Cdiscount’s business-to-business and business-to-customer services
offering within France, and to more generally expand Cdiscount’s operations to other European countries through
direct delivery to countries neighboring France and the further development of partnerships with marketplaces
abroad.

Finally, we aim to reinforce our digital customer relationships through the increased penetration of our banners’
mobile applications. We also plan to expand Scan & Go capabilities to all of our stores by 2021.

In October 2018, we launched Le 4 Casino, the first store in France without a traditional cashier, the technology
of which was deployed over 146 stores (with 188 stores targeted by the end of 2019), allowing for 24/7 store
operation without the presence of cashiers. In March 2019, we opened a logistics innovation lab in the Géant
hypermarket in Pessac, France, where 15 technology solutions are currently being tested in partnership with the
most innovative startups in the field.

These innovative solutions were made possible with the launch of Maxit, a “digital factory” covering our various
banners, employing 40 experts in the digital field and focusing on technology innovation, such as through the
development of the Casino Max, Leader Price and Vindémia mobile applications. Since their launch, these
applications have generated traffic of more than 5 million views per month. Maxit regularly liaises with startups
to develop projects to improve the customer experience.

In addition, Cdiscount runs dozens of tests with startups each year to develop innovative solutions. For instance,
in July, Cdiscount signed a partnership with FACIL’iti to adapt its website for people with disabilities.

Our innovation initiatives also include new activities with strong growth potential, such as the deployment of
electrical vehicle charging stations in our parking lots or ScaleMax, a cloud computing solution developed in our
warehouses and store stocking areas. Each of these projects, in line with our asset-light strategy, have been
developed in exclusive or limited partnerships with the most advanced startups, franchisees with long-standing
relationships with us or with other external specialist teams.

**_Increase pace of development of new activities in France_**

We believe that our new energy and data businesses in France will provide us with significant opportunities to
grow our revenue and further monetize our asset base.

In our solar energy business, we aim to further bolster our leadership position while developing newer activities.
We aim to consolidate GreenYellow’s leadership position in solar energy with a target to increase its installed
capacity, which has already grown significantly, with an installed base of 190 MWp as of December 31, 2018 and
a pipeline representing 350 MWp of future projects as of June 30, 2019. We also aim to consolidate our leadership
position in solar self-consumption in France by continuing to leverage our joint venture partnership with Engie,
pursuant to which we help local authorities and companies in France to generate solar power to meet their
electricity needs. Further, we plan to continue growing our energy performance contract offering, which is a
contract with GreenYellow through which GreenYellow commits to achieve reductions in energy costs and total

10


-----

energy consumed, with external customers. As of December 31, 2018, we had already entered into approximately
€66 million of such contracts. Finally, we intend to further develop our business-to-customer services and expand
our offering through electricity sales to individual customers via Cdiscount Energie and the development of a new
natural gas offering that we intend to launch by the end of 2019.

We also plan to continue growing our data and data centers businesses in order to increase the potential
contribution from such businesses, which generated €41 million in revenue for the year ended December 31, 2018.
We expect to target such growth through accelerating the development of 3W.relevanC’s core activities, as well
as expanding its retail search marketing operations, which develop advertising campaigns linked to internet users’
searches. We also intend to license our Casino Max app and its targeted coupon platform to business-to-business
customers. Finally, through our ScaleMax business, we intend to generalize the use of data centers in our logistics
warehouses and hypermarket stocking areas.

**_Encourage fast growth in Latin America_**

We intend to grow the businesses of GPA and Grupo Éxito through the execution of a range of initiatives at GPA
in Brazil and Grupo Éxito in Colombia that we believe will lead to increased net sales.

In Brazil, GPA’s strategy is centered on four key pillars:

  - Portfolio optimization: GPA intends to continue expanding Assaí cash & carry stores and associated net
sales, with a target of 20 new stores to be opened by year-end. GPA also intends to revitalize and revamp
its other Brazilian banners, through converting certain Extra supermarket stores into Compre Bem and
Mercado Extra stores, renovating its Pão de Açúcar stores and improving the attractiveness of its
commercial retail spaces.

  - Review of our product range: GPA aims to increase the proportion of private-label products in its sales
mix through repositioning its Qualitá private label brand. In 2018, GPA introduced 500 new products,
worked closely with its suppliers to ensure higher production levels to improve profitability and launched
a new marketing model and promotional campaigns.

  - Digital transformation: GPA intends to increase revenue by continuing to pursue its digital and ecommerce initiatives, including through the deployment of delivery platform James Delivery in São
Paulo and 10 other cities by the end of 2019, expansion of GPA’s Cheftime application delivering meal
kits to the São Paulo region of Brazil and extending GPA’s click and collect and home delivery services
to a greater number of stores.

  - Operation / efficiency: GPA has developed a number of initiatives to optimize its gross margin, including
increasing the proportion of higher-margin product offerings, investing in tools to optimize pricing in
each of its store formats and regions and customizing promotions for a better return on investment.

We intend to continue Grupo Éxito’s transformation strategy through carrying out a number of different initiatives.

  - Focus on fast-growing formats: Grupo Éxito plans to expand the recently introduced cash & carry format
in Colombia through the additional openings and conversion of existing stores into stores under the
Surtimayorista banner. Grupo Éxito also intends to continue launching new concepts in Colombia, such
as the Éxito WOW concept in its hypermarkets, which offers a complete revamp of its food and nonfood product selection, and the FreshMarket concept in its Carulla premium supermarkets, with an
improved selection of fresh and healthy products.

  - Digital transformation: Grupo Éxito believes that local market conditions are favorable for the
development of omni-channel marketing solutions, including increased e-commerce, retail mobile
applications and last-mile delivery services. Consequently, Grupo Éxito intends to accelerate the
development of its digital and omni-channel activities in Colombia through efforts to increase the number
of users of the Éxito and Carulla mobile applications and expanding the Puntos Colombia loyalty
program application that Grupo Éxito has developed in partnership with Bancolombia with rewards that
can be used by customers at several companies.

  - Property development: Grupo Éxito plans to continue expanding its Viva Malls property development
business in Colombia, which has become the leading player in the Colombian commercial property
market.

**_Unlock additional value through simplifying our Group’s structure in Latin America_**

order to simplify our organization with the objective of improving the valuation of the publicly listed Latin

**_Continue transformation into a less capital-intensive business model with a strong focus on improving_**
**_profitability and cash flow generation and proactive deleveraging in France_**

We have launched a number of initiatives to achieve improvements in several financial metrics in France,
including our costs of operations, trading profit, capital expenditures, net debt and working capital requirements.

We intend to optimize head office expenses at the corporate level and at the level of each of our banners and
reduce store costs, continue to negotiate better purchasing conditions for goods, realize logistics synergies through
unifying the logistics serving our Casino, Franprix and Leader Price banners and close or dispose of loss-making
stores through our Rocade Plan in order to save costs. During the first half of 2019, we have already made
significant progress toward our cost savings goals. We have already achieved significant run-rate savings,
including approximately €60 million in cost savings through head office and store costs reductions of
approximately €29 million, purchasing savings of approximately €16 million and logistics synergies of
approximately €15 million, each on a full-year basis. In addition, through our progress on the Rocade Plan, we
disposed of 15 hypermarkets, 13 supermarkets and 11 Leader Price stores and closed a further 56 stores across
our various French banners, leading to a positive impact on trading profit that we estimate would be approximately
€52 million on a full-year basis. We have also disposed of eight franchised supermarkets and nine franchised
Leader Price stores and have closed 62 franchised stores, leading to an estimated positive impact of approximately
€27 million in trading profit for the franchisees on a full-year basis, with an expected €13 million of normalized
net income for our Group. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to our Business and Industry—We may not be able
_to implement our business strategy”._

12


-----

We also seek to improve our France Retail trading profit through improvements in format mix and an emphasis
on organic and fresh food products, through developing retail-adjacent sources of revenue from our new
businesses GreenYellow, 3W.relevanC and Scale Max, and through the continued disposal of loss-making stores.

We are continuing to focus our retail gross capital expenditures on initiatives that we believe will have a favorable
impact on the development of our business, with a targeted level of approximately €350 million per year from
2019 through 2021. We believe this will include investments in the further digitalization of our retail activities,
such as the recent launch of the Leader Price mobile application, the development of e-commerce initiatives such
as our partnerships with Ocado and Amazon. We believe this level of capital expenditure is adequate after years
of significant investment in revamping our banners and implementing new concepts, such as the Mandarine
concept in Franprix stores, intended to transform them into friendly, practical and pleasant stores. In addition, the
development of franchises has reduced our capital expenditure requirements, as franchisees finance the capital
expenditures for the stores that they operate.

We aim to reduce our year-end net debt through continuing our favorable track record of deleveraging in France.
We intend to achieve this goal through improving our free cash flow generation, continuing the Rocade Plan,
pursuing our €4.5 billion Asset Disposal Plan and the absence of dividend payments until the end of 2020. We
believe we have made significant progress on these initiatives already, having already signed approximately €2.1
billion of asset disposals out of the announced €4.5 billion, of which transactions approximately €1.8 billion have
closed. As of July 24, 2019, we had also signed agreements for the disposal of integrated stores for an aggregate
sales price of €233 million.

Finally, we aim to improve our working capital requirements, primarily through reducing inventories. We aim to
reduce inventories through a number of different initiatives, including ceasing to offer products which are cashconsuming, extending logistics pooling between our banners, which previously had been limited to frozen goods,
to a wider range of products and closer tracking through advanced digital inventories solutions. We have already
demonstrated improvement in this respect, having generated a cash inflow from changes in inventories during the
twelve months ended June 30, 2019 of €105 million, which is an improvement on our performance in the twelve
months ended June 30, 2018.

In the context of such performance and strategic positioning initiatives, we have set ourselves a target of reducing
our France Retail net debt to €1.5 billion on a sustainable basis.

**The Issuer**

Quatrim S.A.S. (the “Issuer”) is organized as a société par actions simplifiée under the laws of France. It is
registered in France under sole identification number 833 032 121 R.C.S. Saint-Étienne. Its registered office is
located at 1, cours Antoine Guichard, 42000 Saint-Étienne, France.

The Issuer is indirectly wholly owned by CGP through its subsidiary CPF. The Issuer is a holding company whose
principal asset is its 100% stake in the share capital of IGC and, on the Issue Date, intragroup receivables owed
to it under the Proceeds Loans and, if applicable, the Escrow Account. IGC is a French company whose primary
activity is the direct or indirect holding (through a number of subsidiaries) of real estate or leases to real estate
used in the Group’s France Retail operations, as described below.

As of the Issue Date, the Issuer will not be, and after giving effect to the Permitted Specific Perimeter
Reorganization (as defined in “Description of the Notes—Certain Definitions”), we do not expect that the Issuer
will be considered to be a “principal subsidiary” for purposes of the negative pledge provisions included in the
Existing EMTN Bonds. For a further description of such negative pledge provisions, see “Description of Certain
_Financing Arrangements—Existing EMTN Bonds—Common Provisions”._

The Notes will be secured on a first-ranking basis by pledges over (i) the securities account to which the
outstanding shares of IGC held by the Issuer are credited and which, as of the Issue Date, will contain all of the
outstanding shares of IGC, (ii) all intragroup receivables owed to the Issuer under the Proceeds Loans, (iii) the
bank accounts of the Issuer and (iv) the Bond Segregated Accounts. Although no appraisals of any collateral have
been prepared in connection with the offering of the Notes, the Note Collateral represents less than 10% of our
consolidated revenue and consolidated assets. The value of the Note Collateral resides mainly in the value of the
shares of IGC, which will be significantly impacted by the value of the real estate assets which are directly and

13


-----

indirectly owned by IGC. As a consequence, although not part of the Note Collateral, the value of the real estate
assets directly and indirectly owned by IGC will have a significant impact on the value of the Note Collateral.
There can be no assurance that the Note Collateral will be sufficient to secure the obligations under the Notes.
The value of the real estate assets directly and indirectly controlled by IGC is subject to change and may be
impacted by many factors beyond our control, including general macroeconomic conditions, evolution of the real
estate market in a specific area of France and the assessment of French courts in the case of insolvency or
bankruptcy proceedings in France; if certain insolvency or bankruptcy proceedings are opened in respect of IGC
and/or its subsidiaries, it is possible that subsidiaries and/or their real estate or other assets could be disposed of
for significantly less than their in bonis market value. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Indebtedness, the

**IGC**

IGC is a French company whose primary activity is the direct or indirect holding (through a number of
subsidiaries) of real estate or leases to real estate used in the Group’s France Retail operations.

A number of entities that are currently joint ventures with IGC and direct or indirect subsidiaries owned by IGC,
as well as certain real estate assets held by IGC and its subsidiaries may be sold or transferred to other entities of
the Group (the “IGC Reorganization”). These assets and entities include:

Apollo Global Management, Inc. and Fortress Investment Group LLC in connection with sale and
leaseback transactions;

  - real estate assets or legal entities that own real estate assets in respect of which we have signed sale
agreements with third parties or for the sale of which we are in advanced discussions with third parties;

  - the legal entities that own our stake in Mercialys;

  - certain legal entities that do not own, directly and indirectly, any real estate assets or shares in real estate
investment vehicles;

  - GreenYellow; and

  - cash and receivables held by IGC and its subsidiaries on the Issue Date.

Certain of these sales or transfers may only occur after the Issue Date.
