**_Leases_**

In connection with the Refinancing, IGC, DCF and other Group subsidiaries within France will, on or prior to the
Issue Date, enter into a master lease agreement (the “New Master Lease Agreement”), pursuant to which all the
existing leases within the IGC perimeter with Group entities within France as lessees will be renewed and the
principal terms of such leases will be agreed. The template for such leases will be appended to the New Master
Lease Agreement.

The New Master Lease Agreement will provide that all the new leases will take effect retroactively on October 1,
2019 for a period of twelve years (of which there is a firm minimum term of nine years), and a maximum period,
if renewed, of 39 years.

The rents for each of the renewed leases will be fixed, subject to an annual revision in line with a standard annual
indexation clause linked to the change in the _Indice National des Loyers Commerciaux (the National Index of_
Commercial Leases, a reference measure that is published on a quarterly basis by the French National Institute of
Statistics and Economic Studies (INSEE)) and paid on a monthly basis. The initial rents have been agreed for each
real estate asset.

At any renewal date, if the rights to the lease (droit au bail) have been transferred outside the Group, the new rent
will be, unless otherwise agreed between the parties, adjusted to reflect the rental market value of the asset at that
time.

Under the New Master Lease Agreement, the sale of the rights to the lease will be permitted to any other member
of the Group. The sale of the rights to the lease to a company outside the Group will only be permitted if such sale
includes the corresponding going concern (fonds de commerce) and will be subject to the prior written approval
of IGC, which may only be withheld if the transferee is not sufficiently solvent. In case of assignment, the assignor
shall remain jointly liable with the assignee for three years. The landlord shall inform the assignor of any default
of payment of the lessee within one month as from the date on which the due amount was required to be paid by
the lessee. The Indenture will provide that the New Master Lease Agreement may not be amended, waived or
allowed to enter into default in any manner that would adversely affect the holders of the Notes or the relevant

16


-----

lessor in any material respect. See “Description of the Notes—Limitation on Amendments of the New Master Lease
_Agreement”._

Subleases are allowed to any other member of the Group and, with some restrictions, to third-parties.

As long as DCF and other subsidiaries party to the leases are members of the Group, IGC has undertaken:

  - not to create or rent additional selling areas to another hypermarket or supermarket in the catchment area
of each store; and

  - not to sell to, transfer in any way to or enter into long-term leases (bail emphythéotique) with a competitor
of the Group (including food-retailers and real-estate companies affiliated with a food-retailer).

The New Master Lease Agreement provides that in the event of (a) an enforcement of the pledge over the shares
of IGC that form part of the Note Collateral and (b) the exercise of the termination clause, the undertakings
mentioned above shall be disapplied.

In addition, if IGC wishes to sell all or part of the leased areas, DCF and the other relevant members of the Group
will benefit, as long as it is a member of the Group, from a right of first offer and a pre-emption right.

DCF and IGC will enter into the individual new lease agreements with respect to each real estate asset before
March 31, 2020.

IGC is also party to rental agreements with third parties in respect of retail space in the shopping malls it owns.
These rental agreements reflect market practice in France. They are primarily ten-year lease agreements, whereby
the lessee has the right to terminate the lease after three or six years. Most rents are composed of a fixed
component, with an additional variable component. The leases also have indexation clauses linked to the change
in the Indice National des Loyers Commerciaux. Rental payments due thereunder are primarily paid on a quarterly
basis.

**The Refinancing**

In connection with the Offering, we intend to enter into the New Term Loan B Facility Agreement to be dated on
or prior to the Escrow Release Date in the event that the Offering is consummated prior to the date of execution
of the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement in an aggregate principal amount of at least €1.8 billion (and
otherwise on or prior to the Issue Date), among, _inter alios, CGP, as borrower, BNP Paribas, Crédit Agricole_
Corporate and Investment Bank, Credit Suisse International, Goldman Sachs International, HSBC Bank plc, J.P.
Morgan Securities plc and Natixis, as mandated lead arrangers, Credit Suisse International, as agent, and Citibank,
N.A., London Branch, as security agent. The New Term Loan B Facility Agreement will provide for the borrowing
by CGP of an aggregate principal amount of €1.0 billion under the New Term Loan B Facility that will mature in
January 2024. Interest on the New Term Loan B Facility will be payable quarterly in arrears at a rate of EURIBOR
(subject to 0% floor) plus a margin. CGP’s obligations under the New Term Loan B Facility will be guaranteed
on a senior secured basis by DCF, Casino Finance and Monoprix S.A.S. and, following the Latam Reorganization
Transactions, by Segisor. The New Term Loan B Facility will be secured by pledges on certain assets of CGP,
DCF, Casino Finance and Monoprix S.A.S. and, following the Latam Reorganization Transactions, of Segisor
(the “Credit Facilities Collateral”). Noteholders will not benefit from the Credit Facilities Collateral. For a
further description of the New Term Loan B Facility Agreement, see “Description of Certain Financing
_Arrangements—New Term Loan B Facility Agreement”._

Furthermore, in connection with the Offering and the entry into the New Term Loan B Facility Agreement, we
also intend to enter into the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, to be dated on or prior to the Escrow
Release Date in the event that the Offering is consummated prior to the date of execution of the New Revolving
Credit Facility Agreement in an aggregate principal amount of at least €1.8 billion (and otherwise on or prior to
the Issue Date), among, inter alios, CGP, as borrower, BNP Paribas, Credit Suisse International and J.P. Morgan
Securities plc as Mandated Lead Arrangers and Bookrunners, Crédit Agricole Corporate and Investment Bank, as
agent, and Citibank, N.A., London Branch, as security agent. The New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement will
provide for the borrowing by CGP, Casino Finance and Monoprix S.A.S. of an initial aggregate amount of up to
€2.0 billion under the New Revolving Credit Facility. Borrowings under the New Revolving Credit Facility will
be guaranteed on a senior secured basis by CGP, DCF, Casino Finance and Monoprix S.A.S. and, following the
Latam Reorganization Transactions, Segisor. The New Revolving Credit Facility will be secured by the Credit
Facilities Collateral. For a further description of the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, see “Description
_of Certain Financing Arrangements—New Revolving Credit Facility”._

We intend to use the gross proceeds from the Offering, along with the proceeds raised in connection with the
incurrence of the New Term Loan B Facility for a principal amount of €1.0 billion and cash from our balance

17


-----

sheet, to (i) repay amounts drawn under our Existing Syndicated Credit Facilities, (ii) repay and cancel our
Existing Bilateral Facilities, (iii) repay, through a tender offer launched on November 5, 2019, a portion of our
Existing EMTN Bonds at the CGP level, directly or indirectly through the refinancing of certain intercompany
loans (and deposit those amounts pending closing of the tender offer in a Segregated Account), (iv) leave cash on
balance in a Segregated Account to repay, on or about the Segisor Guarantee Date, along with cash proceeds to
the France Retail and E-commerce segments resulting from the Latam Reorganization Transactions,
approximately €195 million of the Segisor Credit Facility on or about the Segisor Guarantee Date and (v) pay the
fees and expenses related to the Refinancing.

If the Offering is consummated prior to the execution of the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement in an
aggregate amount of at least €1.8 billion, the Initial Purchasers will, concurrently with the issuance of the Notes
on the Issue Date, deposit the gross proceeds of the Offering into the Escrow Account in the name of the Issuer.
The Escrow Account will be controlled by the Escrow Agent and pledged in favor of the Trustee, for the benefit
of itself and for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. The release of the escrowed proceeds will be subject to the
satisfaction of certain conditions, including the execution of the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement
providing for the New Revolving Credit Facility in an aggregate amount of at least €1.8 billion. If the execution
of the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement providing for the New Revolving Credit Facility in an aggregate
amount of at least €1.8 billion does not occur on or prior to the Escrow Longstop Date, or upon the occurrence of
certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a Special Mandatory Redemption at a price equal to 100% of the
aggregate issue price of the Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the Special
Mandatory Redemption Date. See “Description of the Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory
_Redemption”. If the Offering closes concurrently with or after the execution of the New Revolving Credit Facility_
Agreement in an aggregate amount of at least €1.8 billion, the foregoing escrow procedures will not apply, and
the Initial Purchasers will transfer the net proceeds of the Offering in accordance with the instructions provided
by the Issuer on the Issue Date.

The requisite majority of lenders under our Existing Syndicated Credit Facilities have consented to the
Refinancing. Certain consenting lenders will have their commitments cancelled and will simultaneously become
lenders under our New Revolving Credit Facility. Certain consenting lenders who have not chosen to become
lenders under the New Revolving Credit Facility and the lenders under the Existing Syndicated Credit Facilities
who have not consented to the Refinancing will stay committed under the Existing Syndicated Credit Facilities
until their respective maturities.

The Offering and the entry into the New Term Loan B Facility Agreement and the New Revolving Credit Facility
Agreement and the use of the proceeds therefrom are collectively referred to herein as the “Refinancing”.

**The Latam Reorganization Transactions**

The Group previously announced its plan to simplify its Latin American holding structure through a number of
interrelated transactions (the “Latam Reorganization Transactions”). The Latam Reorganization Transactions
involve the following main steps.

**_Tender offer for the outstanding shares of Almacenes Éxito. On October 19, 2019, CBD announced that Sendas_**
Distribuidora S.A. (“Sendas”), a wholly owned subsidiary of CBD, published in Colombia the first notice of an
all-cash tender offer to acquire up to 100% of the outstanding shares of Almacenes Éxito at the price of COP
18,000 per share (pursuant to which CGP’s wholly owned subsidiary Tevir S.A.S. (“Tevir”) will tender its entire
55.3% stake, which it currently holds indirectly through various subsidiaries, in exchange for approximately
€1,194 million (based on the intraday average mid-market EUR/COP exchange rate on October 28, 2019).
Shareholders of Almacenes Éxito will have between October 28, 2019 and November 19, 2019 to accept the
tender offer. The settlement of the tender offer will occur three business days after the results of the tender offer
are communicated by the Colombian Securities Exchange to the Financial Superintendence of Colombia.

Assuming Sendas acquires 100% of Almacenes Éxito’s shares, the amount that Sendas will pay to acquire the
shares will be €2,159 million (based on the intraday average mid-market EUR/COP exchange rate on October 28,
2019). The acquisition will be financed through cash on hand at GPA and with the proceeds from the issuance by
Sendas of BRL 8.0 billion (or €1,803 million based on the intraday average mid-market EUR/BRL exchange rate
on October 28, 2019) in aggregate principal amount of unsecured debentures guaranteed by CBD, with maturity
dates ranging from one to four years from the date of issuance, which Sendas announced on August 9, 2019.

**_Acquisition by CGP of shares of Segisor held by Grupo Éxito. On August 19, 2019, CGP entered into a share_**
purchase agreement with Onper Investments 2015 S.L., a wholly owned subsidiary of Almacenes Éxito
(“Onper”), pursuant to which CGP agreed to purchase, and Onper agreed to sell, 50% of the outstanding shares
in Segisor, a French holding company of CBD, at a price of BRL 113 per share (or approximately €1,271 million
in total, based on the intraday average mid-market EUR/BRL exchange rate on October 28, 2019), approximately

18


-----

€1,074 million of which will be paid in cash, with the remainder of the purchase price paid through the assumption
by CGP of Segisor’s liabilities under the Segisor Credit Facility. After giving effect to this acquisition, CGP will
be the sole owner of Segisor. Segisor currently owns 37.3% of CBD’s share capital or 99.6 million shares. Onper
will benefit from a partial purchase price matching clause equal to 80% of the price difference on the 49.8 million
CBD shares that CGP is acquiring from Almacenes Éxito in the event of a disposal of all or part of such shares
above a price of BRL 113 per share within 15 months from the sale date.

**_Conversion of CBD preferred shares and migration to the Novo Mercado._** We further intend to convert the
preferred shares of CBD (which are currently listed) into ordinary shares at an exchange ratio of 1:1 in the context
of the migration of all the outstanding shares of CBD to the Novo Mercado segment of the B3 - Brasil Bolsa
Balcão S.A. (formerly BM&F Bovespa) stock exchange, which is for the trading of shares issued by companies
that commit themselves voluntarily to adopt strict corporate governance standards. The conversion and migration
are expected to occur in early 2020.

**_Partial repayment of the Segisor Credit Facility. On or about the Segisor Guarantee Date, we further intend to_**
repay approximately €195 million outstanding under the Segisor Credit Facility, under which €399 million was
outstanding as of June 30, 2019.

Upon completion of the Latam Reorganization Transactions, CGP will indirectly hold approximately 41.4% of
CBD. We expect to be able to continue fully consolidating GPA and Grupo Éxito into our consolidated financial
statements following completion of the Latam Reorganization Transactions. However, neither GPA, Grupo Éxito
nor their respective subsidiaries will be considered our subsidiaries for purposes of the covenants in the Indenture.
Consequently, the covenants will not restrict any actions at those entities following completion of the Latam
Reorganization Transactions.

For a summary presentation of our corporate structure following the Latam Reorganization Transactions, see
“Summary Corporate and Financing Structure”.

Cdiscount generated GMV of €940 million during the three months ended September 30, 2019, an organic
increase of 9.0% from GMV for the comparable period in 2018, driven by ongoing marketplace expansion,
monetization revenues related to B2B services and Cdiscount “shops-in-shops” in Casino stores.

The share of Cdiscount GMV generated by sales in its marketplace continued to grow to represent 39.4% of GMV
for the three months ended September 30, 2019, a 3.2 percentage point increase from the comparable period in
2018.

Monetization revenues, including commissions related to B2C services, financial services, B2B marketplace
services and revenues in relation to 3W.relevanC were 34% higher for the three months ended September 30,
2019 than the comparable period in 2018. This increase was primarily driven by B2C services, especially
Cdiscount Voyages, Cdiscount Energie and financial services.

Latam Retail

Net sales generated by our Latam Retail segment for the three months ended September 30, 2019 were 3.0%
higher on a same-store basis and 9.6% higher on an organic basis than those it generated during the comparable
period in 2018. Latam Retail net sales benefited from a favorable currency effect of 2.1%.

As reported by GPA, GPA generated sales growth of 10.3% on an organic basis, despite a decrease in food price
inflation of 2.4 percentage points compared to the first half of 2019.

  - Assaí continued to deliver very strong organic growth of 18.4% compared to the comparable period of
2018, due to the opening of 19 stores during the last twelve months. Same-store growth came to 3.0%,
reflecting a difficult comparative base, following five years of average same store growth above 10%.

  - Multivarejo sales were impacted by the challenging economic environment in Brazil, a high basis of
comparison in 2018 (6.0% growth in gross sales on a same-store basis) and declining inflation.

_Additional Current Trading Information_

During the three months ended September 30, 2019, the Group pursued the implementation of its announced
action plans, in particular related to cost savings, rationalization of the network and development of new
businesses in France, which collectively continued to have a positive impact on its profitability.

The evolution of our net debt for our France Retail and E-commerce segments as of September 30, 2019, as
compared to June 30, 2019, was consistent with the historical seasonality of our business in France in the last
three years (see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key
_Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Seasonality and comparability of results”). We continued to implement_
our initiatives to improve our cash flow generation and accelerate our deleveraging through, in particular, further
reduction of our inventory levels in France as well as our asset sale program (such as through the signing of the
Vindémia disposal in July 2019).

**_Asset Disposals_**

In July 2019, we announced the completion of the sale of three hypermarkets, four Casino supermarkets and one
Leader Price store for €39 million. We also signed new agreements relating to the disposal of three hypermarkets
for total transaction proceeds of €42 million that represented net sales of approximately €76 million and a trading
loss of around €2 million in the year ended December 31, 2018, and are expected to be completed at the end of
2019, after the prior consultation of employee representatives and fulfilment of the customary conditions
precedent.

On September 19, 2019, we confirmed we received an expression of interest from Aldi France in the acquisition
of Leader Price in metropolitan France. Following this expression of interest, we have entered into discussions
with Aldi France with a view to have Aldi France submit a binding offer.

On October 16, 2019, we closed our previously announced transaction with funds managed by companies
affiliated with Apollo Global Management for the sale and leaseback of 31 store properties (12 Géant Casino and
19 Monoprix and Casino Supermarkets stores) worth €465 million (net of taxes payable). The sale price for this
transaction was €341 million (of which €327 million has been received and another €14 million is expected to be
received within twelve months following the transfer of another asset, which was postponed for technical reasons;
another asset had been initially identified for sale as part of this transaction and instead will be sold to another
third party by the end of 2019 under the same conditions). We may receive up to an additional €140 million in the
future from the sale, depending mainly on the future yield derived from the monetization of the properties sold.
This variable component has not been recognized in our financial statements. We have retained a stake in the
entity holding the sold properties. The properties identified for sale as a part of this transaction were recorded as
of June 30, 2019 as assets held for sale in accordance with IFRS 5 for a value of €338 million. We expect to
continue operating the stores under leases representing annual rent of €27 million.

On October 17, 2019, we announced that we had entered into agreements to sell 20 restaurants under our À la
Bonne Heure and Coeur de Blé banners, as well as certain of our real estate properties on which our franchisees
operate 6 restaurants. The agreements signed represent a total amount of approximately €20 million and the
underlying sale is expected to be largely completed at the end of 2019.

21

In addition, on October 17, 2019, we announced the signature of agreements for the sale of two Géant Casino
hypermarkets to Système U valued at €57 million. In 2018, these stores generated pre-tax sales of approximately
€64 million and a loss in trading profit of around €2.5 million.

By no later than the Segisor Guarantee Date, the Collateral is

In the event that the proceeds of the Offering are deposited
into escrow, the Notes will also be secured by the Escrow
Account Charge from the Issue Date until the Escrow Release
Date.

For more information on the Note Collateral, see
“Description of the Notes—Security”.

The value of the Note Collateral resides mainly in the value
of the shares of IGC, which will be significantly impacted by
the value of the real estate assets which are directly and
indirectly owned by IGC. As a consequence, although not
part of the Note Collateral, the value of the real estate assets
directly and indirectly owned by IGC will have a significant
impact on the value of the Note Collateral. The value of the
real estate assets directly and indirectly owned by IGC is
subject to change and may be impacted by many factors
beyond our control, including general macroeconomic
conditions, evolution of the real estate market in a specific
area of France and the assessment of French courts in the case
of insolvency or bankruptcy proceedings in France. See “Risk
_Factors—Risks Related to Our Indebtedness, the Notes, the_
_Note Guarantees and the Note Collateral—_ _The Note_
_Collateral may not be sufficient to secure the obligations_
_under the Notes, the Notes being secured only to the extent of_
_the value of the assets that have been and will be granted as_
_security for the Notes”. For a description of the leases held_
directly or indirectly by IGC, see “Summary—The Issuer”.

The security interests in the Note Collateral will be subject to
certain contractual and legal limitations and defenses
provided by French law, as described in “Certain Insolvency
_Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and_
_Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and Security Interests”_
and may be released under certain circumstances. See
“Description of the Notes—Security—Release of the
_Security”._

The Offering is expected to be consummated on the Issue
Date, which may be prior to the date of the execution of the
New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement in an aggregate
amount of at least €1.8 billion. If the Offering is
consummated prior thereto, pending the execution of the New
Revolving Credit Facility Agreement providing for the New
Revolving Credit Facility in an aggregate amount of at least
€1.8 billion, the Initial Purchasers (as defined herein) will,
concurrently with the issuance of the Notes on the Issue Date,
deposit the gross proceeds of the Offering into the Escrow
Account. Following the deposit of the gross proceeds of the
Offering in the Escrow Account by the Initial Purchasers, the
Escrow Account will be controlled by the Escrow Agent and
pledged on a first-ranking basis on behalf of the Trustee for
its benefit and for the benefit of the holders of the Notes.
Upon delivery to the Escrow Agent and the Trustee of a
certificate stating that the conditions to the release of the

**SUMMARY HISTORICAL CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER DATA**

The Issuer is a holding company with no independent operations of its own and whose material assets as of the
Issue Date will consist only of its direct interest in the share capital of IGC and intragroup receivables owed to it
under the Proceeds Loans and, if applicable, the Escrow Account. The Issuer does not prepare, and does not intend
to prepare, consolidated financial statements at the level of the Issuer. As a result, this Listing Prospectus instead
presents consolidated financial and other data for CGP and its consolidated subsidiaries only.

The summary financial information presented below is taken from CGP’s audited consolidated financial
statements for the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2018, prepared in accordance with IFRS and CGP’s
unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements for the six months ended June 30, 2019 prepared
in accordance with IFRS, a free translation of which, in each case, are included elsewhere in this Listing
Prospectus.

CGP’s audited consolidated financial statements for the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2018 were subject
to an audit by Ernst & Young et Autres and Deloitte & Associés, CGP’s statutory auditors for those years. CGP’s
unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements for the six months ended June 30, 2019 were
subject to a limited review by Ernst & Young et Autres and Deloitte & Associés, CGP’s statutory auditors for
such period.

The summary financial information presented below also presents unaudited financial information of CGP for the
twelve-month period ended June 30, 2019 which was calculated by adding the unaudited interim condensed
consolidated financial information for the six months ended June 30, 2019, excluding the impact of IFRS 16 –
Leases, to the audited consolidated financial information for the year ended December 31, 2018 extracted from
the audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018, and subtracting the
unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial information for the six months ended June 30, 2018, excluding
the impact of IFRS 16 – Leases, but restated to reflect the retroactive application of IAS 29 – Financial Reporting
in Hyperinflationary Economies.

During the periods under review in this Listing Prospectus, we have adopted certain accounting standards that
may have an impact on the comparability of the financial information presented herein. This includes the adoption
of IFRS 16 – Leases, IFRS 15 – Revenue from Contracts with Customers. IAS 29 – Financial Reporting in HyperInflationary Economies and IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments. We have applied each of these standards with limited
retroactive effect and as a result, our financial statements may not be directly comparable between periods. See
“Presentation of Financial and Other Information”.

In connection with our adoption of IFRS 15, we changed the presentation of the income statement appearing in
our consolidated financial statements beginning with our consolidated financial statements as of and for the year
ended December 31, 2018, with a restated presentation of the comparative information as of and for the year ended
December 31, 2017. We did not, however, republish our consolidated financial statements as of and for the year
December 31, 2017 (which include a presentation of comparative information as of and for the year ended
December 31, 2016). To facilitate the review of these periods and present our financial information in a
comparable manner:

  - where we present income statement information for the year ended December 31, 2017 alongside income
statement information for the ended December 31, 2018, we present such income statement information
for the year ended December 31, 2017 restated for IFRS 15; and

  - where we present income statement information for the year ended December 31, 2017 alongside income
statement information for the year ended December 31, 2016, we present such income statement
information for the year ended December 31, 2017 excluding the retrospective application of IFRS 15 as
it appears in our consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2017.

We have applied the IFRS 16 standard from its mandatory adoption date of January 1, 2019. In the preparation of
our financial statements as of and for the six months ended June 30, 2019, we applied the full retrospective
transition approach and have restated all comparative information for the prior comparative period in accordance
with IAS 8 – Accounting Policies, Changes in Accounting Estimates and Errors. We have not, however, restated
our financial statements as of and for the years ended December 31, 2016, 2017 and 2018 presented in this Listing
Prospectus to give effect to IFRS 16.

Our discussion of our results of operations from continuing operations for the six months ended June 30, 2018
and 2019 presented herein is on a pre-IFRS 16 basis. We also present certain non-IFRS measures on a pre-IFRS
16 basis in this Listing Prospectus. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Other Financial
_Measures”. While we will be required under IFRS to produce financial statements that give effect to IFRS 16,_

Facility will be calculated without taking into account the impact of IFRS 16 and we only intend to comment on
our financial condition and results of operations on a pre-IFRS 16 basis going forward in reports that we provide
to noteholders.

(i) Net gain on disposal of non-current assets for the year ended December 31, 2018 primarily concerned the France Retail
segment and especially disposals of Monoprix store properties in sale and leaseback transactions. Net gain on disposal of
non-current assets for the six months ended June 30, 2019 primarily concerned the France Retail segment.

(ii) The net asset impairment losses recognized during the year ended December 31, 2016 primarily concerned individual assets

in the France Retail segment in an amount of €28 million (mainly Franprix-Leader Price and DCF) and the E-commerce
segment in an amount of €10 million. The impairment loss recognized during the year ended December 31, 2017 mainly
concerned individual assets in the France Retail segment in an amount of €36 million, the Latam Retail segment (primarily
GPA) in an amount of €28 million, and the E-commerce segment in an amount of €7 million. The impairment loss recognized
during the year ended December 31, 2018 mainly concerns the France Retail segment. The impairment loss recognized during
the six months ended June 30, 2019 mainly concerns the France Retail segment and relates to the Asset Disposal Plan.

(iii) The €154 million net expense recognized during the year ended December 31, 2016 resulted primarily from changes in the

scope of consolidation in the Franprix-Leader Price sub-group in an amount of €72 million (including €59 million for sales
to master franchisees and acquisitions of controlling interests in other franchisees) and at DCF in an amount of €34 million,
together with related transaction costs of €19 million, partly offset by the €16 million effect of measuring at fair value the
previously-held interest in Geimex when the Group acquired control of this company. The €90 million net expense recognized
in 2017 resulted mainly from the loss of control of supermarket stores at DCF for an amount of €30 million, a net expense
related to various changes in scope at Franprix-Leader Price in an amount of €9 million, and fees of €31 million. The net
expense of €146 million recorded in 2018 resulted primarily from the reclassification to profit or loss, in accordance with
IAS 21, of foreign currency translation adjustments accumulated in the foreign currency translation reserve for an amount of
€67 million. The €33 million expense recorded during the six months ended June 30, 2018 primarily concerned fees related
to various projects for changes in the scope of consolidation. The expense relating to the store optimization plan in the France
Retail segment, including employee costs, store closure costs, inventory reduction costs and impairment totaled €67 million

42


-----

during the six months ended June 30, 2019 (of which €21 million corresponding to changes in scope and €46 million to
restructuring). Other changes in scope of consolidation mainly concern the France Retail segment.

(iv) Restructuring provisions and expenses in 2016 were recognized mainly in the France Retail segment in an amount of €207

million (including employee costs of €58 million, rent on closed stores of €25 million, external costs of €57 million and
impairment losses and scrapped assets of €67 million) and at GPA in an amount of €26 million. Restructuring provisions and
expenses in 2017 were recognized mainly in the France Retail segment in an amount of €169 million (including employee
costs and store closure costs in an amount of €113 million and store transformation costs in an amount of €54 million) and in
the Latam Retail segment (mainly GPA) in an amount of €38 million. Restructuring provisions and expenses in 2018 were
recognized primarily in the France Retail segment in an amount of €140 million (including employee costs and store closure
costs in an amount of €102 million and store transformation costs in an amount of €24 million) and in the Latam Retail
segment (mainly GPA) in an amount of €58 million. Excluding the impact of the store optimization plan, restructuring
provisions and expenses for the six months ended June 30, 2019 were recognized mainly in the France Retail and Latam
Retail segments in amounts of €28 million and €20 million, respectively. Restructuring expenses for the six months ended
June 30, 2018 related chiefly to the France Retail segment in an amount of €49 million (including employee-related costs and
store closure costs in an amount of €41 million, and store conversion costs of €8 million) and to the Latam Retail segment in
an amount of €37 million.

(v) In 2016, provisions and expenses for litigation and risks were recognized at GPA in an amount of €106 million, mainly
covering tax risks. Provisions and expenses for litigation and risks represented a net expense of €84 million in 2018, including
€35 million for tax risks at GPA. The net expense of €92 million in 2017 included €60 million for the tax amnesty programs
in which GPA participated during the period. Provisions and expenses for litigation and risks represented a net expense of
€43 million in the six months ended June 30, 2019, including €24 million for tax risks at GPA. In the six months ended June
30, 2018, the net expense of €16 million was recognized primarily in the France Retail and Latam Retail segments in the
amounts of €6 million and €8 million, respectively.

(vi) The net expense for 2016 included €43 million related to the 2015 tax on retail space (“TaSCom”) payable in France.

Following the introduction of new tax rules which led to a change in the period in which this levy is recognized, the TaSCom
due for 2015 was recognized in full at the beginning of 2016 in Other operating expenses and the TaSCom for 2016 was
recognized on a straight line basis over the year in Trading profit.

(b) Including BRL 288 million (€75 million) of cumulative Program of Social Integration (“PIS”) and Contribution for the Financing
of Social Security (“COFINS”) tax credits recognized in 2016 as a deduction from “Cost of goods sold” in the accounts of GPA
(of which €68 million related to prior years) after all the conditions supporting their recognition and future use were fulfilled during
the year.

(c) Of which BRL 723 million (€201 million) for the Imposto Sobre Operações Relativas à Circulação de Mercadorias e Serviços de
Transporte Interestadual de Intermunicipal e de Comunicações, or Tax on Circulation of Goods and Services for Interstate and
Intercity Transportation and Communication (“ICMS”) and Substituição Tributária, or Tax Substitution (“ST”) tax credits dating
back prior to November 2016 and recognized by GPA during the year as a deduction from “Cost of goods sold”. The tax credits
were recognized following the publication in April 2017 of the agreement for the enforcement of the October 2016 ruling by
Brazil’s supreme federal court stipulating that the ICMS-ST tax is not a final tax and should not therefore be included in the basis
of assessment of PIS and COFINS taxes, allowing GPA to apply for a refund from the Brazilian state administrations. Recognition
of the pre-November 2016 ICMS-ST tax credits of Sendas Distribution (a subsidiary of GPA), in the amount of BRL 369 million
(€102 million), had no impact on the consolidated income statement because they are not expected to be recovered and were written
down in full.

(d) Of which BRL 481 million (€111 million) in respect of tax credits recognized by GPA during the period (mainly reversal of the
valuation allowance on Assaí’s ICMS-ST tax credit following a change in the law, as described above).

(e) Of which BRL 414 million (€100 million) recognized in respect of tax credits by GPA during the period (mainly reversal of the
valuation allowance on Assaí’s ICMS-ST tax credit following a change in the law, as described above).

(6) Underlying net profit/(loss), Group share corresponds to net profit from continuing operations, adjusted for (i) the impact of other
operating income and expenses, (ii) the impact of non-recurring financial items and (iii) income tax expense/benefit related to these
adjustments. Non-recurring financial items consist of changes in the fair value of equity derivatives (such as total return swaps and
forward contracts on CBD shares) and the effects of discounting tax liabilities in Brazil.

Minority interests in underlying profit represent the share of underlying net profit attributable to non-controlling interests. This indicator
is therefore equal to net profit from continuing operations attributable to non-controlling interests, adjusted for non-controlling interests
in other operating income and expenses and the impact of non-recurring financial items, as well as income tax expense/benefits related
to these adjustments. The Group uses these indicators to measure changes in recurring profit from operations.
