concepts under its Carulla banner and Éxito hypermarkets. Moreover, Grupo Éxito continued to develop its
complementary businesses, such as property development with the delivery of the Viva Envigado and Viva Tunja
projects in October 2018. The property network now totals approximately 735,000 square meters. Lastly, the
Group pursued its omni-channel strategy with sales growth in e-commerce in Colombia.

_Other revenue_

Other revenue decreased by €23 million, or 4%, from €555 million for the year ended December 31, 2017 to €532
million for the year ended December 31, 2018, for the reasons described below.

France Retail other revenue decreased by €16 million, or 4%, from €397 million for the year ended December 31,
2017 to €381 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to a decrease in property development
sales and in property trading activity in France (which is by its nature subject to volatility due to the number of
ongoing projects at any given point in time) and is unrelated to the Asset Disposal Plan and the Rocade Plan.
Latam Retail other revenue decreased by €7 million, or 4%, from €158 million for the year ended December 31,
2017 to €151 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, mainly due to the negative impact of depreciation of
the Brazilian real and the Colombian peso in 2018, which was partially offset by the positive effect of the
development of real estate projects in Colombia.

_Gross margin_

Gross margin decreased by €185 million, from €9,490 million for the year ended December 31, 2017 to
€9,305 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, for the reasons discussed below. As a percentage of total
revenue, gross margin remained flat at 24.9% in 2017 and 25.1% in 2018.

In France Retail, gross margin as a percentage of total revenue increased by 1 percentage point, due to
improvements in our mix of concepts, geographies and products.

Our E-commerce segment’s gross margin as a percentage of total revenue increased by 2 percentage points in
2018, due to the increased share of Cdiscount’s GMV attributable to its marketplace, which is a higher margin
source of revenue for us.

In Latam Retail, gross margin rate decreased by 1 percentage point, mainly due to the lower impact of tax credits
on cost of goods sold in Brazil in 2018 compared with 2017. In addition, the growth of Assaí’s share of GPA’s
business negatively impacts gross margin, as its overall business model has lower margins.

During the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2018, GPA recognized certain tax credits in Brazil. Such tax
credits were first recognized in application of an October 2016 ruling by Brazil’s supreme federal court regarding
the assessment basis for certain taxes, which allowed GPA to apply for a refund from the Brazilian state
administrations. During the year ended December 31, 2017, BRL 723 million (€201 million) for such tax credits
were recognized by GPA during the year, which were reflected in our results of operations as a corresponding
reduction in cost of goods sold. During the year ended December 31, 2018, GPA recognized only BRL 481 million
(€111 million) of such tax credits, which were reflected in our results of operations as a corresponding reduction
in its cost of goods sold.

_SG&A_

SG&A decreased by €182 million, or 2%, from €8,277 million for the year ended December 31, 2017 to €8,095
million for the year ended December 31, 2018. In France Retail, SG&A increased by €222 million, or 4.7%, from
€4,729 million for the year ended December 31, 2017 to €4,951 million for the year ended December 31, 2018,
resulting from the impacts of perimeter effects in Monoprix (including the acquisition of Sarenza in the first half
of 2018 and impacts of the expansion of the network in 2017 and 2018), the development of GreenYellow and
other operational initiatives such as the extension of opening hours. E-commerce SG&A increased by €21 million,
or 11%, from €194 million for the year ended December 31, 2017 to €215 million for the year ended December
31, 2018, in line with its 10% increase in GMV. In Latam Retail, at actual exchange rates, SG&A decreased by
€387 million, or 11%, and at constant exchange rates they would have increased by €181 million, or 5%. Of such
increase at constant exchange rates, the increase of SG&A at Assaí, the SG&A of which grew by 23%, in line
with its 24% increase in sales, alone represented 4 percentage points, and Grupo Éxito’s Argentine business, the
SG&A of which increased by 29% due to inflation, represented 1 percentage point of this increase.

_Trading profit_

As a result of the foregoing, trading profit decreased by €4 million, or 0.3%, from €1,213 million for the year
ended December 31, 2017 to €1,209 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, as a result of the factors
discussed in the segment discussion below. On an organic basis, trading profit increased by 9.8%. Excluding the

122


-----

impact of tax credits in Brazil of €201 million in 2017 and €111 million in 2018, trading profit increased by 8.5%
on an as-reported basis and 18.0% on an organic basis. As a percentage of net sales, trading profit increased from
3.2% for the year ended December 31, 2017 to 3.3% for the year ended December 31, 2018.

France Retail

Trading profit for our France Retail segment increased by €43 million, or 7.9%, from €536 million for the year
ended December 31, 2017 to €579 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, due primarily to improved retail
trading profit and the development of additional businesses (including GreenYellow and 3W.relevanC, offset
partially by a decline in property development trading profit. As a percentage of France Retail net sales, France
Retail trading profit increased from 2.9% for the year ended December 31, 2017 to 3.0% for the year ended
December 31, 2018.

Trading profit for the retail business excluding property development trading amounted to €518 million, reflecting
organic growth at constant exchange rates of 15.7% that was attributable to an improved margin mix, the
optimization of the store base and our banners’ success in signing up new store operators and franchisees. Property
development trading profit was €61 million in 2018, compared with €87 million in 2017.

E-commerce

Trading loss for our E-commerce segment decreased by €23 million from a loss of €37 million for the year ended
December 31, 2017 to a loss of €14 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. As a percentage of E-commerce
net sales, E-commerce trading loss decreased from 1.9% for the year ended December 31, 2017 to 0.7% for the
year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to an increased marketplace share, higher
revenues from relatively higher margin monetization of its marketplace, data, traffic, customer and logistics assets
and an optimized pricing and shipping strategy.

Latam Retail

Trading profit for our Latam Retail segment decreased by €69 million, or 9.7%, from €713 million for the year
ended December 31, 2017 to €644 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. On an organic basis, Latam
Retail trading profit increased by 7.1%. As a percentage of Latam Retail net sales, Latam Retail trading profit
decreased from 4.2% for the year ended December 31, 2017 to 4.1% for the year ended December 31, 2018. Latam
Retail trading profit was primarily impacted by the recognition of tax credits in Brazil, as described in further
detail above. Excluding the impact of these tax credits, Latam Retail trading profit increased primarily due to the
continued strong performance of Assaí, the success of new formats in Brazil and Colombia and efforts to optimize
store costs and reduce expenses generally in Brazil.

_Other operating income and expenses_

Other operating expenses decreased by €105 million, or 21.9%, from a net expense of €480 million for the year
ended December 31, 2017 to a net expense of €375 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. For the year
ended December 31, 2018, other operating income and expenses included a net expense of €263 million, which
was mainly due to restructuring costs incurred to complete major store transformation plans (such as the
conversion of Leader Price stores to the “Next” concept, the conversion of Franprix stores to the “Mandarine”
concept and development of proximity formats). Other operating expenses also included non-recurring expenses
related to closures of loss-making stores pursuant to the Rocade Plan. In 2017, net operating expense mainly
comprised costs related to (i) the reduction of Géant retail space, (ii) the roll-out of the Mandarine concept across
our Franprix stores, (iii) the overhaul of our catering business and (iv) the streamlining of our convenience stores
network.

_Net finance costs_

Net finance costs decreased by €40 million, or 10.9%, from a net expense of €367 million for the year ended
December 31, 2017 to a net expense of €327 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease resulted
from a decrease in interest expense on borrowings and on finance lease liabilities of €85 million mainly driven by
lower interest rates in Brazil and Colombia, partially offset by a decrease in interest income on cash and cash
equivalents of €44 million related to the repatriation into France of cash held in Brazilian reais.

_Other financial income and expenses_

Other financial income and expenses increased by €60 million, or 75.9% from a net expense of €78 million for
the year ended December 31, 2017 to a net expense of €138 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This
change was due primarily to the net effect of remeasurements at fair value of non-hedging derivative instruments

123


-----

(including a TRS and a forward contract on CBD shares) and the impact of applying IAS 29 to our operations in
Argentina to account for hyperinflation.

_Profit before tax_

Profit before tax increased by €83 million, or 29%, from a net profit of €286 million for the year ended December
31, 2017 to a net profit of €369 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, as a result of the factors discussed
above.

_Income tax expense_

Income tax expense increased by €156 million from a net expense of €48 million for the year ended December
31, 2017 to a net expense of €204 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. In addition to an increase in our
profit before tax, income tax expense in 2018 was impacted by (i) non-deductible non-recurring expenses recorded
in 2018 related to currency conversion differences previously accounted for in equity and subsequently recognized
in our income statement in 2018 in accordance with IAS 21, (ii) the effect of a €60 million benefit recorded in
2017 due to a reimbursement of a tax on dividends and (iii) a tax expense on Monoprix real estate assets sold in
2018, to which an effective tax rate of 34.43% applied, but for which we had recorded deferred tax liabilities
based on a projected 2022 tax rate of 25.83% based on the most recent tax legislation.

_Share of profit of equity-accounted investees_

Share of profit of equity-accounted investees increased from €13 million for the year ended December 31, 2017
to €17 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was related to an increase in the contribution
of equity-accounted investees in the Latam Retail segment, partially offset by a decrease in the Group’s share of
profit of equity-accounted Franprix-Leader Price investees.

_Net profit/(loss) from continuing operations_

Net profit/(loss) from continuing operations decreased by €69 million from a net profit of €251 million for the
year ended December 31, 2017 to a net profit of €182 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, for the
reasons described above. Net profit/(loss) from continuing operations, attributable to the Group, decreased by
€153 million from a net profit of €108 million for the year ended December 31, 2017 to a net loss of €45 million
for the year ended December 31, 2018, principally due to higher income tax of €156 million. In 2018, the nondeductibility of certain non-recurring expenses resulted in an increase of €62 million in tax charges, while in 2017,
we benefited from a one-off €60 million tax benefit related to a refund of dividend tax in France.

_Net sales_

Net sales increased by €1,792 million, or 5.0%, from €36,030 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to
€37,822 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was due to increases in our E-commerce
and Latam Retail net sales, slightly offset by a decrease in France Retail net sales, as described below. On an
organic basis, net sales would have grown by 3.2%.

France Retail

France Retail net sales decreased by €36 million, or 0.2%, from €18,939 million for the year ended December 31,
2016 to €18,903 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was mainly due to declines in net
sales from our supermarkets and convenience and other retail businesses, partially offset by growth in our
Monoprix, Franprix, Leader Price and hypermarket sales. On an organic basis, France Retail net sales grew by
0.1%, and on a same-store basis, France Retail net sales grew by 0.8%.

Sales performance by format over the period was as follows:

  - Monoprix net sales grew by €87 million, from €4,229 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to
€4,316 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. On an organic basis, Monoprix net sales would
have grown by 2.8%. On a same-store basis, Monoprix net sales would have grown by 2%.

Monoprix’s growth was due in part to higher customer traffic, an expanded range of services, the
development of its omni-channel strategy, the expansion of its loyalty program and the expansion of its
network. Monoprix customer traffic was up 2.0% on a same-store basis. During 2017, the banner
developed new services such as deliveries on foot within the hour and extending its opening hours. In
addition, Monoprix’s omni-channel strategy gained ground late in the year, with a 21% increase in online
sales in the second half of 2017 as compared with the second half of 2016, the entry into several online
partnerships (including with Ocado, Epicery and Google Home) and innovation initiatives (such as
Monop’Easy, a scan-and-go application that allows customers to avoid having to wait to pay at the
checkout counter). Monoprix continued to successfully deploy its new loyalty program and 66% of its

125


-----

net sales were made with card-carrying customers. Furthermore, Monoprix increased the pace of its
expansion, including through accelerating the development of its organic store format Naturalia (60
Monoprix stores opened in 2017, including 24 Naturalia stores; on a net basis, the Monoprix network
grew by 44 stores) and recording a 5.7% rise in same-store traffic over the year.

  - Supermarket net sales decreased by €48 million, or 1.5%, from €3,301 million for the year ended
December 31, 2016 to €3,253 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, due mainly to store
disposals to franchisees. On an organic basis, supermarket net sales would have increased by 1.2%. On
a same-store basis, supermarket net sales would have increased by 1.5%.

The increase in our supermarkets’ net sales on a same-store basis was driven in part by increased sales
of fresh and organic products, the continued roll-out of our new upscale Bijou concept, the expansion of
its loyalty program, the development of our supermarket loyalty program and the expansion of our
supermarket network through franchises.

  - Franprix net sales increased by €10 million, or 1%, from €1,586 million for the year ended December
31, 2016 to €1,596 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. On an organic basis, Franprix net sales
would have increased by 1.3%. On a same-store basis, Franprix net sales would have increased by 1.3%.
This growth was due to increased customer traffic on a same-store basis (up 3.1% year-on-year), the
continued roll-out of the banner’s Mandarine and Noé concepts (with almost 80% of the Franprix
network having been renovated under the Mandarine concept at year-end) and the growth in the network,
primarily in the Greater Paris area.

  - Convenience net sales decreased by €12 million, or 1%, from €1,277 million for the year ended
December 31, 2016 to €1,265 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, due primarily to a decrease
in the number of stores in our network. On an organic basis, convenience net sales would have decreased
by 0.4%. On a same-store basis, convenience net sales would have increased by 0.3% when compared
with 2016, due in part to the continued improvement of our store network and the development of our
franchisee network. For example, during the year ended December 31, 2017, we rolled out the new Le
Petit Casino concept in 128 stores, and developed new services, including home delivery and new corners
within stores, such as La Poste, Relay and PMU.

  - Leader Price net sales grew by €10.2 million, or 0.4%, from €2,526 million for the year ended December
31, 2016 to €2,536 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. On an organic basis, Leader Price net
sales would have decreased by 2.9%. On a same-store basis, Leader Price net sales would have increased
by 0.2%. This growth was due in part to the deployment of Leader Price’s Next concept, which focuses
on more quality-oriented stores that maintain a discount cost structure. The banner also continued its
operational improvement initiatives, including an improved checkout process.

  - Géant Hypermarket net sales increased by €17 million, or 0.4%, from €4,432 million for the year ended
December 31, 2016 to €4,448 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. On an organic basis, Géant
hypermarket net sales would have been stable. On a same-store basis, Géant hypermarket net sales would
have increased by 0.1%. Our hypermarkets boasted strong food sales, which were led by fresh market
areas and fresh and organic products, and the continued development of its omni-channel offering and
loyalty programs.

E-commerce

E-commerce net sales increased by €152 million, or 8%, from €1,843 million for the year ended December 31,
2016 to €1,995 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This was primarily driven by an increase in GMV
of €397 million from €2,994 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to €3,391 million for the year ended
December 31, 2017, an increase of 9.6% on an organic basis.

Growth in GMV was driven by the following:

  - Strong sales growth, especially during the third quarter of 2017, as a result of Cdiscount’s strategic
realignment plan to extend its product assortment and make further delivery enhancements, as well as
particularly strong Black Friday sales in November 2017 resulting from increased promotion of Black
Friday in France.

  - We continued deploying our strategic plan for our E-commerce segment, including:

`o` Expansion of the product range: we added an additional 17 million references in 2017, bringing
total online listings to 37 million, a rise of 80% in the marketplace product offering and a three
126


-----

fold increase in references eligible for the “Cdiscount à volonté” (CDAV) loyalty program.
CDAV accounted for 31% of GMV sales in 2017, a 10 percentage point increase over 2016.

`o` Enhanced multi-channel strategy: As of December 31, 2017, five Cdiscount corners were open
in Géant hypermarkets, with immediate pick-up available for nearly 4,000 referenced items.
The banner also began rolling out a click & collect service in stores.

`o` Enhanced delivery services and innovation initiatives: As of December 31, 2017, same-day
delivery was available in the Greater Paris area, Lyon, Lille and Bordeaux.

`o` Development of new revenue streams, including “Coup de pouce”, Cdiscount Energie, Cinstallé
and a roll-out of a range of services associated with the “Fulfillment by Cdiscount” solution.

Traffic to sites consolidated under our E-commerce segment increased by 12% to 922 million visits in 2017, and
the number of customers was 6% higher year on year, at 8.6 million. In 2017, Cdiscount was France’s second
leading e-retailer, with 17 million unique visitors a month on average.

Latam Retail

Latam Retail net sales increased by €1,676 million, or 11%, from €15,247 million for the year ended December
31, 2016 to €16,923 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This was primarily due to strong growth in
the Assaí format in Brazil and increased sales from the roll-out of new concepts and formats in Colombia.

On an organic basis, Latam Retail net sales would have increased by 6.4%. On a same-store basis, Latam Retail
net sales would have increased by 3.1%.

GPA net sales grew by €1,630 million, or 15%, from €10,749 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to
€12,379 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. On an organic basis, GPA net sales grew 8.7%. On a
same-store basis, net sales grew 4.7%. This was the result of the following:

  - On a same-store basis, sales for Multivarejo (hypermarkets, supermarkets and convenience) grew by
0.7% in 2017, due in part to additional market share in the period and higher sales volumes. Extra
hypermarkets performed well in 2017, buoyed by non-food sales, which generated double-digit growth.
Volumes at Pão de Açúcar improved beginning in the third quarter of 2017, as a result of several
initiatives, including the introduction of the “My Discount” loyalty program, promotional campaigns and
more attractive pricing on certain popular items. Finally, 50 stores were renovated at the end of 2017 as
part of our continued efforts to renovate stores under this banner.

  - Assaí (cash & carry) sales rose 27.8% on an organic basis and 11.0% on a same-store basis, buoyed by
network expansion (new store openings and conversions and a move into two new states). The banner,
which accounted for 41% of GPA Food’s annual sales in 2017, delivered steady growth in volumes and
traffic and also won additional market share, in a market context defined by falling prices for certain food
categories (such as basic commodities, dairy and meat).

At the end of 2017, there were 126 stores operating under the cash & carry format, an increase from 107
stores as of December 31, 2016, including 15 conversions of Extra hypermarkets to the Assaí format.
Sales in converted stores were 2.5 times higher than sales in Extra hypermarkets.

Grupo Éxito net sales increased by €45 million, or 1.0%, from €4,499 million for the year ended December 31,
2016 to €4,544 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. On an organic basis, Grupo Éxito’s net sales grew
by 1.2% in 2017. On a same-store basis, Grupo Éxito’s net sales declined by 0.6% in 2018, due in part to higher
competitive pressure in the Colombian market led by hard discounters. Grupo Éxito’s growth was linked to
development of its cash & carry format and new concepts designed to take advantage of favorable consumer
trends. Grupo Éxito also continued to grow businesses that complement its retail operations, including the
development of real estate projects such as Viva Envigado, Colombia’s largest shopping mall, and Viva Tunja,
and the Puntos Colombia multi-banner nationwide loyalty program.

_Gross margin_

Gross margin increased by €461 million, from €8,666 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to
€9,127 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. As a percentage of net sales, gross margin remained flat at
24.1%. In France Retail, gross margin as a percentage of net sales remained stable. Our E-commerce segment’s
gross margin as a percentage of net sales decreased by 1 percentage point, reflecting the implementation costs of
customer offering and service enhancements in 2017. In Latam Retail, gross margin as a percentage of net sales
increased by 1 percentage point, mainly due to a higher amount of Brazilian tax credits, which reduced cost of
goods sold, recognized in Brazil (BRL 723 million in 2017 versus BRL 288 million in 2016). The impact of these

127


-----

tax credits was partially offset by Assaí’s increased share of activity in the Latam Retail segment, which reduces
gross margins due to its low-margin business model.

_Other income_

Other income decreased by €128 million, or 24%, from €542 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to
€414 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to a decrease in property
development sales and in property trading activity (which is by its nature subject to volatility due to the number
of ongoing projects at any given point in time), unrelated to our Asset Disposal Plan.

_SG&A_

SG&A increased by €126 million, or 1.5%, from €8,174 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to €8,300
million for the year ended December 31, 2017. In France Retail, SG&A decreased by €164 million, or 3%, from
€5,003 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to €4,839 million for the year ended December 31, 2017,
of which 2 percentage points were driven by savings realized due to increased franchising of Franprix and Leader
Price stores. Our E-commerce segment’s SG&A increased by €9 million, or 5%, from €189 million for the year
ended December 31, 2016 to €198 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, in line with its 8% increase in
net sales. In Latam Retail, at actual exchange rates, SG&A increased by 11%. Latam Retail SG&A would have
increased by 6% at constant exchange rates. Of such constant exchange rate increase, the SG&A of Assaí, which
grew by 29%, in line with its 27% increase in net sales, represented 4 percentage points.

_Trading profit_

Trading profit increased by €208 million, or 20.1%, from €1,034 million for the year ended December 31, 2016
to €1,242 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, mainly driven by a strong increase in our Latam Retail
segment trading profit and an increase in our France Retail segment trading profit, offset partially by a decrease
in our E-commerce segment trading profit, each as described below. On an organic basis, trading profit would
have increased by 13.4%.

France Retail

Trading profit for our France Retail segment increased by €48 million, or 9.5%, from €508 million for the year
ended December 31, 2016 to €556 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, mainly due to stronger
profitability of our Franprix and Monoprix banners, an improved contribution from Casino Supermarkets and
increased profitability at Géant, as well as an increased contribution from our property development business
(€92 million in the year ended December 31, 2017, compared with €87 million in the year ended December 31,
2016). As a percentage of France Retail net sales, France Retail trading profit increased from 2.7% for the year
ended December 31, 2016 to 2.9% for the year ended December 31, 2017.

E-commerce

Trading loss for our E-commerce segment increased by €16 million, from a loss of €11 million for the year ended
December 31, 2016 to a loss of €27 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. As a percentage of E-commerce
net sales, E-commerce trading loss increased from negative 0.6% for the year ended December 31, 2016 to
negative 1.3% for the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was primarily due to the impact of investments
we made in our E-commerce business under the Cdiscount strategic plan, including expansion of its assortment
and subsequent warehousing capacity and a revamp of its website and mobile application.

Latam Retail

Trading profit for our Latam Retail segment increased by €175 million, or 32.7%, from €538 million for the year
ended December 31, 2016 to €713 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, mainly due to the recognition
of tax credits in 2017 and a favorable exchange rate development. At constant exchange rates, Latam Retail trading
profit would have increased by 26.3%. As a percentage of Latam Retail net sales, Latam Retail trading profit
increased from 3.5% for the year ended December 31, 2016 to 4.2% for the year ended December 31, 2017.

Trading profit for Latam Retail was positively impacted by the recognition of certain tax credits by GPA in Brazil,
which were reflected in our results of operations as a corresponding reduction in cost of goods sold. In the year
ended December 31, 2017, the recognition of such tax credits had an impact of BRL 723 million (€201 million),
compared with BRL 288 million (€75 million) in the year ended December 31, 2016. Certain other tax credits of
Sendas Distribution (a subsidiary of GPA) relating to the period prior to November 2016, in the amount of BRL
369 million (€102 million), had no impact on the consolidated income statement, because they are not expected
to be recovered, and were written down in full. Excluding the favorable impact from GPA’s tax credit recognition

128


-----

described above, GPA’s trading profit margin would have increased from 2.1% in the year ended December 31,
2017 to 2.7% for the year ended December 31, 2018 at actual exchange rates.

Grupo Éxito saw a decline in profitability as its trading profit margin, as a percentage of net sales fell to 4.0%,
down 123 bps. At GPA, trading profit margin as a percentage of net sales climbed 148 bps to 4.3%.

_Other operating income and expenses_

Other operating expenses decreased by €145 million, or 23.2%, from a net expense of €625 million for the year
ended December 31, 2016 to a net expense of €480 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease
was primarily due to the gradual completion of a number of retail concept transformation programs in France. In
2017, in France, other operating expenses mainly comprised costs related to (i) the reduction of Géant retail space,
(ii) the roll-out of the Mandarine concept across our Franprix stores, (iii) the overhaul of our catering business
and (iv) the streamlining of our Convenience stores network.

In 2016, net operating expense mainly comprised (i) the reorganization of the Franprix – Leader Price and Casino
supermarkets networks in France, (ii) restructuring costs, particularly in France (primarily social costs and costs
associated with store closures) and the implementation of new concepts, (iii) provisions for litigation and risks,
mainly related to tax risks for GPA’s Brazilian operations, and (iv) other expenses, mainly reflecting the impact
of a change in tax rules which exceptionally resulted in our recognition of tax on retail space payable in France
for both 2015 and 2016 during the 2016 financial year.

_Net finance costs_

Net finance costs increased by €43 million, or 13.4%, from a net expense of €324 million for the year ended
December 31, 2016 to a net expense of €367 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was
due to an increase in interest expense on borrowings and on finance lease liabilities of €15 million, combined with
a decrease in interest income on cash and cash equivalents of €29 million. Finance costs were higher in France
due to the full-year impact of an interest step-up on our bond debt following Casino’s rating downgrade to BB+
by Standard & Poor’s in March 2016, which was partially offset by lower finance costs in Latin America,
reflecting the decrease in interest rates in Brazil.

_Other financial income and expenses_

Other financial income and expenses deteriorated by €43 million from a net expense of €35 million for the year
ended December 31, 2016 to a net expense of €78 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This change
was due primarily to the net effect of remeasurements at fair value of non-hedging derivative instruments in 2016
in connection with TRSs and forward contracts on CBD shares and on TRSs on Big C Thailand shares (which
swaps were unwound in 2016) and in 2017 in connection with TRSs and forward contracts on CBD shares.

_Profit before tax_

Profit before tax increased by €266 million from a net profit of €50 million for the year ended December 31, 2016
to a net profit of €316 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, as a result of the factors discussed above.

_Income tax expense_

Income tax expense increased by €22 million from a net expense of €34 million for the year ended December 31,
2016 to a net expense of €56 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase was primarily due to
an increase in our profit before tax, offset by a €60 million benefit recorded in relation to the reimbursement of a
tax on dividends and the favorable impact from the activation of deferred tax assets.

_Share of profit of equity-accounted investees_

Share of profit of equity-accounted investees decreased by €7 million, or 35%, from €20 million for the year ended
December 31, 2016 to €13 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease was related to a €6
million lower contribution from our stake in Mercialys.

_Net profit/(loss) from continuing operations_

Net profit/(loss) from continuing operations increased by €237 million from a net profit of €36 million for the
year ended December 31, 2016 to a net profit of €273 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, for the
reasons described above. Net profit/(loss) from continuing operations, attributable to the Group, increased by €94
million from a net profit of €33 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 to a net profit of €127 million for

129


-----

the year ended December 31, 2017, reflecting an improvement in trading profit, partially offset by higher finance
costs and expenses.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

We use cash to pay for working capital requirements, taxes, interest and dividend payments, capital expenditures
and acquisitions and to service our indebtedness in accordance with repayment schedules.

Our sources of financing consist mainly of the following:

  - cash generated from our operating activities and asset disposals;

  - borrowings under our confirmed credit facilities, overdraft facilities and commercial paper program (as
of June 30, 2019, CGP had confirmed, undrawn lines of €2,719 million); and

  - net proceeds from our outstanding debt securities and any other debt securities that we may issue in the
future.

As of June 30, 2019, as adjusted to give effect to the Refinancing and without giving effect to IFRS 16, our France
Retail and E-commerce gross debt before the impact of IFRS 5 would have amounted to €6,182 million, our
France Retail and E-commerce gross debt after the impact of IFRS 5 would have amounted to €5,199 million and
our France Retail and E-commerce net debt would have amounted to €3,615 million.

**_France Retail Assets Classified under IFRS 5_**

We hold a number of assets on balance sheet that are treated in accordance with IFRS 5– Non-current assets held
for sale and discontinued operations because they represent assets are held for sale. IFRS 5 allows companies to
classify certain assets as held for sale, and therefore presented separately in the company’s statement of financial
position, among other consequences, when a disposal occurs or is planned, including distribution of non-current
assets to shareholders, and certain criteria defined in IFRS 5 are met. The held-for-sale criteria in IFRS 5 apply to
non-current assets (or disposal groups) whose value will be recovered principally through sale rather than through
continuing use. The criteria do not apply to non-current assets that are being scrapped, wound down or abandoned.
As of June 30, 2019, excluding the impact of IFRS 16, we had €983 million in assets classified under IFRS 5 on
our balance sheet in our France Retail segment. These were primarily related to the Asset Disposal Plan and the
Rocade Plan. During the six months ended June 30, 2019, assets on our balance sheet classified under IFRS 5
decreased by €559 million, due primarily to the completion of the sale of real estate assets to Fortress.

**_Free Cash Flow_**

We define free cash flow as EBITDA less change in working capital, income taxes and net capital expenditures.
Free cash flow is presented before the payment of dividends to shareholders and holders of CGP’s Existing Deeply
Subordinated Perpetual Notes and excluding financial expenses. We present free cash flow as additional
information because we believe it is helpful to investors in highlighting trends in our business. However, other
companies may present free cash flow differently than we do. Free cash flow is not a measure of financial
performance under IFRS and should not be considered as an alternative to operating income as an indicator of our
operating performance or any other measures of performance derived in accordance with IFRS.

**_Non-Hedging Derivative Instruments_**

We have entered into certain non-hedging derivative instruments, in particular a TRS (the “GPA TRS”) and
forward contracts (the “GPA Forward Contract”, and, together with the GPA TRS, the “GPA Instruments”)
relating to CBD shares, which are cash-settled instruments. Under the applicable documentation, when the forward
contracts expire, the shares are sold on the market by the banking counterparties and we are required to pay the
difference between the sale proceeds and the amount paid by the counterparties to purchase the shares at the
contracts’ inception (if such proceeds are lower), or receive such difference (if such proceeds are higher). We
report the fair value of the GPA Instruments, and gains or losses on the GPA Instruments are recognized in other
financial income and expenses. As of December 31, 2018 the GPA Instruments had an aggregate negative fair
value of €272 million, as compared with a negative fair value of €260 million as of December 31, 2017. For the
six months ended June 30, 2019, we recorded a positive €36 million fair value adjustment to the GPA TRS and a
positive €20 million fair value adjustment to the GPA Forward Contract. The GPA TRS expires in June 2020 and
the GPA Forward Contract expires in February 2020. For more information on the GPA Instruments, please see

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure of Market Risks**

We are exposed to various market risks as part of our business activities. Several of these risks are described in
detail elsewhere in this Listing Prospectus under the caption “Risk Factors”. The main risk areas that may have a
material influence on our business performance as well as our financial position and results of operations are set
out below.

**_Liquidity Risk_**

Liquidity risk is the risk of a company not having the necessary funds to settle its commitments when they fall
due.

Our liquidity policy is to ensure, to the extent possible, that we always have sufficient liquid assets to settle our
liabilities as they fall due, in either normal or impaired market conditions.

We aim to mitigate liquidity risk through:

  - diversifying financing sources;

139


-----

  - diversifying borrowing currencies;

  - maintaining at all times confirmed financing facilities that significantly exceed our liabilities;

  - limiting annual debt repayments and proactively managing the repayment schedule; and

  - managing the average maturity of debt.

The liquidity analysis is performed both at the level of CGP (taking into account cash pool in place with its French
subsidiaries) and for each of our international subsidiaries. Each banner submits weekly cash reports to the Group
and all new financing facilities require prior approval from the Corporate Finance department. For a discussion of
our contractual commitments under our financial debt, see “—Contractual Obligations and Commitments”.

For a further discussion of our management of liquidity risk, see note 9.5 to our unaudited interim condensed
consolidated financial statements as of and for the six months ended June 30, 2019 and note 11.5.4 to our audited
consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 included in this Listing
Prospectus.

**_Interest Rate Risk_**

Interest rate risk is the risk related to an increase in borrowing costs due to higher interest rates. We are exposed
to this risk to the extent that our borrowings accrue interest at variable rates.

We manage interest rate risk by monitoring rate forecasts and, when necessary, entering into hedging transactions.
The aim is to manage the risk of an increase in interest rates and optimize borrowing costs. We use various
standard instruments to implement this strategy, principally interest rate swaps and options. These instruments do
not always qualify for hedge accounting; however, all interest rate instruments are contracted in line with our risk
management policy.

CGP’s debt is mainly composed of fixed-rate bonds. Certain interest streams on part of this debt were swapped
for variable rate streams. As of December 31, 2018, CGP had a portfolio of 68 interest rate swaps and options
with 12 bank counterparties. These instruments expire at various dates between 2019 and 2026. As a result, as of
December 31, 2018, 31% of the outstanding amount of CGP’s bond debt was hedged at a fixed rate, 35% was
hedged at capped variable rates and 34% was unhedged and accrued at uncapped variable rates.

For a further discussion of our management of interest rate risk, see note 11.5.2 to our audited consolidated
financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 included in this Listing Prospectus.

**_Currency Risk_**

Due to our geographically diversified business base, we are exposed to both currency translation risk on the
translation of the balance sheets and income statements of subsidiaries outside the euro zone into euro and to
currency transaction risk on transactions denominated in currencies other than the euro. Currency translation risk
primarily concerns the financial statements of the Group’s subsidiaries in Brazil and Colombia and arises from
changes in exchange rates for the Brazilian real and Colombian peso against the euro. Transaction risk mainly
concerns goods purchases billed in U.S. dollars.

An unfavorable change in exchange rates could have a negative impact on our consolidated financial statements
(translation risk) and lead to financial losses (transaction risk).

We hedge currency transaction risk on highly probable future purchases (mainly goods purchases billed in U.S.
dollars) through forward purchases of the payment currency. In addition, we fully hedge currency risks on debt
issuances denominated in a currency other than that of the issuer.

We use standard financial instruments such as interest rate swaps and forward currency transactions to manage
our exposure to currency risks. These instruments are mainly over-the-counter instruments entered into with firstclass bank counterparties. Most of these transactions or instruments qualify for hedge accounting. However, like
many other large groups, we may take very small, strictly controlled positions that do not qualify for hedge
accounting, for more dynamic and flexible management of our interest rate exposures.

For a further discussion of our management of currency risk, see note 11.5.2 to our audited consolidated financial
statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 included in this Listing Prospectus.

**_Counterparty and Credit Risk_**

Counterparty risk is the risk that a counterparty fails and is unable to honor its financial commitments (credit risk)
or other commitments to our group.

140


-----

We are exposed to counterparty risk in several ways: as a result of our operating activities (for example, consumer
finance for our customers), our cash investing activities and our interest rate and currency hedging activities (our
counterparties being banking institutions for the latter three cases). If a counterparty risk were to occur, we could
incur financial losses.

We monitor these risks regularly using several objective indicators and attempt to reduce our exposure by dealing
with low-risk counterparties (as determined mainly on such counterparties’ credit ratings and their reciprocal
commitments with us).

Our policy for managing customer credit risk consists of checking the financial health of all customers applying
for credit. We regularly monitor customer receivables. We do not believe our exposure to bad debts is material.

**France**

**_Macroeconomic and Demographic Overview_**

In 2018, the nominal gross domestic product (“GDP”) of France amounted to €2,349 billion, according to the
International Monetary Fund (“IMF”). The IMF ranked France as the 7[th] largest economy globally, and 3[rd] largest
in Europe. The French economy grew 1.5% in real terms in 2018, is projected to grow 1.3% in 2019 and 1.5%
with a compound average growth rate (“CAGR”) between 2018 and 2024 (source: IMF). Due to ECB policy,
inflation is relatively low in France, reaching 2.1% in 2018. Inflation is projected to be 1.3% in 2019, with a
CAGR of 1.8% between 2019-2024 (source: IMF).

France is one of the most populated countries in Europe, currently ranking only behind Russia, Germany and the
UK. In 2018, the population of France amounted to 64.7 million people (source: IMF) and was 1.1% higher than
in 2014. The French population is expected to reach 66.5 million people by 2024, which implies a 0.5% CAGR
between 2018 and 2024 (source: IMF).

80% of the French population lives in cities (source: World Bank), with around 20% of the total population living
in the Paris area as of January 1, 2019 _(source: Institut national de la statistique et des études économiques,_
_“INSEE”). France’s economic growth is largely driven by three regions: Ile-de-France, Rhône-Alpes and_
Provence-Alpes-Côte d’Azur. These regions each have favourable trends such as tourism, favourable
demographics and high living standards. These three regions have a cumulative population of 23.9 million people
(35.7% of the total French population), but generate 48% of France’s GDP according to latest data available for
2018 (source: INSEE). The French unemployment rate was 9.1% in 2018 and is projected to decrease to 8.8% in
2019 and even further to 8.4% in 2020 (source: IMF).

142


-----

**_Grocery Retail – Key Trends_**

France remains a dynamic market for retail. In France, food expenses account for 12% of the aggregate consumer
spending. This is relatively high compared to other European countries (e.g. 11.3% for Spain, 9.4% for Germany,
7.1% for the UK and slightly below 13.1% for Italy. (source: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and
_Development, “OECD”)._

**‘13-18**

**2013** **2014** **2015** **2016** **2017** **2018** **CAGR**

Food spending (€ million).. 140,281 140,140 141,841 144,659 146,402 147,967 1.1%

_Source: OECD_

As a comparison, in 2018, Italy’s food spending amounted to €138,759 million, €77,978 million for Spain,
€153,604 million for Germany and €94,403 million for the UK according to the same source.

Between 2013-18, grocery retail sales in France grew at a CAGR of 1.2%, according to Euromonitor. The French
retailing market is gradually evolving, driven by changing consumer lifestyles and socio-demographic trends,
such as an ageing population, smaller families, growing individualisation of lifestyles, digitalisation as well as
increasing urbanisation. These trends have led to a transition in gross retail from mass market to more tailored
offers which results in a greater diversity of retail formats and concepts, a broader and more segmented product
offering, as well as more individualised contact with consumers.

As economic prospects have deteriorated with falls in household consumption affected by rising taxes and a price
inflation that exceeds growth of wages and social security benefits, several challenges weigh on major store-based
grocery retailing players. Such challenges include technological change, with the emergence of international
marketplaces operating online and pure player specialists, as well as moderate volume growth due to slowdown
in economic activity. In addition, grocery retailing players are experiencing increasing competition from online
retailing as well as from international players interested in the French market, such as Action, Hema or Stokomani,
or growing local players such as Grand Frais, and the development of organic specialist retailers.

The grocery retail market is rapidly evolving on the technological front. Store-based grocery retailers are signing
new partnerships or acquiring digital players to adapt to consumer demand. With the spread of internet usage,
retailers are developing internet-linked solutions to meet consumer demand and pure-play online retailers acquire
physical spaces. The convergence of pure players and bricks-and-clicks retailers is expected to lead to the further
development of web-to-store concepts, notably “phygital” stores, hybrid connected bricks-and-clicks shops which
enable consumers to order on big screens (e.g. Monoprix’s acquisition of Sarenza or Carrefour’s acquisition of
17% of Showroomprivé).

To maintain or increase market shares, grocery retailers are expected to focus on their e-commerce operations, athome delivery services, omni-channel product offering, lengthening opening schedules as well as improvements
to product differentiation and price competition.

**_Grocery Retail – Overview of Key Formats from Euromonitor_**

_Modern grocery retailing is the aggregation of the grocery channels that have emerged alongside the growth of_
chained retail. It is the aggregation of five channels: Hypermarkets, Supermarkets, Discounters, Forecourt
Retailers and Convenience Stores.

_Traditional grocery retailing is the aggregation of channels that are invariably non-chained and are, therefore,_
owned by families and/or run on an individual basis. It is the aggregation of three channels: Independent Small
Grocers, Food/Drink/Tobacco Specialists and Other Grocery Retailers.

In 2018, 80.5% of French grocery retail sales were accounted for by modern grocery retailing as opposed to
traditional grocery retailing, which compares to 79.0% for Eastern and Western Europe, 86.6% for Germany,
78.7% for Spain and 89.6% for the UK. The share of modern grocery has decreased at a rate of 0.4 ppts per annum
in the last 5 years in France.

The Hypermarket channel is on the decline in France, with a decline in Retail Sales Value (“RSV”) of (0.1%) per
year between 2013-18. Several players have decreased or have announced their intention to decrease the area
contribution of their hypermarket operations (e.g. Casino reduced its hypermarkets sales area from 916,000 square
meters in 2016 to 848,000 square meters in 2018. Carrefour announced in February 2019 its target of 400,000
square meters sales area reduction worldwide by 2022).

143


-----

In the meantime, organic product specialist retailers, driven by a premium development trend, are supporting high
growth in the grocery retail market, and have recorded robust growth on the back of consumer preference for
organic products. Organic products’ healthy sales and high margins have encouraged modern grocery retailers to
develop their own organic corners and private label lines. This has led major players to buy smaller organic
specialist retailers (e.g. Les Mousquetaire’s acquisition of a minority share in Les Comptoirs de la Bio, Naturalia’s
development for Casino, and Carrefour’s acquisition of So’Bio). Such deals are a way to attract additional
consumers with differentiated and more engaging products.

As more and more people live in urban areas, format diversification is required to reach urban consumers not
interested in hypermarkets on the edge of towns. In order to benefit from urbanisation and concentration of highincome households around cities, grocery retailers have developed their convenience and proximity formats to
cater to consumers’ demands for convenience, accessibility, as well as premium and tailored offering. The
convenience format has proven to be highly attractive and carries on attracting more consumers that are less
sensitive to price.

**_Grocery Retail – Market Structure and Competitive Landscape_**

Key domestic modern grocery retailers in France, which have a significant nationwide presence, include
Carrefour, Intermarché, Système U, E Leclerc, Auchan Group and Casino. These grocery retailers are the six
biggest in terms of market shares grocery retailers measured across all channels and also in the specific modern
grocery retail segment.

Casino is a leading player ranked #5 in terms of market share in modern grocery retail in 2018. With the Horizon
supply network joint venture, which Casino has established with Auchan, these two players combined are the
market leader in terms of market share in modern grocery retail. In 2018, Monoprix was the #5 supermarket banner
in terms of market share in modern grocery retail and is the only large banner with a premium positioning in
France. Within the supermarket channel overall, Casino is #3 in France in 2018. In the Hypermarket channel
Géant Casino is #7 in 2018, and Leader Price is the #3 discounter in France in 2018.

for proximity and convenience stores.

Online marketplaces have gained considerable share in the e-commerce competitive landscape. This is driven by
retail sales value remaining concentrated around a few websites with the widest reach and largest sales. This
phenomenon is accentuated by the emergence of international marketplaces which can mutualize costs thanks to
high volume traded, and offer competitive prices while keeping margins constant. In addition to Amazon, some
players like Cdiscount, vente-privee.com and eBay have successfully established marketplace operations. On
September 23, 2019, Cdiscount announced the launch of a European platform to compete with Amazon, along

**_Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency_**

Through its subsidiary GreenYellow, Casino is present in the energy industry, more specifically in the
photovoltaic energy industry. The key drivers of the energy transition, driving GreenYellow’s business model are
the following: rapidly increasing share of decarbonized energy sources, strong regulatory incentives for
renewables and energy savings, shift from centralized to decentralized energy production units and customers’
willingness to reduce their energy bills whilst limiting capex, therefore benefitting energy efficiency agreements
(“EEAs”).

There are three main cost reduction drivers for renewable power, which GreenYellow aims to be well positioned
on: economies of scale and competitive procurement, technology improvements, and mature client base.
In the alternative/photovoltaic energy market, the market shares of alternative energy suppliers keep growing
since the end of the EDF monopoly in 2007. In France, the gigawatt (“GW”) photovoltaic (“PV”) installed
capacity grew at a CAGR of 13% over 2012-2017, and should grow at a CAGR of 11% over 2017-2035, faster
than all other energy sources (Source: Boston Consulting Group).

In terms of energy efficiency, France is engaged in an energy efficiency plan, aiming at reducing its final energy
consumption to 131.4 million-ton equivalent of petroleum (“Mtep”), and to 219.9 Mtep for primary energy (art.
3 of Directive 2012/27/EU) (Source: Rapport de la Direction Générale de l’Energie et du Climat – Service du

_Climat et de l’Efficacité Energétique). France has set the objective to increase its energy efficiency by 20% by_
2020 similar to all the other European countries (source: European Commission).

**Brazil**

**_Macroeconomic and Demographic Overview_**

In 2018, the nominal GDP of Brazil amounted to BRL 6,826 billion ($1,868 billion) (source: IMF). The IMF
ranked Brazil as the largest economy in South America. The Brazilian economy grew 1.1% in real terms in 2018,
is projected to grow 2.1% in real terms in 2019, and at a CAGR of 2.2% between 2018-24 (source: IMF).
Brazil is the most populated country in South America. As of January 1, 2018, the population of Brazil amounted
to 208.3 million people (source IMF). The Brazilian population is expected to reach 216.3 million by 2024, which
implies a 0.6% CAGR between 2018-24 (source: IMF).

Brazil’s economy suffered a severe political and economic crisis in mid-2014 that only ended in 2016. During
that period, Brazil fell into recession for two years, hit by the fall in commodity prices and demand (driven by
slowdown of the Chinese economy) and an internal political crisis that has undermined investor confidence. Since
then, inflation has decreased significantly from 8.7% in 2016 to 3.7% in 2018, resulting in slower growth in cost
of food and non-alcoholic beverages, housing and transport (source: IMF). Inflation is forecast to grow at a 4.0%
CAGR during 2019-24 (source: IMF). It is a highly urbanised country, where 87% of the population lives in cities
_(source: World Bank). Brazilian unemployment rate was 12.3% in 2018, is projected to fall to 11.4% in 2019 and_
further fall to 10.2% in 2020 (source: IMF).

**_Grocery Retail – Key Trends_**

While hypermarkets have long been used as anchor outlets in shopping centers in Brazil, a growing number of
supermarkets and convenience stores are also opting for such locations. Shopping centers play a strong role in the
Brazilian consumer culture, being not only a place for shopping but also entertainment. By seeking mall
expansion, supermarket and convenience store players seek to take advantage of the high consumer traffic and
shared expenses associated with these areas.

Cash & carry is a strong format in Brazil, catering not only to smaller retailers, small consumer foodservice players
and other businesses, but also individual consumers. The channel has benefited from rising consumer price
sensitivity as a result of past volatility in consumer purchasing power in the country, with Brazilians increasingly
prioritising price over convenience.

Informal retailing is also widely popular in Brazil. Consumers are not only attracted by the lower prices, but also
by the convenience offered by informal retailing, with street hawkers and markets focused on high-traffic areas,
as well as high-traffic transportation hubs – mostly underground and over-ground trains.

2018 saw a significant increase in digitalization in Brazil, with the development of online delivery platforms,
online services such as music and film streaming, as well as online shopping. Brazilians can now pay for these
services via increasingly popular digital wallets. Some grocery retailers have also participated in the evolution of
this trend, with several initiatives such as in-store Wi-Fi, electronic purchasing and click-and-collect initiatives.

**_Grocery Retail – Overview of Key Formats from Euromonitor_**

In 2018, 59.0% of Brazilian grocery retail sales were accounted for by modern grocery as opposed to traditional
grocery. The share of modern grocery has increased at a rate of 1.5ppts per annum in the last 5 years (from 51.5%
in 2013), and the modern grocery retail sales are expected to grow at a rate of 3.6% per annum in the next 5 years.
Brazil has seen strong development of atacarejo (a hybrid of a supermarket/hypermarket and a cash and carry)
over the past years, with a 16.0% CAGR for the period 2013-18. Many consumers and businesses in Brazil make
little distinction between warehouse clubs (such as Sam’s Club, the only warehouse club brand operating in the
country) and atacarejo players. In Brazil, the leading atacarejo are Assaí (Casino), Atacadão (Carrefour), WalMart Brasil’s Maxxi and Makro, although there are also many independent operators in this channel.

**Colombia**

**_Macroeconomic and Demographic Overview_**

In 2018, the nominal GDP of Colombia amounted to COP 984,803 billion ($333 billion) (source: IMF). The IMF
ranked Colombia as the 4[th] largest economy in South America. The Colombian economy faced a growth slowdown
in recent years (2.1% GDP’s growth in 2016, and 1.4% in 2017), but it is now recovering with a growth of 2.7%
in real terms in 2018, and is projected to grow 3.5% in real terms in 2019, and at a CAGR of 3.7% between 201824 (source: IMF). Growth is projected to accelerate, led by continued monetary policy support, election-year
spending by sub-national governments, implementation of the 4G infrastructure agenda, and a positive impact of
recent tax policy changes on investment.

As of January 1, 2018, the population of Colombia amounted to 49.8 million people (source IMF). Colombian
population is expected to reach 52.8 million people by 2024, which implies a 1.0% CAGR between 2018-24
(source: IMF). 81% of the country’s population live in cities _(source: World Bank). The Colombian_
unemployment rate was 9.7% in 2018, is projected to remain stable at 9.7% in 2019 and fall to 9.5% in 2020
(source: IMF).

Inflation has been stable around its target, falling close to 3.0% for the first time in four years. Two-year inflation
expectations remain anchored near the central bank’s inflation target. Inflation is forecast to grow at 3.1% per
annum for 2019-24 (source: IMF).

**_Grocery Retail – Key Trends_**

The improvement of economic conditions, the upbeat expectations of both traders and consumers, as well as
declining uncertainty regarding the socio-political climate after the presidential elections in 2018, resulted in
increased consumption expenditure by locals. In 2018, retailing in Colombia showed a progressive outlook in
terms of consumption by adapting to tax changes, rising prices, and adjustments in households that changed
consumers’ purchasing behaviour, allowing them to regain confidence in acquiring a greater number of durable
goods. Combined with the strengthening of the relation to price, quality and benefits in their shopping experiences,

Consumers can easily access retailers in Colombia when they are located near their homes or workplaces, which

The arrival of discounters in Colombia has decreased the popularity of convenience stores, which are seen as more

well to consumers’ needs and benefited from slowing household consumption, as well as decreasing brand loyalty.

Cash & Carry is in an early development stage in Colombia and, although it started as a central market for the

in 2016 (144 stores by the end of 2018), aiming to attract those who buy high product volumes to sell them on or
process. These two important players plan to open outlets throughout the country.

**Argentina**

**_Macroeconomic and Demographic Overview_**

In 2018, the nominal GDP of Argentina amounted to Argentine peso 14,567 billion ($518 billion) (source: IMF).

The strong peso depreciation around mid-2018 severely fuelled inflation (34.3% of inflation in 2018 and 43.7%
of inflation forecast for 2019 according to the IMF), reducing disposable income and investor confidence.
Argentina is currently running out of hard currency while grappling with high inflation and economic contraction.
The IMF stepped in to assist Argentina with a $44 billion funding arrangement. On September 1[st], 2019, Argentina
imposed currency controls in an attempt to stabilise markets. As such, firms will have to seek central bank

measures will apply until the end of 2019.

population is expected to reach 47.6 million by 2024, which implies a 1.1% CAGR between 2018-24 (source:

was 9.2% in 2018, is projected to increase to 9.9% in 2019 and be stable at 9.9% in 2020 (source: IMF).

**BUSINESS**

**Overview**

We are a leading major multi-format, multi-banner and multi-channel retailer with over 120 years of history,
offering a diverse range of products and services to customers primarily located in France and, through our
interests in Grupo Éxito and GPA, in Latin America. We offer both brand-name and private label food and
consumer products through traditional retail stores as well as e-commerce websites and apps. We also provide
business-to-business and business-to-consumer services through our portfolio of complementary lines of business.

Our retail banners operate under formats which aim to adapt to current consumer trends and needs across the
various geographies in which we operate. Our premium retail format offers many innovative services and a highquality shopping experience. Our convenience retail format is adapted to both city centers and rural areas, offering
everyday basics to meet the expectations of customers searching for quality, authenticity and service. Our
hypermarket, cash & carry and discount retail formats offer a wide range of quality products at affordable prices.
We believe most of our banners enjoy leading market positions in most of our markets.

We have a strong focus on innovation and have developed an omni-channel offering that we believe has favorably
positioned us to respond to consumer trends. We have developed partnerships with innovators such as Amazon
and Ocado in order to provide best-in-class grocery delivery services in France. Our pure-play e-commerce
platform, Cdiscount, is the second largest e-tailer in France by number of unique monthly visitors (“UMV”), and
has allowed us to offer a range of adjacent business-to-consumer and business-to-business services. In France,
Brazil and Colombia, our brick-and-mortar retail banners benefit from mobile applications and other e-commerce
functionality that allow us to provide targeted promotions to our customers and give our customers the flexibility
to shop how they want, when they want.

In addition to our retail operations, we have also developed a number of other complementary lines of business
that allow us to leverage our know-how while monetizing our asset base. These businesses include real estate
development and shopping center management, consumer finance, solar energy and energy efficiency solutions
via GreenYellow and, in France specifically, digital advertising and data center solutions via 3W.relevanC and
ScaleMax, respectively.

We operate primarily in France and, through our interests in GPA and Grupo Éxito, in Latin America, although
through Cdiscount and a number of international affiliates, we provide products and services to customers in other
international markets.

For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, without giving effect to the impact of IFRS 16, we generated €36,659
million in net sales and €1,757 million in EBITDA and our France Retail segment recorded net sales of €18,796
million and EBITDA of €903 million. Our E-commerce segment recorded net sales of €1,979 million and
EBITDA of €28 million for the same period.

**History**

Our origins date back to 1898, when Geoffroy Guichard created Société des Magasins du Casino and opened the
first store in Veauche, in central France. In 1901, we created France’s first private label. Our network quickly
expanded in the Saint-Étienne region, around Clermont-Ferrand and on the Côte d’Azur. By 1939, we managed
nine warehouses, 20 production plants and 2,500 retail outlets.

From the 1950s onwards, we began to diversify our formats and activities. We successively opened our first selfservice store, our first Casino supermarket and our first Géant hypermarket before creating the Casino cafeterias.

Starting in the 1980s, in response to an increasingly competitive retail environment, we began to strengthen our
operations in France and refocus on our core business as a retailer. Mr. Jean-Charles Naouri became our majority
shareholder in 1991. In 1992, we acquired Rallye’s hypermarket, supermarket and cafeteria retail activities. In
1997, we acquired a stake in Monoprix-Prisunic and took control of the Franprix-Leader Price banners.

As the year 2000 approached, we were one of France’s leading retailers and were poised to expand our
international operations. Between 1998 and 2002, we acquired a number of retailers based in Latin America,
Southeast Asia and the Indian Ocean. Notably, in 1999, we acquired minority stakes in the Colombian Grupo
Éxito and Brazilian GPA companies. In France, we consolidated our positioning in convenience and discount
formats. In 2000, we acquired a stake in Cdiscount, an online retailer. We simultaneously developed
complementary businesses with the creation of Banque Casino in 2001. In 2005, Mr. Jean-Charles Naouri became
our Chief Executive Officer. That same year, our shopping center properties in France were spun off through the
creation and initial public offering of the Mercialys property company, in which we continue to hold 25% of
voting rights today.

152


-----

Over the following decade, we decided to refocus our portfolio of international operations and concentrate our
development efforts on markets where we were poised to hold leading positions. With this strategy in mind, we
strengthened our positions in France and Latin America by becoming the majority shareholder of Grupo Éxito in
2007 and of GPA in 2012 and by gaining exclusive control of the Monoprix group in 2013. At the same time, we
disposed of certain activities, such as through the sales of our operations in the Netherlands, Poland, Taiwan,
Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.

In France, we are consolidating our position in leading formats and entering into partnerships with key players in
our field to strengthen our omni-channel strategy, particularly in the food segment. For example, in 2017 and
2018, we formed partnerships with Ocado and Amazon, respectively, for next-day and same-day express delivery.
In 2018, Monoprix acquired online fashion and personal goods retailer Sarenza, through which we intend to
expand our e-commerce channel.

In parallel, we have developed new business lines that leverage our operational expertise and monetize our asset
base. For example, in 2009, we founded GreenYellow, a solar power generation and energy efficiency company.
GreenYellow has since grown into a leader in the provision of solar energy to small and medium enterprises in
France. In 2018, we further expanded GreenYellow’s operational flexibility by selling a minority stake in the
company to Bpifrance and Tikehau Capital.

As we continue to reinforce our positioning in key markets and evaluate our asset portfolio, we have implemented
further disposals of assets that no longer align with our strategic positioning, including our current asset disposal
plan, which is targeted at €2.5 billion, and in respect of which we have already signed agreements for disposals
totaling €2.1 billion. Disposals under this plan have so far included, among others, the sale of 15% of the share
capital of Mercialys through an equity swap for €213 million, the €150 million GreenYellow capital increase
subscribed by Tikehau Capital and Bpifrance and the sale and leaseback of Monoprix real estate assets for €742
million. We have also entered into sale and leaseback transactions with funds managed by Fortress Investment
Group and Apollo Global Management for certain groups of our stores.

In addition to this €2.5 billion disposal plan, we announced in August 2019 a new €2.0 billion disposal plan in
France relating to further non-strategic real estate and other assets that we have identified, which we expect to
complete by the end of the first quarter of 2021 (together with the €2.5 billion disposal plan described above, the
“Asset Disposal Plan”). Such additional disposals will be focused on increasing our exposure to better-performing
formats (such as, e.g., e-commerce and premium and convenience stores) and demographically favorable regions
in France (such as, e.g., the Île-de-France, Rhône-Alpes and Provence-Alpes-Côte d’Azur regions).

We regularly evaluate opportunities for, and may engage in, significant disposals in the future in addition to the
Asset Disposal Plan.

In 2019, we have the objective to increase the profitability of our retail business in France by attempting to improve
purchasing conditions, reduce our cost base, sell or close loss-making stores and encourage the development of
new businesses. We aim to further deleverage in France. In addition to the Asset Disposal Plans and the Rocade
Plan, we also have the objective to improve our generation of free cash flow before interest and dividends in
France by implementing action plans to reduce our inventories and, as a result, improve our working capital and
keep our capital expenditures under strict control. We also intend to improve the profitability of Cdiscount, mainly
through attempting to develop the marketplace, which generally exhibits higher margins than other Cdiscount
sales. Finally, GPA and Grupo Éxito also aim to improve their profitability in 2019.

**Our Competitive Strengths**

**_Leading position in the French food retail market through structurally well-positioned formats and offers_**
**_aligned with new consumer trends_**

We believe that we are poised to take advantage of a number of favorable consumer trends in French food retail
as an already established market leader positioned in dynamic geographic areas and rapidly growing market
segments.

We hold leading positions in the French food retail market, the largest grocery retail market in Western Europe in
terms of retail sales value (“RSV”) (based on partial-year information at a fixed euro exchange rate retail value
measured by retail selling price, excluding sales tax), according to Euromonitor International. The RSV of the
French grocery retail market (in nominal terms and applying a constant 2018 exchange rate) has consistently
grown every year since 2014, and is projected to grow at a CAGR of 2.2% between 2018 and 2023. The graph
below shows RSV growth in the RSV of the French grocery retail market from 2014 to 2018, the RSV and its

According to Euromonitor International, we are the fifth largest food retailer in France, with a market share of

by retail selling price, excluding sales tax). As of June 30, 2019, we had a network of 8,640 stores in France within
a diversified portfolio of 12 complementary banners, each with different strategies to meet changing consumer
expectations. Our portfolio of banners is particularly focused on convenience and premium formats, which
accounted for over 60% of our net sales for the year ended December 31, 2018 and address growing demand from
French consumers. We are a leading urban convenience food retailer in France, with a network of 6,801 premium
and convenience stores that have a distinct urban focus. Approximately 63% of our France Retail net sales for the
year ended December 31, 2018 were generated in three of the fastest growing regions of France – the Ile-deFrance, Rhône-Alpes and Provence-Alpes-Côte d’Azur regions – whose population accounted for 35.7% of the
total French population and approximately 48% of France’s GDP growth in 2018. The map below shows our net
sales in each of these key regions as of December 31, 2018.

In addition, we are the major French food retailer with the smallest exposure to the declining hypermarket format
(which accounted for 25% of our France Retail net sales in 2018). Finally, according to a third-party market
analysis, we were also the second largest retailer of organic products, with approximately €1.0 billion in net sales
from organic products in 2018, which represented growth of 16% over the prior year.
