We believe that the French food retail market is characterized by a number of demographic characteristics that
are favorable for food retailers like our Group. For example, according to the IMF, the French population has
grown at a CAGR of 0.3% from 64.0 million people in 2014 to 64.7 million people in 2018, and population growth
is expected to accelerate to a CAGR of 0.5%, reaching to 66.5 million people by 2024, which necessarily means
an increase in the consumer base for food. Moreover, according to the World Bank, approximately 80% of
France’s inhabitants in 2018 lived in urban areas, favoring retailers that have a particular concentration in towns
and cities. As of December 31, 2018, approximately 53% of our stores in France were located in urban areas and
approximately 1,400 stores (including franchise and affiliate stores) operated in the Paris region alone. In addition,
according to the INSEE, approximately 33% of the French population is older than 55 years old. This segment of
the population drives an estimated 86% of food retail growth and buys an estimated 57% of fresh products, the
offer of which is a key differentiating factor among food retailers and a key source of profitability. Growth in the
French food retail market is moderate, but marked by a strong polarization of format performance, with
convenience stores expected to enjoy growth in net sales of 1.6%, supermarket net sales growth expected to be
flat and hypermarket net sales expected to decline by 1.5% in 2019. In light of our strong focus on the convenience
and premium formats and our low exposure to the hypermarket format, we expect to benefit disproportionately
from the trends favoring supermarkets and convenience formats when compared with our main competitors.

The French food retail market is also marked by consumer trends that we believe will be beneficial for our Group.
For example, we believe that food retail e-commerce has the potential to grow significantly in France due to its
current low level of penetration despite the high overall population of internet users in France. According to
information from Hootsuite, approximately 88% of the French population used the internet in 2018, with 75%
using the internet on their mobile devices and 58% active on social media. While online sales of food products
are typically lower than those of non-food products, our e-commerce food sales in France, excluding Cdiscount,

155


-----

but including sales through our partnership with Amazon, amounted to €315 million in 2018. We believe this
provides us with a significant food retail e-commerce growth opportunity. Furthermore, consumers are
increasingly leaning toward high-quality, organic goods, leading to stronger emphasis on the premium end of the
market and a decline in the mass market segment. We believe this is favorable for retailers like us, with a diverse
range of banners and an already strong position in sales of organic products. We are the only large food retailer
in France with a large-scale banner dedicated to organic products, Naturalia.

We believe that these market trends have led to the emergence of new competitors, such as physical retailers Bio
c’Bon, Biocoop and La Vie Claire in the organic retail space, Grand Frais in the fresh produce space and Action
in the discount segment; online generalist retailers like Amazon and pure players such as Nespresso and Zooplus;
business-to-consumer technology platforms that are last-mile competitors such as Deliveroo, Uber Eats, Frichti
and Glovo. However, we also believe that our product offering and partnerships with online retailers and delivery
services will help us answer customers’ needs and successfully face such competition.

**_Best-in-class omni-channel strategy: pioneer of food e-commerce and one of the leading non-food e-tailers_**

We are present in three e-commerce retail segments in France: food retail, through the development of our omnichannel strategy, household goods, through Cdiscount, and fashion and other personal goods, through the recent
acquisition of Sarenza by Monoprix.

E-commerce activity is an important area of development for our business, especially in light of market trends
that indicate that consumers will make an increasing share of their purchases online. Our online sales for the six
months ended June 30, 2019 in France under our retail banners, together with Cdiscount’s gross merchandise
value, grew by 10.2% as compared to the same period in 2018. Food e-commerce gross sales, including
Cdiscount’s sale volume, grew by 27.5% in the first half of 2019 as compared to the first half of 2017. We
generated €187 million in net sales under our banners in food e-commerce during the six months ended June 30,
2019, and Cdiscount’s gross merchandise volume (“GMV”) was €1.75 billion over the same time period.

We were a first-mover in French food retail e-commerce through home delivery service partnerships that we
formed with Amazon and Ocado. Through our partnership with Amazon, Amazon Prime customers are offered
express two-hour delivery of Monoprix, Casino and Naturalia products in Paris and 35 neighboring cities. We
intend to expand the geographic area covered by this service to other major French cities by 2020. Through our
exclusive partnership with Ocado in France, we expect Monoprix to benefit by 2020 from a front-to-back online,
solution with the ability to provide customers with next-day delivery of 50,000 items with low preparation and
delivery costs, due in part to the construction of an automated warehouse in the Paris region.

We have further enhanced our brick and mortar French food retail operations with a number of digital initiatives.
For example, each of our principal French retail banners has a mobile application enabling customers to do their
shopping or monitor their loyalty card online. As of December 31, 2018, our banners’ applications have been
downloaded approximately 10 million times. Users of our Casino Max app generated approximately 13% of our
hypermarket and supermarket net sales for the six months ended June 30, 2019. Furthermore, we have
implemented a number of digital solutions to enhance our customers’ shopping experience, such as permitting
mobile payments, digital receipts, and scan and go solutions through the Monoprix and Casino Max mobile apps.
Our banners’ apps also allow individual marketing capabilities, with personalized, targeted coupons and discounts,
which we believe is a key distinguishing factor from most of our competitors.

Cdiscount, our pure-play e-commerce platform, is the second-largest e-tailer in France by number of unique
monthly visitors, with an average of 19.6 million monthly unique visitors to its website during the second quarter
of 2019, based on a market study by Médiamétrie. In 2018, the difference in market share based on retail sales
value excluding sales tax between Amazon, the e-tailer with the largest share of the non-food products ecommerce market in France, and Cdiscount, the e-tailer with the second-largest share of the non-food products ecommerce market non-food e-tailer in France, is the smallest when compared to the difference between Amazon
and other European non-food e-tailers’ market share in their home markets. Cdiscount sold €3.6 billion in GMV
of products and services during the year ended December 31, 2018, of which 34% was sold by third-party
merchants through Cdiscount’s marketplace platform. The GMV contribution from products and services sold
through the Cdiscount marketplace has increased over recent years, from 32% of total GMV in 2017 to 34% in
2018 and 40% during the three months ended June 30, 2019. Cdiscount’s online marketplace is the most profitable
portion of its operations because Cdiscount is able to generate net sales through the commissions it receives from
marketplace sellers with limited associated operating costs or working capital investments. We aim to continue to
expand the share of GMV represented by the Cdiscount marketplace in the coming years.

We believe Cdiscount benefits from a strong competitive advantage through its nine million active customers and
its successful Cdiscount à Volonté loyalty program, through which over two million members have the ability to
have free one-day delivery of more than 280,000 items, with on-demand delivery within 30-minute time slots in

Paris, as well as unlimited online access to 200 magazines. The delivery offerings through Cdiscount à Volonté
are made possible by our superior logistics infrastructure, which is capable of handling both heavy and small
products.

We have been able to leverage the Cdiscount platform to offer adjacent business-to-customer services, such as
discount travel, event ticketing, discount energy (through a partnership with GreenYellow), Coup de Pouce
consumer finance loans through its partnership with Banque Casino and insurance. We have also been able to
offer business-to-business services, including fulfilment services to our marketplace vendors, which accounted
for approximately 21% of Cdiscount’s marketplace GMV in 2018, and additional services, such as advertising
and visibility-boosting services. We intend to further develop and expand such service offerings in the future.

Finally, we have been able to roll-out Cdiscount’s reach beyond France to 25 countries in Europe, and have
established partnerships with 45 online European marketplaces as of September 2019. We intend to further expand
Cdiscount’s international operations in the future, such as through initiatives like International Marketplace
Network, our recent alliance with three online marketplaces – in each of Germany, Italy and Romania – that allows
marketplace vendors in each geographic region to access the wider consumer market of all four websites.

Our e-commerce ambitions are not limited to our sales of food products and Cdiscount alone. For example, in
2018, Monoprix acquired Sarenza, a website dedicated to the sale of shoes, fashion and other personal goods.
Monoprix intends to integrate and develop Sarenza as a key online player in the personal goods retail sector in
France.

**_Asset-light model and further acceleration in new businesses_**

In recent years, we have focused on developing an asset-light business model in France through the active
management of our real estate portfolio and encouraging the development of a franchisee network in stores across
our various French banners. We also have developed new lines of business, including solar energy, data analysis
for digital advertising and data centers, that take advantage of our physical footprint and accumulated know-how
from running a major retail group.

We believe that there is limited upside potential from the valuation of commercial real estate in France, and have
undertaken significant disposals of our real estate portfolio, including through entering into sale and leaseback
transactions. As of December 31, 2018, the market value of our owned real estate portfolio in France was estimated
to be approximately €2.6 billion, including transfer duties and excluding our share of property held by Mercialys,
a property development business in which we hold 25% of the voting rights. During 2019, we have sold, or entered
into agreements to sell, real estate assets for a total sales price of €750 million (excluding transfer duties). We
believe these disposals have strengthened our balance sheet, as we anticipate limited or no upside on the valuation
of commercial real estate assets in France, while giving us the operational flexibility to compete in a dynamic
competitive environment.

As for the real estate that we have retained, we have endeavored to upgrade our properties, including our Casino
Supermarkets and Monoprix stores, to improve customers’ shopping experience and boost sales. We have further
reduced average selling area in our hypermarkets by 11% from 2015, through space optimization and
specialization on premises, such as transforming selling or stocking areas into additional retail areas in shopping
centers that are adjacent to our hypermarkets and can be leased to third parties. As a result, based on information
from LSA Conso, the average selling area of our hypermarkets was 6,950 square meters as of December 31, 2018,
compared with 9,184 square meters for Carrefour hypermarkets and 10,460 square meters for Auchan
hypermarkets. We expect that hypermarket sales will represent an increasingly smaller proportion of our France
total gross sales in the coming years.

We have also encouraged the development of our franchisee network as a means of transitioning to an asset-light
model with lower capital expenditures. Growth in our franchisee network has also had a positive impact on our
France Retail sales: we estimate that new franchisees (including the Quattrucci family, whose stores generated
over €300 million in gross sales in 2017, before such stores were part of our Group) joining our network of French
retail stores in 2018.

**_Proactive portfolio management to seize market opportunities and create value_**

We actively manage our businesses, seeking disposal and acquisition opportunities where we believe we can best
derive value for our companies. We also actively seek out and enter into partnerships with third parties in order
to better serve our customers and leverage market trends.

Our Group has historically been able to benefit from our acquisitions of banners with successful formats and name
recognition in markets characterized by favorable trends. Our Group was built through a series of key acquisitions
and combinations, including our acquisition of a stake in Monoprix in 1997, the entirety of which we purchased
in July 2013, the purchase of a majority interest in Franprix and Leader Price in 1997, our acquisition of a stake
in Grupo Éxito in 1999 (in which we acquired a further stake in 2007), our investment in CBD in 1999, our
acquisition of Naturalia in 2008 and, most recently, our purchase of Sarenza in 2018.

We also have a proven history of successfully monetizing our assets through the pursuit of opportunistic disposals.
For example, in 2016, we successfully completed a disposal plan of approximately €4.0 billion through the
disposals of our businesses in Thailand and Vietnam, with significant capital gains associated with these
transactions. In June 2018, following a review of our business portfolio, we announced the launch of an asset
disposal plan covering non-core assets, in particular real estate assets, for a value of €1.5 billion to be completed
by the end of 2019. This plan complemented our already planned disposal of Via Varejo, a Brazilian appliance
retailer, the sale of which was completed in June 2019. We successfully completed the entire plan ahead of
schedule in January 2019, primarily through the execution of sale and leaseback agreements with respect to certain
of our stores’ real estate and the sale of a 15% stake in Mercialys, a commercial real estate management business
in which we have kept a 25% minority stake. We therefore decided to increase the size of the plan to a targeted

€2.5 billion, the Asset Disposal Plan, with the additional €1.0 billion of disposals due to be completed by the first
quarter of 2020. Of this €2.5 billion amount, agreements in respect of disposals of approximately €2.1 billion have
been signed to date, of which €1.8 billion have been completed following the closing of the sale of certain real
estate assets to Apollo Global Management, Inc. on October 17, 2019 and €0.3 billion have been signed and are
to be completed. We subsequently completed a strategic review of our assets in France and announced on August
20, 2019 that we would carry out a second phase of our Asset Disposal Plan for a target amount of €2.0 billion (in
addition to the existing €2.5 billion plan described above) to be raised by the end of the first quarter of 2021 in
order to accelerate the completion of our strategic focus on the best performing formats and most promising
geographic markets. In addition to the Asset Disposal Plan, we have also begun implementing the Rocade Plan,

Finally, we have sought and intend to continue seeking out partnerships with third parties to expand the products

between our Group and Amazon in France, which began in March 2018, pursuant to which Amazon Prime

**_High-growth operations in attractive Latin American markets_**

Through our interests in GPA and Grupo Éxito, we have a highly developed network of retail banners in a number
of attractive formats in Brazil, Colombia, Argentina and Uruguay.

The Latin American business benefits from attractive and fast-growing markets with strong underlying
macroeconomic trends, including a growing population of over 300 million, which is favorable for food retailers.
As an established player in these markets, we believe we stand to benefit from the favorable demographics of
these countries, combined with their improving economies.

Despite a high rate of urbanization, the penetration rate of modern grocery stores in these markets remains
relatively low. As a result of this, as well as the rapid development in these countries of digitalization and
urbanization rates, we expect rapid structural changes in the region. In this context, we believe that retail groups
like ours with extensive digital know-how and omni-channel capabilities are especially well-positioned to benefit
from growth in Latin America, where digital media has had an extensive impact.

In Brazil, GPA was the largest player in grocery retail and one of the largest players in the cash & carry market
in 2018, with net sales of €11,416 million for the year ended December 31, 2018 and €5,914 million for the six

2018. As of June 30, 2019, GPA had a network of 1,059 stores throughout the country. GPA is active across
various formats, channels and regions of Brazil.

**_Extensive record of financial achievements in France_**

We have a history of successfully executing plans to improve our France Retail financial performance and
financial position. Our France Retail trading profit, excluding property development activities, has increased at a
CAGR of approximately 22% from 2014 through 2018, and its trading profit margin, calculated as a percentage
of net sales, has increased by 0.4 percentage points per year over the same time period. Our France Retail same
store net sales have also generally evolved favorably since 2014.

We have been able to reduce our combined France Retail and E-commerce net debt over the past years, from €7.1
billion as of December 31, 2014 to €2.9 billion as of December 31, 2018. We believe that a significant part of this
success is due to our ability to carry out targeted asset disposals through our various disposal plans as described
above. We believe that our successful track record in executing these opportunistic disposals has not only
generated significant value through the monetization of our asset base, but has also enabled us to focus our
business model in France on a core set of activities adapted to the needs of today’s consumers.

We intend to carry out a number of initiatives to improve our France Retail free cash flow generation to support
further reductions in our net debt. For further detail on our financial strategy, see “—Our Strategies—Continue
_transformation into a less capital-intensive business model with a strong focus on improving profitability and_
_cash flow generation and proactive deleveraging in France”._

**_Highly experienced management team to drive sustainable profitable growth_**

We benefit from the expertise of a senior management team that has significant experience in grocery retail and
corporate finance. Jean-Charles Naouri, the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of CGP since 2005, acquired
our indirect majority shareholder Rallye, itself a former chain of supermarkets, in 1991, and implemented its
merger with Casino in 1992. Mr. Naouri holds degrees from the École Normale Supérieure and the École
Nationale d’Administration and has a doctorate from Harvard University. We also benefit from the services of
our talented team of divisional managers, who more closely oversee the day-to-day operations of our retail banners
and our purchasing functions. Each draws upon significant experience in the retail sector and most of them have
been with our Group for many years.

**Our Strategies**

**_Accelerate leadership in convenience, organic and premium formats in France_**

We intend to capitalize on French consumer trends by further focusing on and developing our well positioned
formats and product range. We aim to adjust our mix of formats to best position our business for long-term growth.
We also aim to continue to expand our premium and convenience stores, formats which we believe will continue
to be particularly promising over the medium term, with the goal of opening 300 new stores by 2021. In particular,
to take advantage of consumers’ increased preference for organic products, we intend to develop our organic
product offering in each of our banners and speed up the expansion of our Naturalia stores. Through this and the
promotion of organic products through our digital distribution channels, including our partnership with Amazon
Prime, we believe that our net sales of organic products will continue to increase over the next few years.
Moreover, we plan to further reduce our exposure to the hypermarket format from its 21% share of France total
gross sales under banner in 2018, by focusing on our most profitable locations. With respect to the remainder of
the hypermarket portfolio, we expect to focus on initiatives to maximize real estate efficiency and area utilization.

We also plan to enhance our existing store network in France to meet changes in consumers’ tastes and needs. We
intend to continue developing new concepts and services in our stores, such as the Franprix Noé concept, which

161


-----

consists of lifestyle stores focusing on organic, healthy and fair-trade products, Le Drugstore Parisien, a
partnership with L’Oréal Paris, and Le 4 Casino, a phygital store with several digital innovations. Most recently,
we have launched a pilot store in Paris for our newest concept, Darwin, a Franprix store offering consumers a host
of conveniences, including full kitchen access, a large seating and dining area and the ability to shop for products
from other brands, such as Cdiscount and home goods retailer Hema, in store. We also intend to provide catering
services across our various banners, such as in-store salad bars and snack areas. Finally, we intend to expand our
network of autonomous Monoprix, Franprix and Casino supermarkets in order to improve customer service and
increase net sales from expanded opening hours.

**_Continue to strengthen our leadership in digital and omni-channel initiatives in France and pursue_**
**_innovations in all parts of our business_**

Innovation and digital transformations are two major axes of our development strategy. We intend to leverage
favorable consumer trends and our strong experience in digital and omni-channel offerings by increasing our focus
on efforts to expand our e-commerce activities in food retail, further developing our Cdiscount business, growing
our digital customer relationships and rolling out further innovative concepts and solutions.

Leveraging on the full deployment of our partnership with Ocado to develop a fully automated warehouse and
with the expansion of the delivery area through which Amazon Prime customers can order Monoprix, Casino and
Naturalia products, we aim to generate significant food e-commerce sales in the near- to medium-term.

In our pure-play e-commerce business, we intend to increase Cdiscount’s GMV through the further development
of our marketplace, which we expect will account for an increasing share of Cdiscount’s net sales in the coming
years. We also intend to further expand Cdiscount’s business-to-business and business-to-customer services
offering within France, and to more generally expand Cdiscount’s operations to other European countries through
direct delivery to countries neighboring France and the further development of partnerships with marketplaces
abroad.

Finally, we aim to reinforce our digital customer relationships through the increased penetration of our banners’
mobile applications. We also plan to expand Scan & Go capabilities to all of our stores by 2021.

In October 2018, we launched Le 4 Casino, the first store in France without a traditional cashier, the technology
of which was deployed over 146 stores (with 188 stores targeted by the end of 2019), allowing for 24/7 store
operation without the presence of cashiers. In March 2019, we opened a logistics innovation lab in the Géant
hypermarket in Pessac, France, where 15 technology solutions are currently being tested in partnership with the
most innovative startups in the field.

These innovative solutions were made possible with the launch of Maxit, a “digital factory” covering our various
banners, employing 40 experts in the digital field and focusing on technology innovation, such as through the
development of the Casino Max, Leader Price and Vindémia mobile applications. Since their launch, these
applications have generated traffic of more than 5 million views per month. Maxit regularly liaises with startups
to develop projects to improve the customer experience.

In addition, Cdiscount runs dozens of tests with startups each year to develop innovative solutions. For instance,
in July, Cdiscount signed a partnership with FACIL’iti to adapt its website for people with disabilities.

Our innovation initiatives also include new activities with strong growth potential, such as the deployment of
electrical vehicle charging stations in our parking lots or ScaleMax, a cloud computing solution developed in our
warehouses and store stocking areas. Each of these projects, in line with our asset-light strategy, have been
developed in exclusive or limited partnerships with the most advanced startups, franchisees with long-standing
relationships with us or with other external specialist teams.

**_Continue transformation into a less capital-intensive business model with a strong focus on improving_**
**_profitability and cash flow generation and proactive deleveraging in France_**

We have launched a number of initiatives to achieve improvements in several financial metrics in France,
including our costs of operations, trading profit, capital expenditures, net debt and working capital requirements.

We intend to optimize head office expenses at the corporate level and at the level of each of our banners and
reduce store costs, continue to negotiate better purchasing conditions for goods, realize logistics synergies through
unifying the logistics serving our Casino, Franprix and Leader Price banners and close or dispose of loss-making
stores through our Rocade Plan in order to save costs. During the first half of 2019, we have already made
significant progress toward our cost savings goals. We have already achieved significant run-rate savings,
including approximately €60 million in cost savings through head office and store costs reductions of
approximately €29 million, purchasing savings of approximately €16 million and logistics synergies of
approximately €15 million, each on a full-year basis. In addition, through our progress on the Rocade Plan, we
disposed of 15 hypermarkets, 13 supermarkets and 11 Leader Price stores and closed a further 56 stores across
our various French banners, leading to a positive impact on trading profit that we estimate would be approximately
€52 million on a full-year basis. We have also disposed of eight franchised supermarkets and nine franchised
Leader Price stores and have closed 62 franchised stores, leading to an estimated positive impact of approximately
€27 million in trading profit for the franchisees on a full-year basis, with an expected €13 million of normalized

164


-----

net income for our Group. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to our Business and Industry—We may not be able
_to implement our business strategy”._

We also seek to improve our France Retail trading profit through improvements in format mix and an emphasis
on organic and fresh food products, through developing retail-adjacent sources of revenue from our new
businesses GreenYellow, 3W.relevanC and Scale Max, and through the continued disposal of loss-making stores.

We are continuing to focus our retail gross capital expenditures on initiatives that we believe will have a favorable
impact on the development of our business, with a targeted level of approximately €350 million per year from
2019 through 2021. We believe this will include investments in the further digitalization of our retail activities,
such as the recent launch of the Leader Price mobile application, the development of e-commerce initiatives such
as our partnerships with Ocado and Amazon. We believe this level of capital expenditure is adequate after years
of significant investment in revamping our banners and implementing new concepts, such as the Mandarine
concept in Franprix stores, intended to transform them into friendly, practical and pleasant stores. In addition, the
development of franchises has reduced our capital expenditure requirements, as franchisees finance the capital
expenditures for the stores that they operate.

We aim to reduce our year-end net debt through continuing our favorable track record of deleveraging in France.
We intend to achieve this goal through improving our free cash flow generation, continuing the Rocade Plan,
pursuing our €4.5 billion Asset Disposal Plan and the absence of dividend payments until the end of 2020. We
believe we have made significant progress on these initiatives already, having already signed approximately €2.1
billion of asset disposals out of the announced €4.5 billion, of which transactions approximately €1.8 billion have
closed. As of July 24, 2019, we had also signed agreements for the disposal of integrated stores for an aggregate
sales price of €233 million.

Finally, we aim to improve our working capital requirements, primarily through reducing inventories. We aim to
reduce inventories through a number of different initiatives, including ceasing to offer products which are cashconsuming, extending logistics pooling between our banners, which previously had been limited to frozen goods,
to a wider range of products and closer tracking through advanced digital inventories solutions. We have already
demonstrated improvement in this respect, having generated a cash inflow from changes in inventories during the
twelve months ended June 30, 2019 of €105 million, which is an improvement on our performance in the twelve
months ended June 30, 2018.

In the context of such performance and strategic positioning initiatives, we have set ourselves a target of reducing
our France Retail net debt to €1.5 billion on a sustainable basis.

**Our Businesses**

Our business comprises both retail and non-retail operations. Primarily, we operate as a retailer, offering a wide
range of products and services in two principal geographic areas, France and Latin America, as well as through
our pure e-commerce platform (primarily in France), Cdiscount. Our products are offered through a diverse
portfolio of strategic banners and distribution channels aimed at providing our customers with a seamless multichannel shopping experience tailored to their preferences. In addition to our retail businesses, we also operate a
number of other non-retail lines of business, principally in the French and, through GPA and Grupo Éxito, Latin
American markets, that allow us to monetize some of our core assets. Our non-retail businesses operate in various
industry sectors that align with and complement our retail activities, such as solar energy, data monetization, real
estate development and management and consumer finance. Certain of our non-retail businesses are established
as joint ventures with key strategic local partners.

**_Our Retail Businesses_**

We operate retail businesses through both brick-and-mortar retail outlets and via online sales. Our operations are
established in two balanced and structured geographic regions: France and Latin America. We are generally
focused on selective international development and on high potential markets, such as Brazil and Colombia, where
GPA and Grupo Éxito hold co-leadership and leadership positions, respectively.

Our physical retail businesses operate under several banners, each of which has a distinct format. The principal
formats of our retail stores include:

165


-----

  - _supermarkets, which are large self-service stores that primarily sell food products;_

  - _convenience stores, which are small stores that typically carry everyday essential food and non-food_
products and are generally located in city and town centers;

  - _premium stores, which cater to an urban clientele, offering food products with a large proportion of fresh,_
organic options and service counters and superior quality non-food products;

  - _hypermarkets, which are stores with very large surface areas that offer a wide range of food and non-_
food goods under a single roof, typically located in suburbs and other locations outside of city centers;

  - _discount stores, which are supermarkets and convenience stores that cater to a price-sensitive clientele;_
and

  - _cash & carry stores, which offer goods on a self-service wholesale basis to customers._

As a modern major retailer operating in competitive markets, we are also focused on developing our multi-channel
pioneering position by leveraging our deep local roots to establish ourselves as a leader in the e-commerce market.
From Cdiscount’s leadership model in France, to the specific digital strategies of our banners and key partnerships
with international leaders in technology and logistics, we are committed to adapting to our customers’ changing
preferences in the global multi-channel space.

As of December 31, 2018, 7,012 stores in our network were operated by franchisees. We have franchise contracts
pursuant to which a franchisee pays a fee to license the rights to a banner, receives a fixed allowance from us to
set up the store, and then mostly purchases merchandise for sale through our central purchasing agency, on which
we earn a margin. In addition, some joint ventures have been set up between us and a master franchisee that in
turn owns one or more franchised stores.

Through franchises, we can expand our store network while pursuing our asset-light strategy. Franchising allows
us to maintain net sales while minimizing cost outlays. Through franchise contracts, we recognize net sales on the
goods we sell our franchisees through our central purchasing agency. On the other hand, overhead costs like leases
and personnel costs, as well as capital expenditures, are shared or limited. For joint venture franchises, we either
fully consolidate or recognize our share of the net income of such stores.

As part of our international strategy, we enter into partnerships in markets in which we are not present, either
through licensing our banners to affiliates in international markets or through private-label product supply
agreements. In addition, we have a number of supply agreements in place whereby we provide private-label
products to leading local retailers in various international markets. We believe that these brands can be particularly
popular with consumers, as they represent a sought-after French lifestyle.

_France_

Our France Retail operations, which include both our French food retail and non-retail businesses, are
concentrated in France, the historical birthplace of Casino Group, where we are a leading retailer. For the twelve
months ended June 30, 2019, our France Retail segment recorded net sales of €18,796 million and EBITDA of
€903 million (without giving effect to the impact of IFRS 16). 37.4% of our net sales for the twelve months ended
June 30, 2019 was generated by hypermarkets and hard discount stores, 62.6% was generated by supermarkets,
convenience stores and premium banners.

_Retail Businesses_

Our French retail businesses serve customers through a network of 8,640 stores as of June 30, 2019. We conduct
our retail businesses within the France Retail segment under several banners, each of which offers a key range of
products that are constantly evolving to anticipate new modes of consumption and adapt to all types of customers,
local lifestyles and environments. These diverse banners present a balanced mix of activities, brands and formats,
including urban, service, convenience, hypermarket and hard discount store formats, each of which reach out to
customers through multiple channels.

Monoprix

Our premium banner, Monoprix, is the leading French omni-channel city-center retailer, aiming to maximize
convenience and customer enjoyment through providing innovative services and a differentiated offering. As of
June 30, 2019, 771 stores operated under the Monoprix banner in France and abroad. For the twelve months ended
June 30, 2019, Monoprix stores, including all of its various formats, recorded net sales of €4,538 million.

166


-----

Monoprix stores are located in more than 250 town and city centers in France and aim to provide consumers with
a diversified product offering, including both food and non-food items such as cosmetics, apparel and housewares,
from both name brands and private-label brands, all under a single roof in a modern and friendly environment.

Monoprix has also developed other formats:

  - _Naturalia a leading retailer specializing in natural and organic products, with 195 stores as of as of June_
30, 2019 offering more than 6,000 items.

  - _Monop’ an ultra-convenience concept. These practical, welcoming stores provide a varied offering that_
meets basic daily needs and provides specialty product options. Monop’ operates in busy urban areas,
including in partnership with train stations, and along motorways. As of December 31, 2018, 149 stores
operated under the Monop’ concept, catering to an active, urban clientele.

  - _Monop’Daily a concept combining fast food with ultra-fresh products. With an average selling area of_
50 to 100 square meters, Monop’Daily stores offer a broad range of snacks, ready meals, dairy products,
beverages, fruit and desserts. As of December 31, 2018, 37 stores operated under the Monop’Daily
concept.

In 2018, we ramped up Monoprix’s omni-channel strategy by signing a partnership with Amazon to offer
Monoprix grocery items with express same-day delivery to Amazon Prime Now customers in Paris. This
agreement complements Monoprix’s exclusive alliance with Ocado in France, entered into in late 2017, which
provides for the construction of an automated warehouse in the Paris suburbs for home delivery of large basket
sizes. Lastly, in 2018, Monoprix acquired Sarenza, an online fashion and personal goods retailer, with a view to
making Monoprix.fr a leader in the fashion and personal goods segment in France, and to consolidate its position
in non-food e-commerce.

Casino Supermarkets

Casino Supermarkets is a banner of supermarkets operating in French city centers and rural areas, focused on a
strong commitment to pleasure, taste, high-quality fresh produce, knowledgeable food service personnel, choice
and customer service, and backed up by innovative digital solutions. As of June 30, 2019, 420 stores operated
under the Casino banner, of which 112 stores were franchises. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, Casino
Supermarkets recorded net sales of €3,015 million.

Casino Supermarkets are concentrated in three primary regions of France: southeastern France, the Rhône Valley
and greater Paris. Casino Supermarkets have an average selling area of 1,740 square meters. Casino Supermarkets
offer mainly food products, including organic and fresh produce, in-house pastries and baked goods, as well as an
array of non-food products, including capsule homeware and apparel collections.

Casino Supermarkets continue to develop their omni-channel offering and novel ways of expanding customers’
digital experience. As of December 31, 2018, approximately 95% of Casino Supermarkets offered e-commerce
solutions to their customers, such as click-and-drive service, where consumers can order their groceries online
and pick them up at a drive-through or a dedicated counter. More recently, Casino Supermarkets opened Le 4
Casino in Paris, which was designed to offer customers a unique shopping experience, including a variety of
innovative digital services enabling customers to shop 24 hours a day, seven days a week without going through
a physical checkout, to easily locate products in store, to choose from a broader range of products and services
through digital interfaces and to find more detailed information about the products on offer.

Franprix

Franprix is the Group’s main hyper-convenience banner for urban areas. Franprix stores are mainly established in
Paris and its surrounding areas, with almost all of its stores concentrated in this region, and in the heart of large
French cities in the Rhône Valley and the Mediterranean basin. As of June 30, 2019, a total of 888 stores operated
under the Franprix banner, including 443 franchises. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, Franprix stores
generated net sales of €1,566 million.

With an average selling area of 410 square meters per store, Franprix stores offer a range of food products intended
to satisfy the daily needs of consumers, combining essential national brands and private-label brands. In 2015, we
launched the Mandarine concept for Franprix stores, intended to transform them into friendly, practical and
pleasant stores. Since then, the concept has grown in line with the innovations created by the banner to drive food
service solutions, healthy and responsible ranges (e.g., scoop-and-weigh), and services aimed at giving Franprix
stores the feel of a local grocery store. These include in-store snacking areas, fresh fruit juicers, bicycle pump
access, phone charging stations, public WiFi access, in-store microwaves and quick delivery options. Ease of
access and flexible opening hours also contribute to the success of the Franprix banner, which launched its first

167


-----

stores that are open 24 hours a day, seven days a week in 2018. Recently, the Franprix banner has explored new
store concepts, including Noé, which offers an increased range of organic and vegan products in an inviting
atmosphere, and Le Drugstore Parisien, a partnership with L’Oréal Paris offering a wide selection of beauty
products.

Franprix continues to focus on innovation in the food retail sector. In September 2019, it entered into a partnership
with Hema, a Dutch company specializing in low-cost trendy housing gadgets and décor, to offer Hema products
in its stores. That same month, Franprix opened a pilot store in with its new, innovative Darwin concept, which
offers customers full kitchen access, including access to pizza ovens and fryers, a large seating area, larger scoopand-weigh offerings and a selection of Hema and Cdiscount products.

Géant Casino

Géant Casino is our French hypermarket banner which offers leading food brands with high-quality traditional
food selections, local fresh produce and a large organic product range and non-food products. Géant Casino
hypermarkets provide ample retail space on a human scale, with the average area measuring approximately 6,950
square meters as of December 31, 2018, which is less than the average surface area of our hypermarket competitors
in France. As of June 30, 2019, 113 hypermarkets operated under the Géant Casino banner, of which 6 stores were
operated by affiliates in France and 5 stores were operated by affiliates outside of France. For the twelve months
ended June 30, 2019, Géant Casino stores recorded net sales of €4,501 million.

In recent years, we have focused on our most profitable locations, reduced retail space and repositioned our Géant
Casino offering to favor product categories and channels adapted to customers’ preferences. For example, our
non-food offering is presented in a connected, user-friendly boutique format and focuses on leisure goods,
homeware and apparel collections, enhanced by in-store Cdiscount sales counters focused primarily on technical
goods. As of June 30, 2019, there were 55 Cdiscount counters in Géant Casino’s hypermarkets, which we believe
has had a positive impact on our sales. In line with its multi-channel approach and with a view to digitizing the
store experience, the banner has adopted the Casino Max app, which offers features including express scanning,
payment facilities, and targeted digital promotions.

Leader Price

Leader Price is our French banner operating stores with a hard discount retail format, and has been a major player
in the sector over 30 years. Leader Price is focused on meeting two criteria: very low prices and good-quality
products. It targets price-sensitive customers without compromising the quality of its product offerings. Leader
Price stores offer a comprehensive food range of over 5,000 items, including both private label and key nationalbrand products. A large number of Leader Price stores are operated through franchises. As of June 30, 2019, 665
stores operated under the Leader Price banner, of which 330 were franchise stores. For the twelve months ended
June 30, 2019, Leader Price stores recorded net sales of €2,320 million.

Leader Price has adapted its in-store experience to leverage its position as a discount food retailer to cater to the
ongoing price sensitivity of French shoppers, while respecting customers’ expectations for stores’ appearance and
product selection. For example, in 2018, Leader Price launched the “discount pleasure” concept, building on its
fundamental values of quality, price and efficiency to match the expectations of its customers, marked mainly by
a refreshed purchasing experience and reinforcing its offer of fresh and organic produce. The performance of
Leader Price stores has benefited from this as well as conversions to the “Next” concept, which sought to improve
customers’ in-store experience through fully redesigned retail spaces and revitalizing Leader Price stores’ fresh
produce departments.

On September 19, 2019, following speculative news coverage of our business strategy, we confirmed that we were
in talks with Aldi in connection with a possible transaction involving Leader Price.

Convenience Stores

Convenience stores round out our retail offering in France, consisting of smaller shops that are located in the heart
of towns, villages and urban centers. As of June 30, 2019, 5,142 convenience stores operated under our banners.
For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, our convenience stores recorded net sales of €1,324 million.

Our principal convenience banners include:

  - _Le Petit Casino, which is the Group’s historical convenience format, offering an extensive range of food_
products including high-quality fresh produce in urban and suburban areas;

brand goods, as well as other useful day-to-day services, including a loyalty program, home delivery,

  - _Spar, which operates in seasonal destinations and urban and suburban areas, offering a range of_

_Non-Retail Businesses_

Our non-retail operations in France span across a range of industry sectors, including energy, digital advertising,
data solutions, real estate, fast-food services and financial services.

GreenYellow

In 2009, we created GreenYellow, a business centered on solar energy and energy efficiency. Although
GreenYellow primarily operates in France, it has expanded its operations to international markets. GreenYellow
capitalizes on our expertise in the real estate sector through our knowledge of property development, construction
and operation, as well as on the favorable geographic location of our stores, to offer public and private customers
a wide range of solutions to produce and manage their energy.

GreenYellow, which began by installing rooftop photovoltaic systems and energy efficiency solutions in our
stores, today ranks as a leading French player in rooftop photovoltaic systems, with a robust set of external clients
representing an installed base of 190 MWp as of December 31, 2018 comprising more than 150 installations
covering approximately 1,013,000 square meters of shopping center and solar canopy rooftops (mainly on sites
belonging to our Group) at the end of 2018, and a pipeline of 350 MWp of future projects as of June 30, 2019.
Based on the installed base of 190 MWp at the end of 2018, we estimate that such systems save nearly 24,200
tons of carbon dioxide per year and are sufficient to cover the annual consumption of approximately 57,000
households.

GreenYellow’s main areas of expertise include:

  - The decentralized production of energy, such as through the integration of solar panels on roofs and car
parks: GreenYellow has developed, built and operated over 150 power plants in France and
internationally, both on sites that belong to our Group as well as sites belonging to third parties, including
industrial sites, communities and businesses. One example of a GreenYellow installation is its
construction of the largest solar plant in Colombia on the roof of our Éxito Panorama store in Baranquilla.
This plant has approximately 6,300 square meters of solar panels that can produce approximately 780
MWh per year, representing approximately 24% of the site’s electricity consumption.

  - Promoting energy efficiency through energy performance contracts: Through energy performance
contracts (“CPEs”), GreenYellow offers customers an innovative solution with an energy-saving
guarantee without investment from the client and with net gains from the first year. GreenYellow installs
energy efficient installations at a client’s site, the funding for which is fully compensated by the energy
savings realized by the installations. These gains in efficiency are guaranteed over the length of the CPE
by GreenYellow, which monitors the site’s energy consumption closely.

  - Purchasing energy and monitoring consumption: GreenYellow provides purchasing and monitoring
services for over 5,000 points of consumption.

  - Supplying energy to private individuals: Since 2017, GreenYellow has provided energy directly to
consumers.

GreenYellow continues to consolidate its leadership in the photovoltaic systems market. Its installed base includes
projects with industrial customers and local authorities in France, Thailand, Colombia, Morocco and Brazil.

3W.relevanC

We created 3W.relevanC in 2018 to leverage the large amounts of quality data about our customers and their
buying habits in stores and online to which we have access as part of our food retail business operations and
Cdiscount. 3W.relevanC is focused on the production of studies on purchasing behavior, the implementation of
targeted advertising campaigns offering more tailored deals to customers and measuring the impact of these
campaigns on in-store sales. In June 2019, 3W.relevanC entered into a partnership for digital direct advertising
with Conforama, a European leader in home furnishing and building supplies. As of September 30, 2019,
3W.relevanC had a database of 33.6 million anonymized customers, with information on their online and in-store

169


-----

behavior from which it can create specific customer profiles. During the year ended December 31, 2018 and the
six months ended June 30, 2019, 3W.relevanC generated net sales of €41 million and €24 million, respectively.

ScaleMax

In 2018, as part of our asset monetization strategy, we entered into a strategic partnership with Qarnot computing
to launch ScaleMax, a business that installs and operates new-generation data centers for clients in France seeking
access to high-performance computing capacity that is both sustainable and secure and can be rapidly deployed
on a large scale. In 2019, ScaleMax installed and began operating its first data center at a Cdiscount logistics
warehouse in the Greater Paris region, and as of June 30, 2019, over 10,000 cores (equivalent to approximately
1,000 servers) had already been deployed for customers other than Group entities. We expect that ScaleMax will
have signed or deployed nearly 16,000 additional cores at further data centers by the end of 2019.

public company that leases and manages shopping centers and city center retail space in France. As of December
31, 2018, the market value of the Group’s owned real estate portfolio in France was estimated to be approximately
€2.6 billion, including transfer duties (and excluding our share of property held by Mercialys). As of that date,
Mercialys managed over 48 shopping centers and seven city center assets with a combined area of over 873,000
square meters. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, Mercialys recorded revenue of €191 million.

Casino Restauration

Casino Restauration is one of our subsidiary companies that was historically positioned in the fast-food segment
through its operation of a chain of fast food franchise cafeterias in France. In recent years, however, Casino
Restauration has been repositioned through new concepts, including family restaurants such as À la Bonne Heure,
themed restaurants such as Villa Plancha, take-away food, such as Coeur de Blé and events catering services such
as its St Once business line.

Casino Restauration also owned R2C, a corporate food service business, the disposal of which was completed in
the first half of 2019 as part of the Asset Disposal Plan.

Banque Casino

Created in 2001, Banque Casino is a joint venture with French bank Crédit Mutuel CIC (“CM-CIC”), of which
we own 50%, that provides consumer finance programs and insurance products to Cdiscount and Géant
hypermarket customers. It has capitalized on our long-standing retail background and on the financial solidity of
CM-CIC to become an online banking option for customers, providing them with a wide choice of credit cards,
easy terms of payment and fully accessible on-line insurance. It has also developed innovative solutions for etailers, providing them with custom-made services such as payment by installments, allowing customers to pay
for goods online through a completely digital process in three or four separate installments. In 2018, Banque
Casino served 2.7 million customers and issued over €1.7 billion in loans.

_Indian Ocean Region_

Vindémia is the subsidiary through which we conduct our business operations in the Indian Ocean region,
including Madagascar, Mayotte and Mauritius. Currently the area’s retailing leader, we have a multi-format
presence in the Indian Ocean region, positioned through hypermarkets, supermarkets, discount stores,
convenience stores and franchised stores. Our banners in the region include Douka bé, Jumbo, La Croissanterie,
Score, Score Express, Sherpa, SNIE, Supercash, SuperMaki, Spar and Vival. As of June 30, 2019, we had a total
of 246 stores operating under our Vindémia subsidiary.

On July 22, 2019, we announced that we had signed an agreement to sell Vindémia to GBH for an enterprise value
of €219 million as part of our Asset Disposal Plan. The sale is expected to be completed after consultation with
employee representative bodies and is subject to approval by the French Competition Authority.

2019, the Latam Retail segment, which consolidates the Latin American operations, recorded net sales of €15,885

GPA operated 1,059 retail stores in Brazil. As of December 31, 2018, GPA employed 101,230 employees in
Brazil.

Over the past few years, GPA has adapted its positioning to meet changing consumer needs, particularly through

reinforce a culture of innovation.

Retail Businesses

Our retail business in Colombia is carried out through Grupo Éxito, which is Colombia’s leading food retailer.
Grupo Éxito does business in Colombia under a number of different banners representing a broad array of store
formats, including hypermarkets, supermarkets, convenience and discount store formats. As of June 30, 2019,
Grupo Éxito operated 531 stores in 112 cities across Colombia (excluding affiliate stores).

Grupo Éxito also has a network of developed independent franchisees which operate 1,469 stores. Grupo Éxito is
focused on expanding its store offerings to innovative new formats. For example, in late 2017, Grupo Éxito
launched Carulla FreshMarket, a new concept for its premium Carulla markets, offering its customers locally

launched Éxito WOW, an innovative hypermarket concept offering customers 24-hour shopping access in its
warehouse spaces to shop for food and non-food products through an integrated physical and virtual experience.
Grupo Éxito has recently expanded and strengthened its cash & carry operations in Colombia, such as through the
launch of its new Surtimayorista banner, to fight competition from discount retailers. It is also focused on

applications, which represented 3.4% of its net sales at the end of 2018. For example, Grupo Éxito, in partnership
with Bancolombia, launched a customer loyalty mobile application, Puntos Colombia, which allows customers to
earn points for purchases and qualify for future purchase discounts.

_Cdiscount_

In addition to our traditional brick-and-mortal retail banners and their related multi-channel e-commerce
operations, we operate a pure non-food e-commerce business under the Cdiscount banner through our publicly
traded subsidiary, Cnova, in which we have 63.4% of the voting rights and a 64.8% economic interest. Cdiscount
acts as both a direct retailer and service provider to customers in 25 countries in Europe, as well as a marketplace
for third parties offering products and services to customers using Cdiscount’s hosting platform. As of
June 30, 2019, Cdiscount offered approximately 9.2 million active customers (defined as a customer having
purchased at least once through one of Cdiscount’s websites or its app during the prior twelve months) access to
a wide and growing assortment of more than 48 million product offerings, as well as a range of services. Cdiscount
is the number two e-commerce site in France in terms of UMV, attracting an average of 19.6 million UMV during
the second quarter of 2019 and 956.7 million total site visits during all of 2018. Cdiscount offers a customer
loyalty program, à Volonté, which had 2 million registered members at the end of June 2019. For the twelve
months ended June 30, 2019, our E-commerce segment recorded net sales of €1,979 million.

The products offered to consumers on Cdiscount’s sites include electrical appliances, furniture and decor, bedding,
hardware, computer hardware and software, toys, automotive goods, sports equipment and wine. During the year
ended December 31, 2018, Cdiscount sold products with a gross merchandise value of €3,646 million either
through direct sales or through its marketplace.

Cdiscount also offers a broad range of services to consumers. Its service offering includes discount energy and
heating oil through Cdiscount Énergie, discount travel arrangements through Cdiscount Voyages and concert and
other event ticket sales through Cdiscount Billeterie. Cdiscount also offers consumers mobile phone plans, health
and vision insurance, credit cards and short-term consumer loans through its Cdiscount Coup de Pouce program.
With its acquisition of online personal service provider Stootie in 2018, Cdiscount expanded its service offering
to include a platform through which consumers seeking help with a home improvement project, moving, cleaning,
electrical and plumbing work or appliance repairs can find providers to meet their needs.

Consumers are able to purchase products on Cdiscount’s sites either directly from Cdiscount or via a marketplace
from third-party vendors. Merchants pay a monthly subscription fee for Cdiscount to host a store on one of its
websites, and Cdiscount also receives a commission on all sales carried out by third-party merchants through
Cdiscount’s marketplace, which varies based on product category and whether the product is new or used.

In addition, Cdiscount offers ancillary services to merchants using its marketplace. For example, since 2014,
Cdiscount has proposed fulfillment services to third-party sellers in France to promote the competitiveness and
growth of the Cdiscount marketplace as well as to shorten marketplace delivery times. Cdiscount’s fulfillment
services handle storage, preparation, shipping and customer service on behalf of its marketplace sellers, which
enables sellers to increase their turnover and benefit from speedy delivery and increased customer satisfaction.
Moreover, merchants can purchase monthly subscriptions to various Premium Packs, which bundle services such
as customizable online shops, activity reports and analysis. As of December 31, 2018, Premium Packs were

174


-----

subscribed by more than 25% of Cdiscount’s vendor base. The revenues arising from this ecosystem of services
increased by 2.3 times in 2018.

Cdiscount’s delivery solutions remain at the cutting edge of technology: roll-out of real time geolocation on large
parcel delivery now covers approximately 97% of Cdiscount’s order flow and on-demand delivery was launched
in June 2018.

Although Cdiscount generates a substantial majority of its net sales from online transactions, Cdiscount also has
a physical presence in certain of our French retail banners’ stores. During 2018, 45 new Cdiscount showrooms
opened in Géant hypermarkets, bringing the total network to 49 as of December 31, 2018, with further openings
planned in 2019.

Finally, to capture new clients outside its 2017 geographic footprint, Cnova has successfully expanded in Europe
through partnerships with marketplaces in foreign countries and direct deliveries from its French warehouses.
Cnova products are currently available in 25 European countries. In September 2019, Cdiscount announced an
acceleration of its international strategy through its alliance with three European marketplaces: real.de in
Germany, ePrice in Italy and eMag in Romania. This alliance, International Marketplace Network, or IMN, which
was implemented in October 2019, will allow marketplace vendors of these websites to easily and automatically
broadcast and sell their products on all four websites.

**Management of Real Estate Portfolio**

We actively manage our property assets in France in line with our debt reduction plan and our transformation
toward a less capital-intensive model. As of December 31, 2018, the market value of the Group’s owned real
estate portfolio in France was estimated to be approximately €2.6 billion, including transfer duties (and excluding
our share of property held by Mercialys), compared with €3.9 billion at the end of 2017, mainly due to disposals
of real estate assets in the amount of €1.1 billion, including transfer duties, as well as various effects for €0.2
billion (for example, the annual review of rates of rental yield and market rental values, taking into account trends
in the commercial real estate market, acquisitions and revaluations of property).

Our integrated internal teams create value for our Group as well as for third parties that own the real estate assets
where we operate our retail stores through research and design, strategic land purchases, delegated project
management, property development and management, property letting, management of related legal affairs and
asset value enhancement and management.

To address changing consumer habits, we have adapted our hypermarket model by reducing selling areas and the
percentage of non-food product offerings and by optimizing other spaces, particularly stock rooms. This optimized
space presents an opportunity to increase the size and appeal of shopping malls by hosting specialist mid-sized
retailers. In 2018, we executed our strategy of reducing retail space devoted to non-food items in our hypermarkets
and creating additional shopping mall space through (i) the delivery of three hypermarket transformation projects
in Annecy, Besançon and Angers La Roseraie which created 4,000 square meters of shopping mall space, (ii) the
sale of two Géant hypermarket projects in Saint-Nazaire and Montpellier Argelliers in furtherance of the plan to
reduce the retail space of the Géant outlet to create medium-sized areas covering 3,500 square meters of GLA and
(iii) the opening of the first phase of the planned extension of the Port Sacré-Coeur site in Réunion, with a shopping
mall development covering 8,300 square meters of GLA.

**Valuation of IGC’s Real Estate Portfolio**

Certain independent property valuation specialists have carried out a valuation of a large part of IGC’s real estate
assets on an individual property basis as of December 31, 2018, from which all figures in the section “Summary—
_IGC—Overview of Real Estate Assets” are derived. The valuations were prepared on the basis of certain_
qualifications and assumptions, estimates and projections.

In particular, the valuation process did not include a review of all of IGC’s properties or lease agreements and is
thus based on a sample of physical visits over the last three years. The valuation process included a review of
high-level information provided by management, including the possibility to obtain specific building permits, the
properties’ financial performance, property refurbishment and expansionary capital expenditures, material
structural issues and summary lease information. Valuation specialists based their valuation on the assumption
that IGC and its subsidiaries held good title to the properties and that lease terms did not contain restrictive or
unusual terms or any unusual, tax, environment, planning or other restrictions associates therewith.

The valuations are based on the projected mature trading potential of our properties, including assumptions
regarding rental revenues, capital expenditure levels based on our historical and budgeted expenditure levels, or
alternative use value for a limited number of obsolete facilities that we have closed and expect to sell. Most
valuations also took into account the market liquidity of the property, along with market comparables. The thirdparty valuations also did not consider any potential environmental contamination, lead, radon, infestation or other
pollutants or hazardous materials at the properties, which would have a negative impact on any valuations. In
addition, as the valuation process was conducted on an individual property basis, central costs were not considered.
Other appraisers may reach different valuations of our property portfolio. Moreover, the third party valuation and

176


-----

update included herein could be significantly higher than the amount obtained from the actual sale of our property
portfolio, especially in a distressed or liquidation scenario. Accordingly, the valuation and update should not be
considered as a guarantee of present or future value.

See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to our Business and Industry—We cannot assure you that the projections or
_assumptions used, estimates made or procedures followed in the third party valuation of IGC’s portfolio of real_
_estate assets are correct, accurate or complete”._

**Suppliers & Logistics**

We have a large network of suppliers and we believe that we provide an important channel for these suppliers to
access customers. In 2018, our top 10 suppliers represented 10.4% of our cost of goods sold. We work with over
60,000 suppliers who supply us with both private-label and national brand products. Our supplier base is
characterized by numerous stable, long-term relationships with suppliers from a wide variety of backgrounds,
including suppliers of leading or national brands, suppliers of our private-label products, small-to-medium
enterprises or cooperatives and farmers who supply our stores locally and suppliers of goods and services for
general and administrative purposes. Typically, supplier contracts are renewed on a yearly basis. We select our
suppliers based on strict specifications related to product quality. We do not believe that we are dependent on any
one supplier or that the loss of any one supplier would have a material adverse effect on our business.

We actively seek to maintain regular and constructive dialogue with our suppliers and have won awards for our
supplier collaborations, including three Grés d’Or prizes rewarding our relations with small-to-medium
enterprises in France.

To limit the social and environmental impact of our purchases, we have circulated the Supplier Ethics Charter
since 2011. This Charter specifies our expectations regarding freedom of association, which must be respected
across the supply chain, by reaffirming our commitment to banning all illegal practices in business relations and
requiring compliance with applicable laws and standards; upholding human rights and ensuring occupational
health and safety; and taking constant care to protect the environment through the efficient use of natural resources
and diligent waste management and pollution abatement. In 2014, we signed an initial Corporate Social
Responsibility agreement which affirmed the importance of encouraging suppliers to address CSR issues in their
own supply chain and to promote their responsible products; the need to continue training buyers in the standards
defined in the Supplier Ethics Charter and to take working conditions and environmental criteria into account
when selecting suppliers; and the importance of auditing supplier production facilities in countries deemed at risk
and assisting them, to the extent possible or necessary, in deploying corrective action plans.

Our supply chains are organized at the country level and differ banner by banner. For example, in France, for our
retail operations, our specialized subsidiary, Easydis, makes deliveries from 16 sites throughout the country
representing approximately 740,000 square meters of warehousing. We also outsource certain of our logistics
needs, such as transport and courier services, and enter into logistics partnerships designed to reduce supply chain
costs. Our supply chain management information system, from our suppliers to our retail stores, is covered by an
integrated information system. We use specific software to analyze the information we gather from our
distribution network. We believe that the strength and quality of our logistics network is critical to the freshness
of our products, quality control and customer satisfaction. We aim to optimize our logistics systems through
automation, robotization, pooling of warehouses and partnerships with last mile delivery experts. We seek to
reduce the environmental footprint of our supply chain by using alternative modes of transport.

Logistics is particularly crucial to the success of our e-commerce business. Cdiscount has a network of 10
distribution centers in France with a combined total of 523,000 square meters spread across three main regions:
Paris, Lyon and Bordeaux. To support its growing product assortment, a new warehouse of 80,000 square meters
was opened near Paris (Moissy) in June 2018 and a new warehouse of 60,000 square meters was opened near
Lyon in Andrézieux, France in July 2019. To efficiently process the large number of orders received, Cdiscount
has automated and custom-designed its warehouse space, using 3D packing machines which allow the creation of
customized packaging for each order, generating cost savings, and reducing cardboard usage with up to 30% less
wasted space, and installing automated sorting systems to increase the speed of order processing.

In Brazil, GPA operates 22 distribution centers and depots strategically located across the country, with a total
storage capacity of 650,000 square meters as of June 30, 2019. The locations of the distribution centers enable
GPA to make frequent shipments to retail stores, which reduces the need for large in-store inventory spaces, and
limits non-productive store inventories. GPA uses pd@net, a business-to-business technology platform, which
links GPA’s computer-automated system to distribution centers and suppliers in order to automatically replenish
retail store inventory.

**Quality Control**

Product quality and safety are our top priorities. We have developed an end-to-end system from product
specifications to store operations that ensures we sell safe, healthy products of the highest quality. Our
international quality control system is deployed through a number of different channels, including through our
centralized internal Group Quality department that is fully dedicated to monitoring and enforcing quality
assurance and food safety standards and procedures, and managing any quality or food safety issue across our
entire supply chain. The Group Quality department coordinates with subsidiary quality departments to share best
practices and procedures in such areas as product quality and safety policies, traceability, supplier audits, crisis
management and product withdrawal and recall. We perform regular on-side audits of production facilities, with
emphasis of health and safety risks in compliance with Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point principles. In
particular, our audits focus on the inspection of suppliers of private-label food products, our own warehouses to
verify that best practice procedures and guidelines are being followed and our retail store locations in France.

In addition, we conduct various product quality controls throughout the year, including several inspections of our
private-label products by independent laboratories, microbiology analyses by our banners’ quality departments to
manage any potentially serious health risks, sensory analyses conducted with customers to monitor taste, aroma
and sensory characteristics of our products, and grading of produce and butcher meats in warehouses through
approximately 320,000 annual inspections.

Our French and Latin American operations are members of initiatives which set global benchmarks for food safety
standards throughout the supply chain. For example, in 2018, we conducted a total of 33,994 microbiology tests
in France to control food, household and health and beauty products.

We sell high quality private-label food products and work to ensure the quality and safety of our products across
every private-label product range. To that end, we have defined strict contractually binding specifications for
every sourced private-label product which ensure that the supplier delivers a product that complies both with
applicable legislation and the quality grade expected by the banners. These specifications consist of descriptive
technical data, compliance statements and analysis reports.

In addition to the foregoing systems that are deployed on an international level, our individual subsidiaries also
develop and deploy their own quality control and product safety programs.

**Information Systems**

Our information systems are critical to our business operations. They provide management, analytical and
performance evaluation tools that assist management at all levels to undertake business processes. Our technical
infrastructure and computer applications are also used for the day-to-day management of our business, including
purchasing, sourcing, distribution, online sales, loyalty program management, data exploitation, invoicing, cash
collection, reporting, consolidation and electronic data interchange. Our business depends on the ability of our
employees to process transactions on secure information systems and our capacity to store, retrieve, process and
manage information.

Our information systems are highly integrated, covering most of our fundamental business service areas. We have
developed a target model based primarily on two well-known management software suites for administrative
functions and sales functions. This model encompasses IT standards and governance frameworks to ensure that
our information systems are geared to our current and future objectives.

We have a dedicated department, the Group Information Systems Security Department, that ensures the security
of our information systems by regularly assessing each unit’s information systems security, ensuring that action
plans have been drawn up to address areas for improvement and leveraging synergies between information
systems security departments to coordinate initiatives and ensure a consistent level of security across our lines of
business.

We believe that our information systems are robust, adequate to support our activities and operate at standards
that are comparable to other operators in our industry.

Our main banners have established loyalty programs (including digital programs) to improve customer

On September 12, 2017, GPA received a request for arbitration from Fundo de Investimento Inmobiliáro Península

**_DGCCRF proceedings_**

On February 28, 2017, the French Ministry of the Economy, represented by the Department of Competition Policy,
Consumer Affairs and Fraud Control (the “DGCCRF”), brought an action against Casino in the Paris Commercial
Court concerning a series of credits totaling €22.2 million issued in 2013 and 2014 granted to our Group by 41
suppliers. The DGCCRF claims that we demanded that these credits be given to us in an illicit manner outside the

scope of our annual supply contracts and conditioned our future business relations on the grant of such credits.
The DGCCRF is seeking repayment of this sum to the suppliers concerned and the imposition of a fine of €2
